PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have received a letter from the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) advising of his resignation from the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

DEBATE.TITLE: DECLARATION AND REGISTRATION OF MEMBERS' INTERESTS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-

(1) this House re-affirms the requirement for the registration and declaration of the interests of Members, their spouses and dependent children adopted by the House of Representatives on 9 October 1984 a.m.;
(2) the following amendments be made to resolution (2) of the House of Representatives of 9 October 1984 a.m.:
(a) sub-paragraph (b) (ii) after ``trustee'' insert ``(but not including a trustee of an estate where no beneficial interest is held by the Member, the Member's spouse or dependent children)'';
(b) omit paragraph (d), substitute the following paragraph:
``(d) registered directorships of companies'';
(c) omit paragraph (e), substitute the following paragraph:
``(e) partnerships indicating the nature of the interests and the activities of the partnership;'';
(d) paragraph (f) omit ``(excluding short-term credit arrangements)'';
(e) paragraph (i) omit ``including collections, but'';

(f) at the end of paragraph (k) add ``provided that a gift received by a Member, the Member's spouse or dependent children from family members or personal friends in a purely personal capacity need not be registered unless the Member judges that an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist'';
(g) omit paragraph (m), substitute the following paragraph:
``(m) membership of any organisation, and'', and
(h) at the end of the resolution add the following paragraph:
``(n) any other interests where a conflict of interest with a Member's public duties could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise.'';
(3) the Committee of Members' Interests be required to determine a form for registration of interests by 10 April 1986;

(4) each current Member of the House of Representatives be required to provide to the Registrar of Members' Interests by 15 May 1986 a statement of the registrable interests of the Member, the Member's spouse and any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support, as provided by the resolutions of 9 October 1984 a.m. as amended by this resolution'', and
(5) any Member of the House of Representatives who
(a) knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests by the due date;
(b) knowingly fails to notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests within 28 days of the change occurring or
(c) knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Members' Interests
shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the House of Representatives and shall be dealt with by the House accordingly.

In moving this motion, I point out that I have indicated to the Opposition that representations were made to me by the Chairman of the Standing Committee of Members' Interests, the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), that in the timetable referred to in paragraph (4) of the motion members were asked to return their forms by 15 May 1986 so that those forms could be tabled this session. The honourable member for Prospect impressed upon me that he thought there was a rather short period between the preparation of the forms by 10 April and their return by 15 May. I indicate to honourable members that we are prepared to amend that timetable so that the forms will have to be returned by 30 June 1986 for tabling on the first day of the Budget session.

On the last day of the 1985 Budget sittings, I tabled for the information of honourable members a statement of the Government's response to the report of the Committee of Members' Interests concerning the registration of members' interests. The resolution which I have moved reflects the Government's continued commitment to a scheme for registration of members' interests. It is a principle to which the Government has been formally and publicly committed for some years. We believe it to be an important additional means of reinforcing the faith of the Australian people in this Parliament and in their members. The amendments which I have now moved to the original resolution establishing the system of registration are in response to a number of concerns raised by the Committee.

I wish to emphasise at the start of this debate that the Government is determined to move on registration of members' interests, despite the fact that the Senate has given no indication that it will take a similar initiative. Ideally, the Government would like to see a scheme introduced in both Houses simultaneously. As that is not to be, we hope that this scheme will serve as an incentive to the Senate as well as provide a model for action. I also reiterate at the outset the Government's intention to stick firmly to two of the essential elements of the scheme originally proposed; namely the publication of the register and the inclusion of the financial interests of spouses and dependent children as far as these are known to the member.

On the question of the publication of the register, the Committee expressed concern that the register would be so accessible as to pose a threat to the person or property of members and their families. But the register will list only the nature of assets and interests, not their monetary value. There will be no requirement on members, as there is on Ministers, to stipulate the financial value of their assets in a privately held register. We believe that publication of the register is essential to the development of public confidence in the registration scheme. Only publication of the register will ensure that conflicts of interest can be avoided and can be seen to be avoided.

The Committee also questioned the need for the inclusion of spouses and dependent children in the scheme, and reported the feeling of a number of members that it was an indefensible invasion of privacy. The Government's requirement that these interests be registered stems from what we consider to be an indisputable fact: Whilst there is no public register of those interests as far as they are known to the member, they could possibly affect members' actions in the House or in the party room, or be thought to be influencing actions. As such, their inclusion is an essential safeguard of the scheme. And it goes no further than absolutely necessary. It does not, for example, extend to non-dependent children.

I would like to comment on two other general issues-what is a conflict of interest, and what penalties should apply to non-compliance with the scheme-before addressing a number of detailed questions raised in the report. A central concern raised by the Committee is the question of what constitutes a conflict of interest. Obviously there are problems in defining all possible conflicts of interest. But the problems are not insoluble and they should not deter us from pursuing a sensible and practical registration scheme. The Government's scheme provides a firm framework. Beyond that, it is a matter for the judgment of members, and for the judgment and discretion of the Registrar of Members' Interests. That is not asking too much. The Committee has recommended that we consider introducing penalties for non-compliance with the registration scheme. We believe that non-compliance with the scheme should be treated by the House as a serious contempt. Members who are guilty of non-compliance could then be reprimanded or suspended or other appropriate action could be taken.

I wish now to turn briefly to some of the other questions of detail raised in the report. We agree with the Committee that trustees of estates, who have no beneficial interest in the estates, should not be required to disclose their trusteeship arrangements. We endorse the Committee conclusion that all directorships of companies should be registered.

We agree with the Committee that information required on partnerships should concern only the purpose of operations of the partnership and the level of current involvement by the member. We agree with the Committee view that short term liabilities should be registered. The Committee, in developing a form, should prepare guidelines for the benefit of members as to what short term credit arrangements need to be registered. We accept the Committee's judgment that membership of all organisations should be included in the register.

The Committee made the point that there could be difficulties in making a distinction between `collections' and other particular assets and that there may be particular security problems in registering collections. The Government accepts that in most cases the ownership of a collection would be unlikely to bring a member into a situation where he or she faces a conflict of interest, and is prepared to dispense with the distinction. It is now proposed simply to register other assets over a certain value, other than household or personal effects.

The Government agrees with the Committee that a sensible approach needs to be taken to the question of the registration of gifts. We believe that the guideline suggested by the Committee is a sound one-that is, that a gift received by a member, the member's spouse or dependent children from family members or personal friends in a purely personal capacity need not be disclosed unless the member judges that an appearance of conflict of interest may be seen to exist. The guideline puts the onus on the member to exercise judgment. We would propose reviewing the effectiveness of this arrangement, together with other elements of the scheme including the appropriateness of the sums of money specified throughout the resolution, after a suitable period of operation.

The Committee recognised that sponsored travel and hospitality have particular potential for producing conflicts of interest. We note the difficulties raised by the Committee in determining which elements of sponsored travel or hospitality should be included in the scheme. With regard to sponsored travel, we agree with the Committee's definition and obviously accept that the scheme should not include any entitlement received under any determination by the Remuneration Tribunal nor travel undertaken as a member of an official parliamentary delegation. In respect of hospitality, we recognise the need for members to exercise a degree of judgment, and recommend that the Committee draft guidelines along the line of the distinctions made in the report. This is another area which we would propose reviewing after a reasonable operating period.

Finally, I should like to comment on the Committee's suggestion that a similar scheme might also be applied to journalists working in the Parliament. As the Committee pointed out, members of the parliamentary press gallery are uniquely placed to exert considerable influence in the decision-making process. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) advised the House in September 1983 that the Government would consider inviting both the Australian Journalists Association and the parliamentary Press Gallery to develop a similar system to the one that we will be adopting to register their members' interests. We stick by that view. After we finalise our registration scheme I will be writing to the AJA and the gallery drawing their attention to our arrangements and inviting them to formulate and introduce similar requirements for their members. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Committee of Members' Interests was brought in at the end of last year. It was a unanimous report. In paragraph 3 of the report the Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Since that date-
referring to an earlier date-

the committee has held seven meetings at which it has been endeavouring to determine a form of return. It has failed to do so because of potential difficulties foreseen in the registration requirements and because of inequities arising from those requirements.

As usual, we have had the scantest possible notice of the proposals introduced by the Special Minister of State (Mr Young). They arrived in my room shortly before 9 o'clock. The proposals are of profound importance to members of this House, yet they have been given-and given deliberately-no notice at all. The proposals go a little distance to curing some of the deficiencies pointed out in the report but they do not go any distance at all to meeting some of the fundamental problems raised in the report and the reasons why this registration proposal should not be acceded to by this House. The concerns which are expressed in the report-I emphasise again that it was a unanimous report, a report by all parties in this House chaired by the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman)-include the following: First, we have members included but not senators. The senators do not agree to this proposal. The Government has said that it will pursue the proposal with the Senate, but it is perfectly plain that that has yet to be done and it is unlikely that the Senate will agree. Paragraph 7 of the report states:

The Committee cannot see the justification for differing arrangements between the Australian House of Representatives and the Senate. It could even be said that with the present balance of power situation existing in the Senate the registration of Senators' interests is more important than the registration of those of Members of the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, because they influence decisions.

—Exactly. As the honourable member for Barker has said, they influence decisions. We all know that the comment made in the report reflects parliamentary process. Down here we vote on party lines. The Australian Labor Party must vote on party lines. One will never see any member of the Labor Party ever crossing the floor regardless of how deeply, how profoundly and how sincerely he may disagree with the position taken by his Party. We have done it and I have done it because we are not simply party ciphers, but it illustrates the great difference between the House of Representatives and the Senate. Quite simply, it does not matter what is said by members of the governing party, when it is the Labor Party in this House, because it has to follow what the Executive tells it. It is profoundly naive to suggest that in fact if there is some kind of registration system it will save the Government or will save the members from some conflict of interest. We all know that senators do influence the passing of legislation in a way that does not happen down here. We all know that the Australian Democrats at present hold the balance of power. We know that senators from the Liberal Party of Australia cross the floor from time to time on issues about which they feel strongly. That is the reason, if we are going to have these absurd registration proposals, why they should apply to the Senate, not simply to the House, and apply to the Senate with far greater force.

SPEECH.PARA: Next, we have a public register. I suppose that will satisfy some members of the Left of the Labor Party. That public register, I am glad to say, will not include reference to monetary values, which is an improvement on what was proposed originally. Why should there be a public register? Why should there be any register at all? Why-this is another objection raised by the Committee-should spouses' interests be declared? This was something that concerned the Committee. Why is it that any person here has to come to Parliament and declare on a public register what his wife has or her husband has? It may be something which has been learned in marriage and which has no bearing upon the work of the member; yet these matters are to be made public. Why should this outrageous invasion of privacy be allowed? Why should it be pursued by the Government in pursuit of this fantasy that we will have a register which will somehow change the way things work in the Parliament and change it for the better? The unanswered question is this: What good will this register do? The purpose, one would assume, is plain enough. The Government will tell us that the purpose is to ensure that members act in the interests of the Australian community and not their own. That is the underlying purpose. If that is not met by this register, it should be junked.

Let us look at some of the ways in which that purpose is simply not met. Firstly, anyone who wishes to evade will simply rearrange his or her affairs. Does anybody here really suggest that we will legislate for honesty and morality and that if a person comes to this House who is neither honest nor moral, that person will say: `Yes, I do see the force of all this, I will not rearrange my affairs, I will disclose all'? Really, one has only to state the proposition to realise how patently absurd it is. It is as though we are saying that the corrupt will not evade; that the corrupt will obey. Of course they will not. Their affairs can be rearranged, and those who find the intent of this objectionable in terms of requiring them to disclose matters which they are minded not to disclose because of a dishonest intention will so arrange things that they will appear to disclose all. The careless and the honest, who may by chance transgress, may be caught, but one can be assured that the corrupt, the immoral, the shifty and the dishonest will not.

It is a remarkable irony that we come to this House with this Government and this Minister preaching to us on matters of public morality. It was, the House may recall, this Minister some time ago who breached Cabinet security; who told a friend of his something which was the subject of the report of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. We need not go over that report in this House, but the Minister's experience and this Government's experience would tell us that this kind of register is perfectly fruitless and useless. If one is going to breach a confidence of Cabinet, is one going to be caught by a public register? Of course one is not. If one treats Cabinet with contempt, one will treat a public register with equal contempt; indeed, one would think with a great deal more contempt.

The next objection is the invasion of privacy. Nothing has been done to meet that. As I said, if we learn something because we are married, are we now to be compelled to disclose what we learn and what, let us assume, no one else would be told? We would have to say to the House: `Look, true it is that my husband or wife would never have disclosed this to anybody else. True it is that he or she thought it was a private matter that should not be publicly ventilated'. However this information would be placed on the public register. What good would that do? How would this advance the way in which we work here and how would it improve the standards of morality of this House? The answer is that it would not. This would be a profound, deep and unforgivable breach of confidence.

All members from both sides of the House would think that people with a great deal to contribute should be attracted to this House and into public life generally. None of us would think that we alone are the best and we would all agree that both sides of this House could be markedly improved if some of the more talented members of our community entered this place. Everyone knows that one of the reasons why people do not enter public life in this country is the profound contempt and profound feelings of aversion they have for the invasion of their personal privacy that entry into public life demands. What we are doing is reinforcing every suspicion that good Australians, be they Labor, be they Liberal, be they National, be they from any other party, may feel about entering public life. If we want to keep them out of Parliament, if we want to make sure that good people will be reinforced in their aversion to public life, go ahead and have this absurd system of registration.

As we know, the Senate is not involved in this proposal. The members of the Government Party in the Senate are not involved. The Senate is the only House with real power. It is one thing to say to the Parliament that every member of the Executive-that is, every member of the Cabinet-should disclose information. However, it is profoundly stupid to say that members of Parliament, for example, members on the Opposition benches during the term of a Labor government, should disclose on the basis that in some way they are going to influence things.

What we would see with the adoption of this proposal would be a ratchet effect on issues of public morality. In the so-called pursuit of proper disclosure, we would find a vehicle for political assassination. Records would be minutely examined. Errors made in good faith without attempt to hide, to dissimulate or to deceive, would be branded as deliberate dishonesty. We know that there is no pity, no mercy and precious little sense of fair play in this House when those questions arise. The Government's proposal will simply reinforce all of the problems that arise from the hunt for the error made in good faith, the error which will be transformed into something which was done in bad faith with intent to deceive.

Finally, it is profoundly naive to think that what is proposed here will make the slightest difference. It will not. However, it is fundamentally wrong and fundamentally obnoxious. It is something which would do not just damage to the way in which the House may work or to notions of personal privacy but something which would act as a bar to good people coming into public life. I wish to move an amendment in the terms of notice No. 65 in the name of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) as listed in the Notice Paper No. 67 of 12 February. I move:

That the preamble to the resolutions adopted by the House on 9 October 1984, a.m., relating to the declaration and registration of Members' interests by amended by adding the following proviso: ``Provided that these requirements will not come into effect unless the Senate has adopted resolutions requiring Senators to meet similar requirements''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment.

—Members might like to note that the Leader of the House amended the circulated motion by omitting `15 May' in paragraph (4) and substituting `30 June'. Members should amend their copies of the motion accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Madam Speaker, on your election to the office of Speaker.
—I should have done the same thing, Madam Speaker. It was most discourteous of me not to congratulate you as I stood up. I do so now.
—Thank you.

—There are a number of points to be raised. I am tempted to support the amendments moved by the Opposition, but obviously I will not. It is clear that I could do so because our Caucus has not discussed this matter. If Caucus had discussed the matter I am sure it would feel strongly that senators should provide the same details as we do. But that is not my main point. I thank the Leader of the House (Mr Young) for agreeing to make available the longer time in which members can reply. It is important to realise that the questions will be quite difficult to answer. I hope that the Committee can provide a form by 10 April. It ought to be able to do so because it had a form drafted to deal with the original proposition. The Committee sought clarification from the House. It will get that in the terms of today's resolution and will amend the form accordingly. There are still problems associated with the form, some of which I will raise. There will be people involved with assets who may need advice from accountants or lawyers before they can reply to the form in an acceptable way.

SPEECH.PARA: Without wishing to criticise the Ministry too much, it is worthwhile remembering that some 27 Ministers provided a similar sort of statement on 22 September 1983. It was tabled. Within a fortnight or three weeks, at least half of them-13, 14 or 15-amended the form quite significantly. We have not seen any amendment since, but amendments should have been tabled yearly, as I understood it at the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Backbenchers are a lot brighter than Ministers.

—Maybe they are, but it should not have been too difficult for Ministers whose wives receive quite a high income in public positions to mention that when there is a specific question asking what other income is coming into the family. One Minister forgot about his wife's income of some $60,000.

SPEECH.PARA: I take issue with the Minister's proposition that we asked for penalties to be introduced. If he looks at the bottom of page 14 of our report he will see that the last sentence states:
However, it should be made clear-
we had been discussing penalties-
that the Committee neither advocates nor recommends the introduction of specific penalties for failure to comply with the registration requirements.

We did not ask for the introduction of penalties. I raised the question of penalties to ask what the House intends to do. What do we intend to do about resolutions of the House? Let us assume that a number of members-not just one member-fails to provide a statement. According to the resolution they would be guilty of a serious contempt of the House and `shall be dealt with by the House accordingly'. What do we intend to do? Let us assume that all members of the Opposition decided not to provide a statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not make any difference if they were not here.

—Are we going to have a mini-election involving only one side of the House? Let us think the proposition through before we decide that a member `shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the House and shall be dealt with accordingly'. The resolution goes on to say that if a member `knowingly fails to notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests within 28 days of the change occurring' he `shall be guilty of a serious contempt'. We have now decided, and I think it is correct, that the liabilities of members should be registered. I think that liabilities are much more important than assets as far as pressure on members is concerned. If there is a suggestion that members can be influenced the member who can be influenced is much more likely to be the member who has significant short term liabilities and where there is pressure on him or her.
—In particular, with interest rates as they are now.

—The honourable member for Moreton was given a huge asset by this House in error. We thought that we would not see him again. We are now eliminating the caveat about excluding short term liabilities. What this means-it depends on the definition of `nature'-is that as one charges more things to Bankcard, Visa, American Express or whatever, one is supposed to register the fact within 28 days. That is a possible interpretation. It depends on what is meant by `nature'. Does `nature' mean the actual amount or does it mean that we say we have short term liabilities with MasterCard or whatever? Those questions require some fairly intelligent thought. I hope the Committee will come to the conclusion that by `nature' the member will be required to say only that he has access to MasterCard, Visa or whatever and that, therefore, there will be some short term liabilities at most times in that respect. The member will not have to provide the actual details. It could be argued that if one does not provide actual details the whole thing becomes fairly meaningless.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that there are some positive aspects of the proposal. I think that the Australian public ought to be aware-I am pleased that the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) is in the chamber because it has been alleged that he has received a sponsored trip to South Africa; I do not know whether he has or not and whether the South African Government paid for all or part of the trip-that from now on it will be necessary for people to register sponsored travel. That does not apply only to South Africa. We all know that it applies to the Soviet Union, Chile, Cuba, Nicaragua, Libya, Israel, Iraq, Vietnam, China and Taiwan and, for all I know, to very many other places. I think it is important that all those trips be registered. I believe that there are senators who frequently take trips which are paid for by other countries or by organisations. It is important that if someone takes a trip which is sponsored by the Democrat International or the Liberal International-I am not sure of the name, but it is the organisation of conservative parties-that fact be registered. If someone goes to World Peace Council meetings or on similar Soviet-sponsored trips, that fact also should be registered. The public should be aware of such trips and should be alerted to what is happening. I strongly support this, and I think that senators should be doing the same thing. The same should apply to journalists-

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are on touchy ground.

—No, I am not on touchy ground because one of the aspects that were referred to my Committee was what other people should be included in this legislation. Obviously there are journalists who take sponsored trips. They are continuously taking sponsored trips. These journalists give assurances that they will write things in certain ways. We have the evidence of the Hope Royal Commission on Security and Intelligence that Brian Toohey and Marian Wilkinson of the National Times were recommended by David Combe to the Soviet Ambassador for a trip to the Soviet Union because they wanted to bucket the United States. Those sorts of aspects should be revealed-
—What about David McNicoll?

—Yes, David McNicoll's trips to South Africa or to similar places-all these sorts of trips should be revealed, and such people's assets. How the legislation would affect such people also should be revealed. It is ridiculous to suggest that a member of this House has more power than some of the journalists and commentators who cover this chamber. It is quite obvious that many commentators and journalists have a much greater ability to affect what happens in government than any of us in this chamber, and in some cases that would even include Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: The new proposition that membership of any organisation should be stated is an important point and I strongly support it. There will be some difficulties, and that is another point in favour of asking for an extension of time for the reply. In some cases, especially in rural electorates covering many towns, there will be people who belong to large numbers of organisations, either as actual members or in some honorary capacity. They might belong to the local parents and citizens associations or be patrons of organisations and it might be quite difficult for them to collect the names of all those organisations.

At the same time I am pleased to say that all organisations are to be named. I have always thought it a ridiculous proposition that anything that may interfere with the duties of a member in the sense of not saying or doing exactly what he wants to do should be mentioned in the register of interests, yet many Ministers do not mention that they are members of the Australian Labor Party. Some do; but some do not. Surely their whole existence here, their behaviour and how they can act are significantly influenced by their membership of the Labor Party. Obviously it is a good thing that that membership should be mentioned. The same applies to opposition members. In our Party we agree to have decisions made by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party and those decisions, in addition to the decisions of national conferences, are binding on members of the Labor Party in their voting behaviour. Obviously, that should be mentioned. It has been mentioned by some Ministers but some do not mention it.

It strikes me as ridiculous that that fact is not disclosed. We all know the methods involved in preselection, regardless of whether it is for the Liberal Party or the Labor Party, and the significance of belonging to a particular faction. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who comes from South Australia, knows that. He knows that it is important to remember what faction he belongs to and whom he has to keep happy in order to get preselection next time. That also applies in the Labor Party. It would be silly to pretend otherwise.

I have no compunction about stating that I am a member of what is called the Centre Unity group in New South Wales. There are others who are members of Left groups, Right groups or whatever. That affects their preselection. Surely the threat to preselection is the greatest threat that many of us face. Therefore, that interest obviously should be registered. It will be interesting to see which groupings honourable members register membership of. That is all the more reason for believing-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset may I congratulate you on your surprise elevation. I am quite sure that you will do your best in the months ahead to take control of the new onerous position granted to you.
—I thank the honourable member very much. After listening to the honourable member for Prospect I am not quite sure whether I should declare an interest.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I know that being Chairman of Committees has its financial rewards but I do not see many others. The honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) as Chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee of Members' Interests actually let the biggest cat out of the bag when he informed the House that the Minister at the table, the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), the Minister for Paddington bears, had not even discussed this new approach in his own Party's caucus. With his political prowess he no doubt recognised that if he had taken this matter into his party room the Labor Party would have been very much divided on the subject. Therefore, rather than face that he has opted to bring the whole lot straight into the Parliament in an attempt to lock members of the Australian Labor Party-those on his side of the House-into a political vote. This is an attempt completely to stifle their right to have a view. He seeks to impose his view on them and on us.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that this very procedure is something which is born out of the prejudices and upbringing of this former shearer. Probably night after night while his counterpart, my predecessor as member for Moreton, Sir James Killen, also was in the shearing sheds reading and studying to better himself, the Minister was continuing to harbour and build on his prejudices towards people who have been a little bit more successful than he in life. I believe that this legislation is born out of that type of twisted attitude.

I have no argument with Ministers being required to provide a list of what they own to the Prime Minister. Indeed, I believe that was the procedure in the time of the former Government. This Parliament is filled with private individuals, and decisions made by private individuals-decisions in which members of this House have an absolute say-are few and far between, if any, because the procedures of this Parliament and the destiny of this country are decided by the government of the day. The government of the day plans out its policies and its legislation and then takes its proposals to its party room and says: `This is the way we want to go'. If the vast majority of the members of the party which is in government at the time agree with those plans, that is it, and those plans become the order of the day and are passed into legislation. It is the government and the government parties which decide which way they will go.

If some member has a pecuniary interest, surely his peers in the party room will judge him if his opposition to a proposal is based on a selfish interest. I challenge the Special Minister of State, who is the brains behind this intrusion, to put forward examples of members of this Parliament in the last 85 years being motivated in their votes by the self-interest which is referred to in this procedure and tied up in the motion moved today. The Minister would be really scratching.

What are we doing? By accepting this proposal we will be setting up a new bureaucracy in the country. More taxpayers' money will be required to keep a register of members' interests and to appoint a Registrar to list them. If I sell something, within 28 days I will be required to run down to the registrar's office and tell the person in charge what I have done so that changes can be made. I will have to do that if I sell 100 shares in Mount Isa Mines Ltd. Through the Minister, the Government is suggesting that my thinking and attitude may be warped and that I could be bought as a result of such a transaction. I have been a member of this place for 20 years. In that time I have seen a definite decline in the quality of people offering themselves for election to the Australian Parliament. One of the reasons is that people who have been successful in life cannot be bothered to offer themselves for this type of life because of the exposure to which they would be subjected and the scandals that would be whipped up about them, often without foundation. Their attitude is: `Why should I bother?' The procedure the Government is attempting to stampede through this Parliament today is but one more nail in the coffin that will turn people away.

Honourable members might ask what a member has to hide? If John Citizen's kids own something that was given to them by their grandparents, why should he, when he comes in here as a private member, have to hang that out on the public line? In a speech I made in this House almost a year ago, on 21 March 1985, I pointed out that the proposals at that time required that if my child's grandmother gave the child a pushbike for Christmas and the value was $110, I had to race down to the registrar's office and say: `You had better register this before 25 January, because Grandma gave little Johnny a pushbike worth $110 on Christmas Day'. Thankfully, that ridiculous provision has been scrapped, but the thinking which produced that requirement is typical of the thinking in this entire proposal. It is absolutely sick. It goes back to the warped upbringing of the Minister at the table. All he wants to do is find out what everybody owns.

It is to the great credit of this Parliament-I include Labor Party, National Party and Liberal Party members in this place and Australian Democrats in the other place-that I have not seen in 20 years the type of dishonesty that this proposal is trying to prevent. The Government should try to name one of its members that it believes this requirement will catch. It should name one member on this side of the House or one Democrat. The Hawke Government is way off beam because so often it sets about legislating to eliminate problems that do not exist. It must then set up units in the Public Service to police that legislation and that is why it is digging deeper and deeper into the taxpayers' pockets.

Now that the Minister has come clean and has said that he intends to impose penalties on those who do not notify their interests, it is very proper to place greater emphasis on what is happening in the Senate. The Senate is not interested in what the Government is proposing. The Senate will not agree with the proposal. In terms of inconsistency it is ridiculous that the Government wants all members in this place to hang out their washing on the public line, yet senators will simply ignore the proposal. I believe that the Minister's attitude is this: `Maybe one day we might have a majority in the Senate and then I can whip those senators into action and make them enforce this requirement in that other place, but let it be passed in this place first'. In terms of consistency it is indefensible for the Minister to try to push this proposal through the House without it being agreed to in the other place.

It is also indefensible that the Minister did not even have the courage to take the proposal to his own party room. I know as a result of my membership of the Committee that there are members of the Labor Party who have feelings of disquiet about what is being thrust upon this House. The Minister did not have the courage to face members of his Party. That in itself is a very poor reflection on the proposal, because if the Minister does not have the confidence to put it before his own Party, obviously he fears something.

In conclusion, I state that I am not without property in this world; I am not without shares. I put it to honourable members that if anybody who has been in parliament for as long as I have did not have anything he could be judged a fool. A person on a parliamentarian's salary for a long time who had nothing at any time would be a person incapable of looking after his own life.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of rot.

—It is true, after 20 years or even 10 years in this place. Another weakness of the legislation is that there is a Minister-he is not present at the moment; I will not name him-whose wife receives a salary in excess of $60,000 a year. Yet members who have wives in the work force will not be required to state anything about what their wives earn. But after two or three years a spouse could earn an amount which is greater than the value of all of the assets that the non-working spouse of a member may own. But that is not even worthy of noting according to the Government's approach. That is a further inconsistency.

SPEECH.PARA: I put forward the fact that I have pecuniary interests. I have property and I own things. Indeed, before I was 25 I had a lump of land in Brisbane and two beach homes. They were fairly humble, but that was what I owned before I was 25. In terms of acquiring property I have not been unsuccessful. But am I to be the subject of derision because the seat is not out of my pants? The type of thinking within the Labor Party is that someone who has something must be knocked down. Its policy in the last two or three years has been to tear down everybody who is even partly successful, create a common denominator and everything in the country will be marvellous, in the name of socialism and equality. I believe that the Government, particularly the Minister, have hangups. I repeat the challenge I issued a few minutes ago when I challenged the Minister to name one Labor Party, National Party, Liberal Party, Democrat or Independent member in the last 85 years who, by supplying the information that he is demanding people to make, would have changed the course of destiny of Australia by one iota. I say that the Government does not have a hope of proving its case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, first let me congratulate you on your elevation to the position of Chairman of Committees. I believe you will carry out your duties with the integrity and fervour for which you are so well known. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), said that he has some property. I have to admit that I have some property, too. The difference is that I am not unwilling to disclose it, if it is so required by the position that I took on by taking up public office. Of course, I did not dip so deeply into the public purse. I worked all the time before I entered this Parliament to gain what I own, and so did my wife. I arrived in this country on 4 March 1954. That was a Thursday and on the following Monday I started to work in a factory. I have not been out of work for one day. Of course, if one saves, one accumulates some property. But one should not be ashamed of it or shy of it. At the same time one should not say that it is sacrosanct, that it should not be declared in the public interest if one stands for public office. People who are prepared to put themselves forward and ask for public support have a duty to the public. I think we should bring some rationality to this debate and I will come to that in a minute.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee of Members' Interests of which I am a member was formed on 9 October 1984 by a resolution of the House. It was charged with making arrangements for the compilation of a register of members' interests at the commencement of each Parliament. The Committee was established in March 1985 and has met regularly ever since. As a member of the Committee I found that the meetings were used not to facilitate the establishment of a register of members' interests, but to try to find every possible reason why such a register should not be compiled. Previous speakers from both sides of the House have undertaken the same exercise as they did during those Committee meetings. Time and again the Committee meetings were taken up by members trying to outdo each other in their search for reasons and arguments against the establishment of such a register. Believe me, members of parliament have a very fertile mind when their interests, especially pecuniary interests, are in question. This is shown in the report that the Committee submitted. I must admit that I, too, raised an objection to the requirement that spouses of members, who in most cases are female, should also register their pecuniary interests. I argued that, after all, wives of members, especially those who are financially independent by being in business or employment, should not be required publicly to disclose their means, as they are neither seeking public office nor mere appendes of their husbands. However. I quickly abandoned my objection to allow the Committee to get on with its business.

The fertile imaginations of my colleagues were set in motion, depicting all sorts of consequences if their assets or business interests were publicly disclosed. Arguments were voiced that assets of members will be vulnerable to theft and members of their families targets of kidnapping and extortion. Every possible objection to the register was raised-from why members and not senators and why not the parliamentary Press Gallery, to the problems of enforcing the requirements of disclosure and possible sanctions for non-compliance of members.

I agree that the requirement of public disclosure of our assets is an intrusion on our privacy, but we have to balance such an intrusion against the public interest which requires such disclosure. After all, in most democracies overseas or in Australian States, parliaments have such requirements already in place. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), who preceded me in this debate, worked very hard to find every reason to create doubt in this House and to cast doubt on this report. They sought every reason why they should not disclose their pecuniary interests. While they were racking their brains to find those reasons, they forgot to mention that in most democracies that we compare ourselves with, in most legislatures of those countries, such a register already exists. That point was not brought out by the previous speakers and they know about that fact. They should not be hiding it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We put it in the report.

—Yes, but the honourable member did not mention it. He mentioned every other aspect of the report. Honourable members on the other side of the House mentioned every other aspect of the report. They put a lot of time in to show why they should not disclose their accumulated wealth but they never mentioned that in other States such as Victoria, South Australia and New South Wales or in the United States of America, England and other countries a register exists in some form for disclosure of pecuniary interests. I think it is time we looked at this matter quite rationally and not at our own small private interests only. In the United Kingdom, the United States, New South Wales and Victoria, just to mention a few legislatures, members are required to register their pecuniary interests. Why are we so tardy?

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to be partisan in this debate. The honourable member for Prospect was not partisan either. As a matter of fact, I did not know which side he was to speak on, but I have to mention that Opposition members were unable to accept the resolution of this House to establish a register of members' interests. They see themselves as-and they in fact are-representatives of the propertied class of this country. Since Federation, conservative members have introduced and supported legislation which served the interests of big land owners and big capital. They consider assets and profits sacred and private. They oppose any disclosure of their private means, while at the same time they expect public support for their election to parliament. They worship property and its accumulation to such an extent that they are unwilling to accept public scrutiny of their accumulated wealth.

As I said, I wish not to be partisan in this debate, so here are a few words of criticism of my side also. There was a certain reluctance on our side too to accept public disclosure of members' pecuniary interests. It is sad, but it is often true, that we who are elected to represent the interests of the ordinary wage and salary earner often forget on the way to public office the idealism that we started out with. The alienation of the individual from mass organisations and political parties and the resultant apathy is the subject of an essay by Cecil Wright Mills entitled `The Mass Society'. As I think his observations in this regard are pertinent, I would like to quote a passage from his essay. Cecil Wright Mills reminds us all:

The gap between the members and the leaders of the mass association is becoming increasingly wider. As soon as a man gets to be a leader of an association large enough to count, he readily becomes lost as an instrument of that association. He does so (1) in the interests of maintaining his leading position in, or rather over, his mass association, and he does so (2) because he comes to see himself not as a mere delegate, instructed or not, of the mass association he represents, but as a member of `an elite' composed of such men as himself. These facts, in turn, lead to (3) the big gap between the terms in which issues are debated and resolved among members of this elite, and the terms in which they are presented to the members of the various mass associations. For the decisions that are made must take into account those who are important-other elites . . .

As I said before, many of us who are sent here by honest, hard working Australians do tend to forget along the road why we started out on the journey. That explains why some members on my side of the House are also only too eager to see that the deliberation of the Committee comes to naught. We see members of the elite defending the interests of such an elite instead of representing the people who sent us here.

The objections raised by the Committee are not just matters of detail and implementation, but are basic objections against the public disclosure of members' interests. The questions raised by the Committee as to why members shall disclose their pecuniary interests and not the senators and why members' interests should be registered and not the members of the parliamentary press gallery are churlish and infantile.

TALK.START.PARA: —You signed the thing.

—I am more humble than to say that I was the only one really wanting this Committee to work. I was a very small minority. If the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) really wanted something done about it he should have had a committee of one. I would have fixed it. The argument members of the Committee raised was: `Why me and not someone else?' This is too childish an argument to be used by members of parliament. Other arguments by Committee members that we will be targets of kidnapping if our wealth is disclosed are even more ridiculous. After all, Sir Billy McMahon and Sir Henry Bolte are not coveted by the souvenir hunters; nor is there any desire by any kidnappers to target a member of parliament. They are not the most useful persons to be after.

SPEECH.PARA: I, for one, fully agree with the Government's view, as expressed by the Special Minister of State in his response to the report of the Committee of Members' Interests on 30 November 1985, that the registration of members' interests is an important principle to which this Government has been publicly committed and that such a register should be set up without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, first may I convey to you my congratulations on acceding to your office. I would be grateful if you would convey to Madam Speaker my congratulations on her historic and well earned elevation to the office of Speaker.
—I shall do that for the honourable member.

—I am disappointed that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has brought in this matter for discussion so quickly. I am not ascribing to him any ulterior motives, but we did get the details of some of the amendments only this morning and I would have liked some more time to have a look at them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has dealt with some of the questions of the Committee of Members' Interests, but a number of matters will, I believe, still concern the Committee. I was disappointed that the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) made such criticism of the Committee, because I believe that, although it was an all party committee, and although there were Opposition members on that Committee who do not uphold or want this principle, the discussion was constructive. I was disappointed that he should introduce into his speech matters such as conservatives representing the property classes and those sorts of things that were said in an era gone by. I believe those sorts of cliches and those sorts of rationales could be well forgotten.

I am concerned about some very discriminatory matters in this proposal. Firstly, the matter has been raised of the nonsense of one House of Parliament being required to make such declarations and the other House of Parliament, perhaps the more influential House, neither being in that category nor showing any inclination to be in that category. I believe that that is a discriminatory part of this proposal. Secondly, we have had some discussion this morning on the matter of spouses. The proposal states that if a member is reasonably aware of his spouse's situation, that has to be declared. That is totally impracticable. What on earth must a member do to become reasonably aware? In this day and age of the Government bringing in such things as the Bill of Rights and talking about privacy and the position of women and the position of spouses, here we have a situation that is neither practical nor sensible. The discriminatory matter-I hope that the Minister will take this point-is that some spouses will be required to have their interests declared in this House and some spouses will not. That seems totally unfair.

There were members of the Committee who said: `My wife has a business in which she works, it is her business and she will not reveal to me the nature of her business or assets or anything else, nor can I require her to do that'. I suppose that member would not declare it because he is not reasonably aware. Those members who have a closer family situation and a relationship with their spouses where confidences are exchanged will have to declare the interests of their spouses. Which spouse is it whose income is more likely to have some influence in the life and role of a member-the spouse in a family situation who has little but whose privacy is invaded, or the one who has some influence and affluence and assets in this world? The spouse with the influence can escape this net; the other spouse has to have the interest declared. I hope the Minister will consider that. When the Committee brought up this matter it was not looking at the situation where a member was going to connive to get rid of assets and pass them on to his or her spouse and escape some sort of detection; that was not the motive of the Committee at all. The motive of the Committee was the impracticability of the whole situation and the fact that some spouses will have to have their interests declared or the member will be subject to a penalty; other spouses will not. That seems to me to be totally unfair.

The Chairman of the Committee adverted to the Minister's statement-I commend the Chairman on handling very well a very difficult situation and a very big problem-that the Committee has asked for penalties. It has asked for no such thing. If one canvassed the Committee members, one would find that the view of the Committee was absolutely in the other direction. The matter of penalties highlights the discrimination matter I have raised. Members will be penalised in family situations if we do not declare the interests of our spouses of which we are reasonably aware. If we have joint accounts and work together with our spouses, we will be penalised with some fearsome things. We will be held in utter contempt of the House if we do not declare the interests; yet other members, whose spouses do not tell them anything, so that they are not reasonably aware, will escape that situation. The penalty exacerbates the problem of discrimination in this proposal. The honourable member for Hotham mentioned that other parliaments in the world require their members to declare their interests. The Parliament of Westminster is one. I believe that a member who has been in that Parliament for a long time has never declared his interests. That is known, and I suppose the Opposition makes some play of the fact that he has not done that. It is true that there is some sort of register there, but there are none of the fearsome penalties that the Minister is talking about in this proposal.

The public register is another matter that concerns me. The Minister said-I take his point-that he has removed the need to declare the monetary value of assets. Honourable members know the imagination of people out there about the so-called affluence of members of parliament. We have only to mention a joint account or some asset and it can be magnified out of all proportion. I listened with interest to the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) and the honourable member for Hotham. I do not believe that I am a failure, but I have very little of this world's goods. The reason for that is that when I came into this place I had to sell my practice. One cannot conduct an accountancy and consultancy practice and be a member of parliament. I have raised a family of five children and I have tried to help that family, so I do not think there is any shame that I do not have a great deal of this world's goods. I have enough and I am satisfied, and in any case I do not think that is the total aim in life. Nevertheless, people imagine that members of parliament are affluent, grabbing people who have all sorts of assets.

This public register could be distorted and mishandled, and I believe that the sorts of threats and problems that were mentioned to the Committee are very real. Who will want to look at this register and what will be their motives? They will not be the simple motives that the Government would have us believe-that the electorate can look at it and say: `This is an honest man; nobody has bought him, and he will be able to conduct his affairs fairly and with equanimity'. I am concerned that this public register will be used by other people for all sorts of other motives. It is not sufficient to say that somehow we will limit access to that register. If one journalist gets hold of it, the whole world will know.

I turn briefly to the matter of journalists before I come back to other things. Mention has been made of whether journalists ought to have such a public register. I do not believe that members of the House ought to; I have not resiled from that, I accept the amendment entirely. Having said that, however, while members will be forced under penalty to declare their interests in this House, the Press Gallery, which has far more influence on the affairs of this nation than do I as a simple back bencher, will have some sort of immunity. Where is the equity in that? I do not want to denigrate my friends in the Press Gallery; they see their role differently from the way I see it. However, when we look at the current affairs of this nation, they see themselves in the role of Sherlock Holmes. For instance, in the Chamberlain affair, a woman was let out of gaol and the Press have been hounding her, following her in cars and trying to take photographs of her on the aeroplane. Why? Not because they can wring any more interest out of the matter-after all, there will be an inquiry at the end of the line-but because they hope to get a throw-away line, something they can use as a scoop. They see themselves as Sherlock Holmes. I exempt some journalists from that comment, of course; I am talking generally. If journalists look at the register of members' interests, will the situation be any different? I think the Minister should look at the matter of journalists. I notice that the Minister will invite journalists to declare their interests, but he will force members to fill in a register. It would be different if the Minister brought legislation into this House which invited members to fill in a register, so that we could accept or reject that invitation. However, the Government is to invite journalists but compel us to fill in a register.

I believe that some things have been sorted out. The question of estates was a serious one. The Government has looked at this matter and has understood what the Committee was saying to it. However, once again it will be very difficult to decide what a beneficial interest is. I am affected by this situation. I am the executor of my father's very small estate. I get no benefit at all from the position. I suppose that I would be entitled, if I were an unworthy son, to charge the estate some fee for managing it and looking after it. The estate, which consists of just a few shares, is maintained for the purpose of looking after the interests of my mother. Would that be a beneficial interest? Of course, I make no such charge and I do not think any son would. I would not have the Minister regard that as a beneficial interest. Perhaps I will have some interest when that small estate is distributed. I hope that happens some time in the future because I love my mother. However, these things are very difficult to define.

The Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Prospect, was not being obstructive when he raised these matters. He was pointing out the great difficulty in respect of definition. Despite the clarification that has been made by the Government, I can still see that some very difficult decisions will have to be made in trying to design the form. I am pleased to see that the Minister has taken out of the proposal the silly business of a member who is a member of a company having to declare all of the assets and all of the liabilities of the company. That requirement was never on. It was never practical because such elements change from day to day.

I am worried, too, that we are now getting to a situation in which members will be required to give details similar to those involved in the assets test. After all, what are we to declare? When the assets test was brought in, pensioners had to unearth details of all of their insurance policies, collections and all sorts of things. I find it difficult to know what is going to be required of members and where this requirement will finish. The same problems that resulted from applying the assets test, from which I thought the Government would have learned, are going to apply in this case. When we finally get down to the member's opinion of whether there is a conflict of interest, who is going to make the judgment whether the member honestly was of the opinion that his situation would not influence him and who is going to decide whether he should be penalised for it? I think that the amendment that has been moved is the best possible way in which to approach this matter and I support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, first of all, I congratulate you on your election to the position you now hold. I wish you well for many years to come. Today's debate on the motion of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has been of great interest to this point. I think Opposition speakers have clearly indicated the reasons why some of them oppose what the Government has put forward. The Chairman of the Committee of Members' Interests, the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), has put forward some concerns. I am sure that the Minister in his wisdom has taken into consideration many of the matters that have been put before him.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of concerns in relation to the House of Representatives and the Senate. I firmly believe in what the Government is putting forward. I also firmly believe that the Senate also should be involved. I think it would be rather futile if the Senate did not follow what the House of Representatives does in this area. I believe that that will happen in the long term. The public register area is another area about which I have some concerns. I am concerned about the extent to which information on the public register should be made available to the community. I am also concerned about what methods should be used to make the information available to the community and the reasons for doing so. The Committee itself expressed some concerns about that area. I believe that this is something that needs careful consideration. Members of the Opposition have argued today about why they believe the assets of spouses and dependants of members should not be included on a public register. I think that the arguments have been very spurious. There are occasions on which the information should be made available. As I develop my arguments today, I would like to show that there has been a sad lack of understanding by members of the Opposition about the effects of such a register.

The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) argued at some depth that good people will not become involved in public life-that is the terminology he used-if they are required to supply information. He believed that the register would be a disincentive to people entering public life. I cannot see how that could possibly be the case. I cannot see that a person who has the attributes and the willingness to serve his country in a parliament would go against his natural instincts to put himself forward for pre-selection because of the existence of a public register. I think any person with such a view would probably not want to come here in the first place. I believe that such a person would not be put off by such a public register. I was rather surprised to hear the honourable member say that Opposition members have no influence in decision making and consequently there was no reason for them to be on the register. That is a real indication by the honourable member for North Sydney of the absolute belief by members of the Opposition of their total incompetence and lack of influence. We were in opposition in my first three years in this Parliament and I always believed that we had a great influence. We were elected to represent our electorates. I believed that we had something to say and something to contribute. I was rather surprised to hear the honourable member for North Sydney say that Opposition members have no influence on decision making.

I move on to the points raised by the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron), some of which I thought were rather startling. The honourable member challenged us to put forward examples of how and where members had used their position to their beneficial interest. He also took the view that successful people will not nominate and seek pre-selection. He used arguments similar to those put forward by the honourable member for North Sydney and claimed that good people out in the business community would not be attracted to parliament. He has the strange belief that the only good people in the world are those who can show assets, bank accounts or shares on a register. He argued that those sorts of good people would not nominate. I was rather surprised that he took a similar line to that taken by the honourable member for North Sydney.

The honourable member asked us to name one person which the proposal would catch. He asked us to name one Liberal, one National, one Democrat or one Labor member. I would like to spend a little time on this. The honourable member dwelt on what would happen if everybody on the Opposition side decided not to register. This matter was also raised by the honourable member for Prospect. The position in regard to the penalty is quite clear. At page 14 of its report, the Committee said:
. . . it should be made clear that the Committee neither advocates nor recommends the introduction of specific penalties for failure to comply with the registration requirements.
The motion put forward by the Minister today states:
(5) any Member of the House of Representatives who
(a) knowingly fails to provide a statement of registrable interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests by the due date;
(b) knowingly fails to notify any alteration of those interests to the Registrar of Members' Interests within 28 days of the change occurring or
(c) knowingly provides false or misleading information to the Registrar of Members' Interests
shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the House of Representatives and shall be dealt with by the House accordingly.

That is the sort of penalty that one could talk about in respect of an individual person. However, another penalty can be enacted, and that is by the public themselves when they make a judgment on some of the decisions that are taken by their elected representatives as a group. I think that public judgment will be much more damning and much more important than any other judgment. Most of the governments over the past 30 years have been conservative governments. The honourable member for Moreton wants us to name one Liberal or one National. We could name them all if we look at some of the legislation that has been voted on and passed in this House. I refer to occasions on which the interests of members and perhaps members of Cabinet were clearly expressed in the party rooms, not on behalf of the constituency which they represented but on behalf of the vested interests that were influencing the then government. We can see proof of that in society today. I refer to the changes that have been mooted by our Government over the last three years. Many people in the community, who for many years supported the conservative parties, have suddenly realised or have had brought to their attention that much of the voting that took place and many of the decisions that were taken were made on a vested interest approach rather than for their benefit. Had they known some of those interests that a member of parliament held they may have looked much more critically at that member to see why he was arguing a particular line in the party room or in the Parliament. One only has to look at a few instances to see that. We heard over and over again in the debate on the assets test that the vested interests of a small percentage of pensioners were against the wishes of the great majority of pensioners, because money was being paid to very wealthy people who held assets. Therefore the amount of money that could have been made available to pensioners in need was restricted. We have heard that argument debated over and over again. That is where we will see the public judgment penalty come into this. When members of the public become aware of how members of parliament are voting and debating and then look at their own positions, it will be clear whether it is personal interests that the members are protecting or whether they are protecting the interests of their electorate. That public judgment will come up very clearly.

The honourable member for Moreton stated strongly that a person who has been a member of parliament for years and who does not have property and shares would be considered to be a fool. I was interested to hear the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) at least say that he has not spent his time in this place developing property and shares and that he does not consider himself to be a fool. But I consider the honourable member for Moreton to be quite a fool if he thinks that every person in this Parliament who takes that attitude and is not willing to express on a register what he has, and have that expression on a register put up against the way he puts his speeches and arguments in this Parliament, will be afraid of what his constituents may start to read into that. This man is perhaps the real fool. He is the man who is putting forward in the Parliament propositions on which he and his Party vote in the vested interests rather than for the general public good. That is where we will see the main penalty area. It will clearly come in the public judgment area.

Look at the record of honourable members opposite in regard to tax shelters over the seven years of the Fraser Government and how they consistently voted. There was no public judgment which could be assessed as to why those members of parliament were making those sorts of decisions. Was it a perception of what they felt personally, or were they representing their electorates? It became quite clear eventually when the public woke up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I believe this is a gross reflection on members on this side of the House. I ask the honourable member to withdraw the comments that he has been making.
—The honourable member for McMillan will withdraw his remarks.
—If I have reflected on the members of the House--
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw his remarks unreservedly.

—I withdraw those remarks unreservedly. The Government of the time, which was making those decisions, was eventually judged by the people as not making decisions in the interests of the majority of the people. Whether honourable members opposite did it individually, I am not saying; but, collectively, I am saying, they did. Therefore the penalty in regard to this area of registers will allow the public to make a public judgment of a group in parliament-not of an individual-on how they represent their electorates. It is no reflection on a member of parliament, but when decisions keep coming out consistently, members of the public will ask why it is that they have governments representing such small minorities. The honourable member for Fairfax took it up with the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) and said that he was using cliches. Let the public judge whether he was using cliches; members of the public will very quickly be able to work it out when they can see in a public register whose interests are being served by the decisions that are being taken. Many in the community today, particularly in my electorate and in rural Australia, are realising that some of those decisions taken by previous governments-as a collective group, not as individuals-were taken to improve their positions. If one wants evidence, one has only to look at statements by the Liberal Party member in Western Australia who lost his seat last weekend. He quite publicly said that, had the National Party of Australia, which at the time was in charge of the rural portfolios, done its job correctly, a lot of the rural sector would have been much better off today. That is the clear statement I am making. The public will clearly make the judgment. At the moment members of the public cannot make that judgment simply because the information is not available to them. People who are making decisions in the Parliament, influencing the position of government, should be quite willing to make public their interests on a register. I fully support that idea.
—Could a farmer be Minister for Primary Industry?

—I am not going to argue with the honourable member across the chamber; I will talk through the Chair. Members of parliament should declare their interests so that the public can make a judgment. That is what this proposal is all about today. The penalties recommended today are strictly that this House should deal with those who refuse to do the things mentioned in the motion. I read those out before. The House expects them to provide a statement and do those three things. If not, they shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the House of Representatives as individuals. Collectively, it will be the public which will judge from the information it is able to obtain from the register. People are not going to be kept out of this Parliament simply because other people may be saying: `If you are nominated, preselected and go into Parliament, we are going to look at the decisions your Government is making and whether they are to your benefit and not to our benefit'. That is the sort of judgment that people will be able to make. If it is quite clear that the decisions are clearly not in the public interest, the perception will be made much quicker. Most of the people are not fools. Maybe political parties, too, will become interested in the people who are being nominated and preselected, and we may see a little more life getting into some of the branches of the Liberal Party and the National Party. They may have a better selection of candidates. They are some of the ways in which this register will benefit. If there is a benefit it may be for the Opposition benches. I fully support the motion put forward by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have entered this debate on a number of occasions. I repeat that it is, of course, very much evidence of the Australian Labor Party's and the Labor Government's 12-millionaire syndrome. They keep telling us how, with their iniquitous assets test, they caught 12 millionaires. They never bother to say that they also disadvantaged about 57,000 other pensioners. This proposal is a similar approach. As I have said on previous occasions, I am not all that upset about this proposal. My life has always been an open book, if controversial at times. I have never very much worried about people looking into my life. I have often said that when one picks up a stone with `Tuckey' on it, it is usually round on the edges as so many people have been looking underneath it.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also told this House that my wife has told me clearly that she will not tell me what some of her private little bank accounts are. I wonder whom the House is going to punish if that situation continues. Is the House going to drag me before it on a contempt charge because my wife refused to tell me what her personal bank accounts contain or is the House going to drag her before it on a contempt charge?
