In fact, could some other member of my family who may have the privilege that I do not have of knowing what she has in her private bank account be called before the House? Nevertheless, no doubt as time goes by, that sort of thing will be resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait till she finds out what you have in yours.

—That is all right. She signs all the cheques and has been the bookkeeper in our family for as long as we have been in business together, and that is nearly 30 years. I keep raising the question as to whether, other than satisfying this 12-millionaire syndrome, we are going to get anywhere with these different things. We have a register of shareholding in public and private companies. As I saw the ministerial statement of 22 September 1983, the information was very brief. As the House now remembers and the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) remembers to his chagrin, I was able to investigate that matter and to raise serious questions as to the operation of the company concerned and its dealings with the Commissioner of Taxation. Nevertheless, that was not really a matter of pecuniary interests. I did not see the Minister trying to change the tax Act even though he had avoided a large amount of probate and other matters.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to declare family businesses, trusts and nominee companies. I do not expect that any of those would put us in the Commonwealth Parliament in a position that would change our vote. We have to declare real estate. I am sure that as time goes by I will be able to demonstrate to the Government and its members that some of that might not be to their advantage. Family trusts have to be declared. There is an argument around today-it is a pity, because I think there has been use of this nature-that family trusts have been used for tax minimisation purposes when, in fact, their role and the role which I intend to pursue in the future is to protect family assets for the beneficiaries.

Many things are changing in the world today, including the Family Law Act. Trusts will become more and more a way by which families will protect their assets. My will will eventually leave anything that I have left when I die to a family trust. I do not see that as being dishonest or a method of tax evasion. That is the point. I have often declared in this Parliament, whenever we have debated excise or matters of that nature, that I have been involved in the hotel industry for nearly all of my business life. When I make comments in here opposing excise, as I invariably do, do I make them for myself, the hotel industry or the community that is the eventual payer of that sort of tax? Where is my responsibility? More importantly, I am concerned as to what serious contempt might be. To quote the Minister for Trade, justice in this place `resides in the numbers'. Paragraph (h) states:
saving or investment accounts, indicating their nature and the name of the bank or other institutions . . .

I have been through the ministerial statement, which basically reflects what members will be required to do and what Ministers did on 22 April 1983. I went to a particular Minister. Honourable members can rest assured that I do not intend to use the Minister's name in what I am about to say. In fact, I do not intend to disclose it to other people. I noticed that that Minister declared a couple of savings accounts in the name of himself and, I presume, his wife. Subsequent to the declaration of this report I received a letter which I want to read. It says:
I am writing to you because you seem willing to expose the dishonesty of Labor Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before the honourable member continues I draw his attention to the standing order which provides that a member cannot make imputations against members. I do not know whether the honourable member was intending to do so.

—Had you not been talking to someone you would have heard me say, Mr Deputy Speaker, that under no circumstances did I intend to use a member's name. I have deleted it from the letter and as such I will read what the letter says.

—I further advise the honourable member that the practice of the House has been that, if a member on one side or the other feels that an anonymous allegation could be against him or a party, that should also be considered to be out of order.
—If the Minister wishes to come in here and complain about my reading of this letter he is welcome to do so. In the meantime I wish to read the letter.
—Order! Often it is up to the Chair to decide what is proper for the House to deal with. I am just cautioning the honourable member.
—I am most anxious that the particular Minister not be mentioned. I make that very clear. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: You might like to make some inquiries and investigations into Commonwealth Savings Bank Society Cheque A/c No. 911-300.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member wants to adopt a back-door method of identifying someone that is also out of order.
—I believe that number is confidential.
—It would not be confidential for people who work in the bank.
—That comes under the name of a Federal electorate committee.
—I think that the honourable member for O'Connor might be better to pursue something other than what he is pursuing.
—The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Money is paid into the a/c at election time and then it seems only cheques larger than $20 and they are made to-
another account-
He seems to syphon off some of his campaign donations . . . The largest seems to have been cheque No. 302178 for $2,868 last year . . .
That was paid to the member, and another was paid to the other signatory. The letter continues:
None of his workers seem to know about this fund-
that is, campaign workers-

though cheques paid in are for his campaign. There does not seem to be any balance sheets or statements given at any meetings. No cheques to the ALP either. He seems to have taken at least $5,000 over the years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Germane to your comments in caution of the honourable member for O'Connor, I think that what we now have is a back-door expose of some cheque account numbers and cheque numbers. This reflects very badly on the Ministry because the honourable member suggested that these accounts belong to a particular Minister whom he will not name. I think that he has drawn some form of stigma across the whole of the Ministry. I for one take exception. They are certainly not my accounts so I know he is not reflecting on me, but I speak on behalf of 26 other Ministers who are not here. We are all under suspicion.
—I will stop reading the letter, all right?
—That would be a fairly typical method that is normally employed by the honourable member for O'Connor. I suggest that the information that has been supplied should be stricken from the record.

—Order! I am not quite sure whether that can be done. I think that the honourable member for O'Connor would be far better pursuing another line of debate before he gets himself into a bit of deep water.
—I think that the sensitivity of the Minister and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, exactly explains the point. To be quite honest--
—Order! The honourable member will withdraw the reflection upon the Chair.

—Yes, I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. I did not mean it to be a reflection on the Chair when I said it. I wholeheartedly withdraw. The point I am making is that this is how simple this whole thing develops. It is in the Government's hands. The Government wants this thing. It has called upon its Ministers to make a declaration and as a result there appears to be an omission. It might be an omission in respect of the electoral Act as well. All I am drawing to your attention-

—I take a point of order. In view of the reflections that are now being made, I would think that the more proper course of action-if the honourable member for O'Connor could in any way at any time find a proper way to do things-would be to make an official complaint about some alleged misstatement in any Minister's statement of assets.

—There is no point of order. I caution the honourable member for O'Connor again that it is disorderly to make reflections upon individuals or groups of individuals. —I am determined that the matter regarding this person go no further. The point I am making is that this is the type of situation that will arise day after day once this proposal opens the way for this situation. I put that to the House. How often can a member get up in this place, read from a letter such as that, cast this sort of aspersion on people, true or false, and, to quote the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham), who spoke previously, be judged by the public? Surely that is step one. What is the imputation? I gave the example of a previous occasion and all that came out of a ministerial statement. A previous speaker has referred to the deficiencies of that particular statement and the imputations that could be based upon it. However, it is up to the Government. As I said, I am prepared to cop it. I do not know what I will do about my wife's position; I will have to live with that. The Government will have to decide on that. But, if Ministers think that this is the end of it and that that is the end of what is in this little blue file, it is on their heads. Let it be on the Government's head, because once this is under way I can promise faithfully that I will be able to go through that declaration and point out deficiency after deficiency after deficiency. There is no doubt that the Minister concerned in the incident mentioned had to declare all his savings accounts, and I put it to the House that the one I have just mentioned was not declared. In fact, there are allegations that it was improperly used. Those allegations were sent to me under a signature.
—Why don't you have the guts to say who it is outside this place?
— No, because I do not want to hurt that person.
—No, you are a rotten little sneak.

—All right; if I am a rotten little sneak, I will be a rotten little sneak. If the Minister thinks that there are no rotten little sneaks around this place, he will soon find out when he gets an example of how this register is going to work. If his back bench wants to vote for it when this debate is over, let it be on the Government's head. The Government has to come first, honourable members opposite are the Government and therefore it is they who must be tested, page by page by page, on their declarations. No one will argue the point that Opposition members, through their pecuniary interests or other interests, can affect the decisions of this House, yet those who can in another place will not have to make declarations. That is what makes a joke of the Government trying to massage its 12-millionaire syndrome. Government members will be the sufferers. As I said, I am prepared to head the list; I hope that my declaration is in ahead of others. Government Ministers can go through that and some of them can make some suggestions about it. I will welcome that. I promise them that I will not leave anything out.
—I don't think I will find it compulsory reading.
—It will not be at all. As I said, the stones are all round on the edges. I am not too worried about it at all. I can live with it, but there might be some honourable members opposite who cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity, Mr Deputy Speaker, to congratulate you on your attainment of high office. This is the first opportunity I have had to do that, and I hope to have the call on many occasions in the future. I wish to indicate at the outset of my contribution to this debate my strong support for the proposed register of members' interests. It does not surprise me that Opposition members who are taking part in this debate are opposed to a register of members' interests as such a register will disclose to the public their strong ties with wealthy and powerful conservative groups in our society.
—Oh, dear!

—The honourable member may well laugh. For too long members and senators of the National and Liberal parties have been able to hide behind a cloak of concern for the poor and the disadvantaged in our society, whilst at the same time reaping the benefits of the unequal distribution of property ownership in Australia. It must not be forgotten that the wealthiest one per cent of the population owns 22 per cent of the total wealth in Australia and half the population owns less than 8 per cent of the wealth. The richest 2,000 people own just as much as 2 1/2 million people who live on or below the poverty line. It is members on the other side of this House who represent the wealthy and the powerful. It is quite clear, therefore, that we will hear from honourable members opposite expressions of outrage at the possible disclosure of what they will term and what they have termed their private interests.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I do appreciate that there are some problems with the proposed register to which the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has referred in his speech. Although the Minister has indicated that he considers that the definition of what constitutes a conflict of interest will not cause insurmountable problems, I believe that the lack of a definition with indicative guidelines has the potential to cause many lively debates in this House and will make the task of the registrar of members' interests more difficult. The conflict of interest with a member's public duties could arise because of the pecuniary interest or the possible conferring of an advantage because a member belongs to an organised interest group. For example, is there a conflict of interest for me, if the Federal Government is debating whether to provide finance to buy back land in the Dandenong Ranges, because I am a member of the Save the Dandenongs League? My membership of the League came about not only because I lived in the Dandenong Ranges but also because a large number of my constituents lived in the small townships in the ranges.

The Minister has supported the view of the Committee of Members' Interests that membership of any organisation, be it political, sporting, recreational, or community based, must be included in the register. I do not have any difficulty with that proposition, but I must reiterate my view that the question of conflict of interest which may arise as a result of such membership will be virtually insurmountable if the registrar is not given some guidelines to assist him or her in deciding when a conflict of interest has arisen.

I appreciate that some honourable members have argued in this debate that divulging their interests in property or their membership of organisations is an unacceptable invasion of privacy. I reject that argument on the ground that we all accept candidature for public office willingly and we must accept that holding a public office does not allow us to be private citizens. Unfortunately, the Australian public does not hold its parliamentarians in high esteem. The scathing and sometimes insulting comments made by many Australians about their State and Federal parliamentarians are certainly heard in amazement by people overseas. Whilst I have some reservations about the philosophical integrity of some politicians-certainly in general-I take great exception to the ill-informed comments of some media reporters and commentators who should know better and to the insults of letter writers in our magazines and newspapers-

TALK.START.PARA: —Name them.
—I do not have to name them; they know who they are.
—I hope that the honourable member will not name them, because he will then require me to show some considerable impartiality.

—I would not dream of naming them, Mr Deputy Speaker. Fortunately, there are not many of them. The register of members' interests will help to inform the public quite properly of our allegiances and vested interests, if any; but it will not reveal the long hours of exhausting work and the days and sometimes weeks away from family and friends which are so often ignored by our critics.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the intention of the Government, as announced by the Minister, to include in the register of members' interests the financial interests of spouses and dependent children. Initially there was a suggestion that non-dependent sons' and daughters' interests also should be included. I am glad that that suggestion has been dismissed as quite unacceptable. When I mentioned the possibility to my two sons and mydaughter, all three made it quite clear that as adults they considered themselves independent people and that they had no intention of providing any information about their financial interests to me or anybody else in relation to my parliamentary position.

In like manner, I can see some difficulty in the case of spouses, but not in the case of dependent children. Again, I believe that it will be necessary for the Government to provide guidelines because it will be quite reasonable for a spouse to declare that he or she is an independent person and to ask why he or she should provide the Government with details of pecuniary interests for inclusion in a public register. In its report, the Committee referred to the considerable difficulty in applying a reasonable interpretation of the proposition that a member should register pecuniary interests of a spouse of which he or she was aware. To what lengths should a member be required to go to become aware of the interests of a spouse? I trust that the Government and the Committee will look again at this matter because, unless clear guidelines are provided, members could be placed in a compromising and embarrassing situation.

In its report the Committee has referred to the possible penalties which could be introduced for non-compliance with the registration scheme. The Minister has stated that the Committee recommended the introduction of specific penalties; but, with respect, I point out that in its report the Committee neither advocated nor recommended specific penalties. However, I agree with the Government's view that without penalties the scheme would lack credibility. The only plea I make is that a distinction should be made between a wilful contravention and an inadvertent contravention. In my view, an inadvertent contravention should not be subject to a penalty, particularly in the first year of the operation of the scheme. A member should be given some benefit of doubt in a borderline case. I would have thought that the publicity which would arise as a result of even an inadvertent or thoughtless contravention would be sufficient penalty, bearing in mind that the member has to face party members at a pre-selection ballot or the general public at the next election. I hope that the Minister and the Committee will take my comments into account and will form specific guidelines on the matters I have raised so that we can be quite sure that that information will be of great help to the future registrar of members' interests. However, apart from those reservations, I fully support the Government's proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The futility of this measure has been well demonstrated by speakers on this side of the House. That could not be pinpointed more than by reference to the fact that members of this House will be responsible in this way, as demanded by the Government's measures, yet members of the Senate will be able to do as they wish under a cloak of secrecy without any revelation of their personal involvement, which is required by this declaration of members' interests. As has been demonstrated here, this is an utterly futile way to approach such a disciplinary and unfair measure.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of great interest and of great conflict that the Government should be so intent on selling its identification card, the Australia Card, by stressing that there will be regard for privacy-this morning we have seen a furtherance of the Caucus debate-and I understand that another special body, at further great expense to the taxpayer, is to be set up to safeguard privacy. Yet here we are in the process of destroying privacy-not without consequence. The request that details of spouses' financial statements be revealed has some deeper implications. I believe that few members who have spent long years in politics would not have been subjected, either themselves or their families, to personal threats. It seems to me that nothing could make it easier for political crazies or people who carry hatreds to further their evil stunts than to publish names in regard to anything that has a measure of financial or political impact that is transferred to family members. I believe that, regardless of the stricture we are discussing here, when a spouse requests the continued maintenance of her affairs in secrecy on the basis of personal safety the member should escape censure. There is no other way. There must be sympathy in the community for those people who are endangered in some way through no action of their own. In this case it would be the action of a spouse.

Of course, the whole thing is a facade in any case. We are to have this register. Then I suppose we will be able to go to the community and say: `Look, there cannot be any malpractice among politicians or Ministers because we have all signed the register. We have declared our interests. We have to be free of any thought of corruption or malpractice'. That is an absurdity. What a member did if he helped a constituent, what a Minister or highly placed public servant did for a friend or an acquaintance, need not be revealed or alluded to at all by this fiction of an all-revealing register, which, as I have said, is nothing more than a facade.

I know that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who has brought this matter into the House, has a varied background. He seems to have made an anniversary occasion of getting involved in matters of great moment. I have been given information recently that the Minister has done a favour for a friend. I had intended to put this question on the Notice Paper, but as this debate has arisen and seems to surround this question of probity, I would like to ask a question directly of the Minister, as to whether he has done certain things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Boothby knows that Question Time is at 2 o'clock. It is not Question Time now. If he wants to reflect on the Minister he must do so by substantive motion or otherwise continue his remarks.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am not reflecting on the Minister at this time. I am simply putting to him a position. His response would indicate whether he is reflected on. I am requiring information from the Minister, and I believe it is sensible that I should put it to him here. It seems to me to be taking the matter to an absurdity that I cannot have a debate about issues here with the Minister. I thought this was a place of free discussion. The Minister knows well that in his history here in the Ministry he has been subjected to the most strident criticisms. We have had that out in the House, and at times I have been part of that debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I have been told that the Minister has been instrumental in upgrading a friend from an economy class trip to Europe to first class on Qantas Airways Ltd. I would like to know whether he has been involved in that. My information is supposed to be of fairly good quality. Has he upgraded a prominent president of a prominent union in a trip to Great Britain recently? Was another Minister involved? Did he make such a request? Was the union president's wife involved? What was the monetary value of the upgrading? If the Minister can wipe it off, if he can say: `Well, I am a bit of a-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I just remind the honourable member for Boothby that he is supposed to direct his remarks to the Chair, not to the Minister. The Minister is not in a position to reply to questions here. He may decide to reply in winding up the debate. However, if the honourable member for Boothby has a question he might keep it until Question Time, which is the appropriate time in the House for that.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I have put to the Minister a matter which he can reply to if he desires. If he does not reply I might put it on the Notice Paper. I thought it would cut things short, and it fits the description of what we are talking about. If my information is totally wrong the Minister will attack me on that, I am sure, and I will sit down and be somewhat chastened. But if I am right, of course, he will answer, because we are dealing now with matters of revealing these sorts of things. We are being constructively open, and nothing of such a nature is to be hidden. I am sure that the Minister will do one of two things: He will openly answer my query or he will castigate me for having the wrong information. He will get satisfaction, I will get satisfaction, or no one will get satisfaction.
—Could I also respond in respect of Liberal Party people who have approached me for favours as well?
—Order! I am sure the Minister will respond to whatever he likes when the time is right.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I thought we were being quite open about this. I am here to hear what the Minister has to say about the question. In regard to the upgrading of air travel, everyone knows that many members in this House have been upgraded in relation to travel on Qantas when the seats have been available. I guess it has been some sort of unofficial policy that this has been done in a sort of national sense to get members of parliament carried in some standard around Australia, to have them arrive in good health and good temper, so that they can discharge their duties on behalf of the country when they arrive. One could make an argument for that, but what I brought up was quite removed from that matter. I brought up the subject of the Minister taking a role in intervening to upgrade a friend who is the president of a prominent South Australian union. As I said, he will answer that question. SPEECH.PARA: This is an exercise in futility. Ultimately, the only means of censure that are worth anything in this regard are the preselection procedures and the procedures of a general election by the Australian electors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me deal with the contribution of the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). Many requests come to us as members of parliament, as they do to him. Indeed, he rang me a couple of weeks ago to see whether I could help him with an issue. Unfortunately, I was unable to do so because it would have been beyond the criteria set down by government guidelines, although, let me say, I disagreed with the government guidelines and said so when I spoke with the public servants concerned. That issue has now been brought to finality by our changing the system.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to whether a person asked me whether I could assist with that person's travel arrangements, yes, that is true. A question was asked whether I introduced that person to someone at Qantas Airways Ltd. Yes, I did. With regard to the final arrangements which were made, I understand that the person was upgraded. I do not think any member of the Parliament has the power to upgrade people unless he or she is sitting on the Board of Qantas or happens to be the General Manager of Qantas. I do not find this situation that peculiar. I think it has happened quite a lot. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr N.A. Brown) said some months ago in the Press, this is the sort of thing that he has had made available to him over the years. He did not find it so extraordinary. To answer the question of the honourable member for Boothby, if he thinks that this issue throws some colour into this debate, I can tell him that hardly a week goes by that a member of his Party does not come to me to see whether I can be of assistance on some issue. I try to assist wherever it is possible, because I think, as Leader of the House and as the person in charge of facilities and conditions for honourable members, that is one area in which we should be a little bipartisan. I do that. I express that attitude to the honourable member, because I think he raised this matter in order to try to downgrade and denigrate the issue which is before us. The issue before us has been before this Parliament for many years; namely, should this Parliament, like so many other parliaments throughout the world, require members of parliament to declare their interests and put them on a register so that people outside are able to see that all is above board in the Australian Parliament?

Let me deal with the first argument of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I want to disregard the personal abuse the honourable member brought into this debate. Perhaps one day I will have the opportunity of returning the compliment to him, but I will not do it on this occasion. First of all, he argued that because the Senate will not adopt this proposal, we should not do it. Should we be putting pressure on the Senate or should we be subjecting ourselves to pressure from the Senate? That is the question we have to answer. Who is the government of this country? Is it the House of Representatives or the Senate? The Government resides in the House of Representatives. The fact that we are moving this motion today, after giving notice in 1964 of our intent to move in this way, will bring greater pressure on the Senator to move in exactly the same way as we are doing today. I have absolutely no doubt that that is what will occur.

The honourable member for Boothby asked: `Why do this? A senior public servant can have more influence than a member of parliament'. In some cases that is true, but the honourable member for Boothby ought to be aware that a senior public servant already fills out a pecuniary interest statement and submits it to the Minister, and so do members of statutory authorities.

There are some problems with this proposal. I appreciate the contribution made by the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann) relating to some of the finer points that have to be dealt with in the filling out of the declarations. I appreciate the work that has been done by the Standing Committee of Members' Interests in trying to sort problems out. I do not think that the members of the New South Wales Parliament, the Victorian Parliament, the South Australian Parliament, the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, the House of Commons or the United States Congress, who all have to sign declarations, are any smarter than we are. I am pretty sure that if a few members of that Committee put their heads together they could overcome the problems which for honourable members opposite seem to be enormous hurdles that we will never be able to overcome.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has raised some matters in the House. Unfortunately, I missed most of his contribution. I understand that he was making allegations about funds for an election being put in a private account and the extent to which that would infringe upon the declaration of pecuniary interests. First of all I say to the honourable member for O'Connor that the Australian Electoral Commission might be more interested in what happens with political donations of that nature. As the honourable member knows, the Government has moved already to try to clean up the electoral system by requiring the public disclosure of donations of over $200 to a candidate or of over $1,000 to a political party. Those things are supposed to be on the record. I refer to what happened during the last election and all the predictions that the Opposition made about what would happen as a result of public disclosure of political donations and about that being the end of the world. Who took any notice when they were all published? The newspapers ran a story the next day that the biggest donors to us were some company or a trade union and the biggest donor to the Liberal Party was someone else. Who has heard anything about it since? No one.

The same principle will apply to this proposal. We have heard all the rantings from the Opposition about how it will bring the world down and how the Westminster system will suffer as a result of members of parliament having to declare their pecuniary interests. This will all be done in the next few months. In a year's time we will not hear anything about it. Of course, the Press may play it up at first, but we have taken significant notice of the Committee and of where it thought problems might arise in the declaration of monetary values of holdings rather than just the holdings themselves and we have made suitable amendments to meet the problems mentioned by the Committee in that regard. I do not believe that we will face any greater problem than the problems that have been faced by other parliaments around the world, and, indeed, by the majority of State parliaments in this country.

Such a proposal was good enough for the conservatives. The honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) seemed to think that my time in the shearing sheds was spent dreaming up ways of getting at the establishment and that 30 years ago I was thinking that if I ever reached this House of Parliament I would have a pecuniary interest statement made out by members of the Opposition. I tell honourable members opposite that if I was thinking in the shearing sheds about wanting to do something to the Opposition, it would have been far more devastating than having its members fill out pecuniary interest forms. I am not too sure that Margaret Thatcher spent any time in the shearing sheds; yet she subscribed to signing a declaration. She herself fills out a form declaring her interests to the British House of Commons and, as I said, so does every member of the American Congress.

The penalties in our proposal which will apply to honourable members who are found in contempt of the Parliament-that will be something for the Parliament itself to decide-are in line with decisions that have been taken by the State parliaments. There might be some variation on the theme, because I believe that some parliaments have a monetary penalty of up to $5,000. But in a couple of cases, the seat of a member can be declared vacant if that member is found in contempt of the resolution of the Parliament concerned. That is the same sort of proposal we are applying to this Parliament, which is the most important parliament in Australia.

So we are not doing something so terribly radical which is leading the way and which the rest of the world might look upon and be frightened away from. As is so often the case, unfortunately, in the Australian Parliament, in the wake of what has happened in the other institutions around the world, we are bringing our House into order. In the same way as we have made changes to the electoral laws, by virtue of a resolution of this House, we will ensure that members of parliament will declare their pecuniary interests so that all will be above board.

We do not hold any great suspicions. One honourable member challenged me to state a case in the last 85 years in which a member's interests may have influenced his decisions. We do not know the answer. It may have happened. Quite frankly, I would be surprised if it had not happened and some member of parliament had not been influenced by some of his personal or his family's holdings. Where the family may be involved, we have said that only to the extent that a member is aware of his spouse's holdings will he have to declare them.

In the case of the South Australian Parliament a member of that Parliament issued a statutory declaration that she was not aware of the financial or business transactions or holdings of her spouse. In so doing, she did not have to declare them as part of her pecuniary interests. The same will apply in this case. If an honourable member is not aware of a spouse's interests they will not have to be declared.

We have moved along the lines that the Committee has asked us to move in these areas. The conservatives on the Committee really wanted us to abandon the whole idea. We have been saying for at least the 12 years that I have been in the Parliament that we should introduce this proposal. I am glad that it will be brought to a conclusion today, because we have given people plenty of opportunity to look at this matter and to speak about it. Committees have looked at it. The Standing Orders Committee and the parliamentary Committee have looked at it. There have been discussions inside and outside of parliament. There has been the report of the Bowen Committee of Inquiry Concerning Public Duty and Private Interest. There has been the move by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to see that Ministers disclose their interests. Senior public servants and members of statutory authorities do so, and we are the last ones to do so. So all I am suggesting to the Parliament-

TALK.START.PARA: —The second last. What about the Senate?

—I am pretty sure-as I said earlier to the honourable member for Prospect-that what we are doing today will ultimately be the weapon and the necessary pressure that needs to be applied to members of the Senate to do exactly the same as we are doing today. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the grievance debate proceed forthwith.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme-Australia Card-Unemployment-Mudginberri Abattoir-Immigration-Rural Industry-Australian Economy-Australian War Memorial-Local Government-Australian Economy-Albion Explosives Factory

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first opportunity I have had to speak in a grievance debate. As I understand it, because it is a rare occasion one has to give some deep consideration to the matters one wants to speak about. Being the youngest Liberal in this House, the area that concerns me most and also concerns many in my electorate of Bass is the question of education, and today I want to talk about the tertiary education assistance scheme. In the last 12 months I have had considerable correspondence with the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) on this matter. I think it is something this House has been neglecting and something this community is very concerned about, and I should like to highlight some of the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The number of students in this community on a TEAS allowance is small compared with the number who would like to be beneficiaries. Indeed, a very great number of students in educational institutions rely on financial assistance provided by the Government. However, and this is the reason I really want to speak today, the levels of financial assistance available are extremely low and the conditions which apply to the granting of such assistance are extremely restrictive. Not only does this therefore mean that many students are in receipt of financial assistance which is quite patently inadequate to help them meet their needs, it has also resulted in the disturbing situation that potential students are prevented from attending tertiary institutions because of the absurdly low levels of parental income used in calculating the means test. Even worse, potential students realise that financially they would be far better off if they were receiving unemployment benefits.

This Government is on the public record as having committed itself to bridging the gap between benefits payable under TEAS and those payable under unemployment benefits. Let us examine the figures. Unemployment benefits offer a person over the age of 18 some $90 a week on which to live, not a mighty sum, but it is a princely sum when compared with the pittance offered to those who wish to further their education. If a student wishes to go on to study and is forced by circumstances to live away from home, he or she is given a maximum of $73.28 a week by the Government. If a student lives at home, this Government will donate the staggering sum of $47.50 a week. There is a perverse disincentive for young people to qualify for the unemployment benefit rather than put themselves through three or more years of rigorous academic study. Even worse are the unrealistic and totally iniquitous eligibility restrictions which apply to applications for assistance under TEAS. Tertiary students who have not met certain criteria for independence from their parents are discriminated against. A combined parental income of just $22,280 will exclude a student living at home from receiving any assistance. If a student is forced to live away from home, he receives no assistance if the combined income of his parents exceeds $27,320.

In a nation where the average wage, which admittedly can only ever be a very rough benchmark, is of the order of $20,000 per annum, these parental income limits are patently absurd and too low. Indeed, maximum assistance is granted only when the combined parental income is $14,281, an amount so low it could be treated as a sick joke if this were not such an important matter. This Government makes much of its posturing on improving the plight of the disadvantaged in our society. In Tasmania we have a Liberal Government which is really trying to help those students forced to live away from home. Every student who is in such a situation gets $40 a week towards the cost of living for 30 weeks a year, a total of $1,200; that is, every student who does not receive any assistance under TEAS, however small an amount. The TEAS guidelines allow for the receipt of a maximum $500 per annum from other allowances and grants. How absurd! Those who qualify for maximum assistance do so on the supposition that their socio-economic status entitles them to special financial help from the Government. Yet this Government's own regulations deny these people in Tasmania at least $700 a year because it has not concerned itself with the question of how best to assist those most in need. That $700 a year could go a long way to alleviate the excessive rise in book costs. All of this goes on while the Government expresses concern and wrings it hands, as indeed do all Australians, about the appallingly low retention rates evident in our education system.

According to the Government's own figures presented in the last Budget in Budget Paper No. 13, only 9.6 per cent of all people aged between 19 and 24 were engaged in some form of tertiary education in 1984. In fact, this was less than the comparable percentage figures for a decade ago. So we are slipping back, we are not going forward. One need only examine some comparable educational statistics for nations such as Germany in order to gain an indication of Australia's appalling record in this regard. For instance, in the field of tertiary engineering study, which will become an increasingly important area of research and study, the comparative figures are as follows: In Australia 24,200, which is 0.16 per cent of the population; in the United States of America nearly 1 1/2 million, being 1.53 per cent of the population; and in Japan 393,000, being 0.33 per cent of the population.

Australia lags far behind its international competitors in this vital area of tertiary education. Part of the blame at least must be sheeted home to this Government, as must the quite perverse disincentives which exist in relation to a choice between tertiary study and unemployment. This matter is one which I have consistently raised with the Minister for Education. It remains, however, an issue which this Government has been reluctant to address in any material way.

There are a number of specialised problems in relation to TEAS which are also of interest to me. There exists within my electorate of Bass the Australian Maritime College, the only maritime college in this country and a unique institution. As a result of direct action taken by this Government, some 50 students who attend the Australian Maritime College have been deprived of the benefit of even one return trip home per year. These 50 students are assessed as being substantially independent from their parents and are required to study in Launceston. They cannot study anywhere else in Australia. The argument of the Government that they are not deserving of any assistance to enable them even one trip home per year is petty in the extreme, and the budgetary savings per annum cannot amount to more than $30,000. If from a budget of $69 billion this Government cannot find $30,000 to assist a few of the small number of tertiary students in this nation, its priorities are well and truly wrong. This Government must stand condemned for its failure to assist the youth of this nation and, particularly, future mariners.

We talk a lot in this chamber about exports and how we wish to see exports expand. Since I have been in Parliament we have talked about the Australian shipping line. We need people who have expertise to run these ships. We need a shipping line that will be efficient and has the right type of people involved. If we are not prepared to help educate the people who will be involved in the shipping lines, whether it be a government run shipping line or private shipping lines, we condemn ourselves. I continue to write to the Minister to try to get this issue resolved, but I continue to get stupid, bureaucratic replies that give no substance to the things she has been saying about wanting to narrow the gap between education assistance and the unemployment benefit. It is simply appalling.

I went through the university system on TEAS. At the stage I was at university TEAS met the cost of university colleges but now it does not even half-way meet that cost. Something has to be done. It is a grievance felt by many people contemplating starting university and many people in universities. To say that the maximum amount of TEAS can be paid at a parental income up to $14,000 is a sick joke. Those on the other side of the chamber stand condemned. At least on this side of the chamber we have a young Australian who is prepared to have a bit of a go and look at these educational issues. When our policy is put forward, these issues will be addressed in a way that reflects the needs of the community and the needs of a country which has to lift its retention rates if we want to compete with the rest of the world. At the moment we are falling behind rapidly and it is a real grievance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I grieve today because of the Government's proposal to introduce a national identification system involving the issue of an identity card and a national computerised data system. I wish to sound a warning, as I genuinely believe that the Government is in error and that the introduction of an identity card system will erode our civil liberties without producing the benefit of preventing tax avoidance as the Government believes. It causes me deep anguish and sorrow that such a proposal, which is absolutely alien to the Australian Labor Party, should come from our ranks. It is unacceptable to me, as it is unacceptable to most thinking Australians, that we should ever give up any part of our privacy, civil liberties or rights, for the sake of efficiency and at the behest of Big Brother.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not alone in opposing the introduction of ID cards. There are many civil libertarians, individuals and organisations who join me in voicing their opposition to such a development. For a long time I was puzzled as to how it could be possible that such a proposal could come from a party which calls itself democratic socialist. I once heard a story which said that there is a fascist streak in the minds of many socialists or social democrats. The proponent of that theory argued that Hitler's and Mussolini's support came not from the conservatives, but from many right wing socialists and social democrats and the so-called lumpen proletariat. That, of course, would explain how the proposal for the introduction of ID cards could have come from our own ranks. However, I reject the theory that there is a fascist streak in the minds of some of us, and I also reject the necessity for the introduction of the card. That it is called an Australia Card is an exercise in cynicism in itself. Nothing can be more un-Australian than the need to prove one's identity on the call of an official, be it a policeman or a bureaucrat. It would be much more appropriate for the proposed card to be called a Hitlercard or Stalincard, as the whole exercise smacks of authoritarianism.

The proposal to introduce an identification card system and computerised data bank on individuals is a sinister attack on our civil liberties by the bureaucracy. It first appeared in some obscure Treasury papers, nudging the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to use it as a means to mop up the undeclared interest on the small savings of Australian wage and salary earners. It was of no concern to the small minds of the bureaucracy that, in the process of mopping up the petty amounts from average Aussies who are reluctant to pay taxes on inflation, by the use of identity cards our traditional liberties and our way of life which respect the privacy of the individual will be jeopardised.

Since Federation, except for a limited period during the war, we have got by well without ID cards. During the two centuries of our existence on this continent, we have always treated the individual with great respect. By the introduction of ID cards, this respect for the individual will be eroded and so will be the respect for his or her privacy. In many overseas countries where ID cards operate, including Western-type democracies, the individual, unless he or she belongs to the elite, is treated as part of the mob by the bureaucracy. In many such countries, anybody who packs a pistol can board a train or bus and ask the passengers for their ID cards.

I can tell honourable members of more extreme uses of systems of identification. I have many friends who have their numbers, not imprinted on a plastic card, but tattooed on their forearms. They have told me that if it were not for the use of ID cards overseas, the nazis would have found it much more difficult to find them and herd them into concentration camps. I mention this only to show the extremes to which systems of identification can be taken. I am not suggesting for one moment that such a use of ID cards would ever be contemplated by the Australian bureaucracy. Nonetheless, I refuse to be numbered and branded.

There is no doubt that once the ID card is introduced it can be used for any purpose, legitimate or sinister, depending on the government of the day-or, even worse, on the bureaucracy. Irrespective of assurances by the Treasurer, would anyone seriously suggest that the police will not use it as one of their tactics to intimidate individuals, by asking them to produce their ID card at every opportunity? One would have to be born in cuckoo land to believe that they will not.
I received a letter addressed to Caucus members from the Privacy Committee of New South Wales, urging us to reject the introduction of ID cards. I quote from that letter:
The Privacy Committee has consistently opposed the introduction of any `standard universal identifier'. Significant North American inquiries have rejected such a scheme as:
1. significantly privacy invasive;
2. having the potential for abuse by government and private organisations through the use of computer `matching' techniques;
3. raising a `presumption' of validity regarding the cards which would be exploited by organised crime;
4. providing the skeleton for a national dossier system;
5. requiring the creation of a complex bureaucratic apparatus to assign and administer such a scheme.

Mr Frank Costigan, a former royal commissioner, recently told the Joint Select Committee on an Australia Card-I am in agreement with him-that the introduction of a national system of identification will substantially erode privacy and civil liberties because thousands of people will be able to gain access to personal information about every Australian; and that the system is open to abuse. It will not deter organised crime or stop individuals from using multiple identities for purposes of tax avoidance and social security fraud. This point is supported by evidence from the United States and West Germany, where it is estimated that $20 billion in revenue is lost every year as a result of the fraudulent use of social security cards. I, together with other members of the community, agree and support these observations and criticisms and urge the Government to reconsider the proposed introduction of a national identification card system in Australia. I also urge the Government to give more serious consideration to other less intrusive, less authoritarian means of reducing the rate of tax evasion and social security fraud, such as the reform of banking practices and the further tightening of loopholes in the Income Tax Assessment Act, which Mr Costigan and many others have suggested.

The disclosure of taxation file numbers as a prerequisite for opening bank accounts would decrease the incidence of tax avoidance and social security fraud by eradicating non-disclosure of income and the possession of multiple bank accounts under false names. Measures such as these constitute a less costly and more effective method of reaching the same objectives as the Australia Card, without the same invasion of privacy or destruction of individual civil liberties. I could also quote many other articles and editorials opposed to the introduction of a national identification card system, but I choose only one, from Arthur Horner in the Age of 20 August last year. Horner wrote:

. . . let's face it, when in a democracy you need a bit of card to say not that you can drive a car or are credit worthy but simply that you exist, and have a number to prove it, it's time to get a bit concerned. While such a card could be very handy for those of us who don't know who we are, the rest of us should take a good hard look at it-before it happens.

Accordingly, I call on the Treasurer and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is in charge of this infamous proposal, to think again before it happens. I would like again to remind the House of the seventeenth century French philosopher, Descartes, who said `Ego cogito, ergo sum', which means: `I think, therefore I am.' If the Treasurer and the Minister for Health, formerly of the Civil Liberties Council of South Australia, need a plastic card instead of thought to determine who they are, I certainly do not. I reject such intrusion of my privacy and of the privacy of millions of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Strange though it may sound, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) will find a lot of agreement on this side of the House to what he has said today. I compliment him and remind listeners that he is someone who during the Second World War fought in Yugoslavia against the nazis and has a very full understanding of what the numbering system is all about. His comments should not be dismissed lightly, despite the fact that the editorials and some newspaper articles write down those of us who have the same concerns as those expressed so well by him from the other side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition Whip's office rang me last evening and said: `You are speaking in the grievance debate tomorrow'. So I got out the file of the subject on which I had been wishing to speak for some time. I felt: Well, I am ready for it. At 20 past 12 this morning in bed at my hotel I was reading a Courier-Mail-I am not sure whether it was yesterday's Courier-Mail or the one for the day before-and tucked away at the back of the paper was a reference to the length of time that people are out of work. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures had shown that over the last five years there had been a considerable growth in terms of the time, or the number of weeks, that people were out of work. I want to state today that Australia's unemployment problem is far worse than presented and it is getting worse. The Hawke Government is deceiving the public on the unemployment problem. The latest Bureau of Statistics figures show that the unemployed are waiting longer than ever to find a job. This means that overall unemployment has reached its most devastating proportion since the Great Depression. I repeat that: It has reached its most devastating proportion since the Great Depression. Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which I have prepared.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, these figures, which are all based on financial years, for the year ending 30 June, show the following: In 1981 there were 400,000 Australians out of work but the number of weeks out of work was 34. What it meant in that time was that 260,000 work years were being lost by the population as a result of unemployment. In 1982, when the Fraser Government was getting on to slippery ground, the 400,000 unemployed had grown to 480,000 unemployed and the 260,000 work years had grown to 320,000 work years. In 1983 there were 725,000 out of work and the total lost work years amounted to 550,000. In all fairness, a lot of that was in the Fraser years, but it was also the beginning of the Hawke years. I will repeat those figures: 725,000 people out of work and 550,000 work years lost.

SPEECH.PARA: We are all subjected to propaganda about how marvellously the Government is doing. In 1983 that 725,000 unemployed fell to 630,000. However, lost work years grew from 550,000 to 580,000. Even now, although the number of unemployed has fallen just below the 600,000 level, the number of work years lost has almost touched 600,000 work years. The point I am making is that in the last five years we have seen the numbers grow from 260,000 lost work years in 1981 to 320,000 lost work years in 1982, to 550,000 lost work years in 1983, to 580,000 lost work years in 1984, up to the end of last financial year when it touched the 600,000 mark. Even for the year in which unemployment was at its highest level ever-in 1983, when there were 725,000 out of work-the number of work years lost was infinitely lower than it is now. The proud chest beating of Australian Labor Party Ministers about unemployment figures must be a distressingly hollow and phoney sound to the nearly 600,000 still out of work who have been through a bitter experience and have learnt the hard way that to go on the dole now means to face a sentence of a year's hardship.

For reasons of political expediency the nation has been continually taught to forget about unemployment as a problem. I suggest that in view of the picture that is emerging this is a shameful act. Unfortunately, even in the recent parliamentary recess, we saw articles coming out which suggested that Australia has probably reached a stage where we are always going to have this number of people unemployed. I think the Government ran away from actually commenting on that. One or two Ministers or academics said: `Perhaps that's right'. I do not believe that this nation has any chance of recovering while we fail to recognise that the problem of unemployment is in fact worse than it has ever been.

Lest it be suggested that I am using figures selectively, I am using not only the Bureau of Statistics figures but also the figures of the Department of Social Security. Here is the cost to the nation of unemployment benefit over the five years I have just referred to: In the year 1981, $1 billion dollars, in the year 1982, $1.25 billion; in the year 1983, $2.25 billion; in the year 1984, $2.9 billion; and in the year 1985 it is touching $3 billion. It could be said that there is an inflationary factor in that in terms of higher benefits, and I willingly agree that that would be the case. The point is that in the Fraser years the benefit was costing $2.25 billion and today it is costing $3 billion. I believe that when we put both these sets of figures together it completely destroys the myth that has been created in this country that unemployment is under control and things are getting better.

In conclusion I state as fact that this continuing unemployment is draining the nation. Granted there are fewer people being hurt, but those hurt are being hurt for longer. I believe that one year on the dole compared with, say, 34 weeks during the Fraser years can mean the absolute destruction of so many lives. The Government, including the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), describes the Treasurer (Mr Keating) as the world's greatest. That is a lot of piffle. One only has to look at interest rates and our balance of payments to destroy that claim. I include the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in this. I believe it is time that people knew the truth as to what is really going on. The only apology I make is that I have not thought of presenting the figures in this way before, when it has suited so many politicians and others to conceal the truth by simply talking about the raw numbers rather than the man years being lost, because that tells an entirely different story. The complacency which exists on the other side has come to an end. Now that members on this side of the House know what the figures are about, we are going to give the Government heaps into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this grievance debate I would like to grieve momentarily about the sophistry that one hears in this House from time to time. I draw the attention of the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) to the words of Sir Winston Churchill's father when he referred to liars, damned liars and statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been giving some consideration to what the future of this House is. It has a lot of history. With the advent of the bicentennial year we will be moving to a magnificent new structure up the road and I think some thought should be given to what we should do with this House. In the time that remains for it I would like to use it as a slaughter house to try to slaughter some of the sacred cows that beset Australia.

The one I would like to start with concerns Mudginberri. The Mudginberri incident was not the answer. It is true that slaughtermen can earn big money at Mudginberri, but unskilled workers did not fare anywhere near as well and there is no doubt that the big exporters working under the existing scheme have been the greatest contributors to our performance. It was an attempt to impose American culture on ours and as such it was bound to cause friction. In saying that, I must say I have absolutely no respect for the performance of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union; its public relations was deplorable. It is interesting to note in Mudginberri that these masters of free enterprise who put forward this scheme wanted the Government to compromise our health standards to protect their profits, thereby putting at risk the export of all Australian meat.

Mudginberri had its supporters in the rural sector, many of them mindless ideologues-and there are ideologues on the Right who are just as mindless as some of those on the Left. There were people in the rural sector who supported Mudginberri out of desperation, for it is true that the rural sector is beset by enormous problems and something must be done to address the problems of terms of trade, interest rates and markets that exist in the rural sector. Mudginberri was a simplistic answer and simplistic answers are often popular.

I suspect it would be more beneficial for the rural sector to look at perhaps slaughtering stock in Australia, boning it out in, say, China and distributing it from there. There might be many markets to be opened and opportunities to be obtained there. In any case, China offers enormous potential to Australia. I was told while I was in China recently that by the year 2050, President Reagan permitting, they expect to have stabilised their population at 1.2 billion people and to have a per capita income approaching that of the West. As such, China will be the powerhouse of the world economy.

When I was in Lanzhou I noticed stacked up in a factory I visited oil pump jacks, all consigned to America. In Australia when we buy pump jacks for pumping oil from fields such as those which exist north of Derby in my electorate we buy them from America at four times the price. We have an enormous balance of trade deficit with America, an enormous surplus with China. Every dollar we buy out of China means we can sell into China and I think that we must be exploring the potential of the China market.

I would like to attack another couple of myths: The myth of multiculturalism and the myth of family reunion immigration policy. Multiculturalism is a policy propounded by both major political parties in this country, and it is simply wrong. This country is not multicultural; this country is Anglo-Celtic in origin. That is an accident of history but it is a fact, and the machinations of politicians will not disguise this. The great danger to this country is that that main culture, that Anglo-Celtic culture, is dividing against itself and it is dividing on a city-country basis. The manifestation of this is the macho image that farmers and miners try to portray-the image that they as earners of export income are somehow more important than city workers; a nonsense concept.

We have seen it manifested in the cities by a disregard for the problems in the rural sector. Twenty, 30 years ago, everyone in the cities had an uncle or brother in the country, or just moved from the bush and there was a sympathy. I think that has died and it is a tragedy for Australia. We must be working to unite those two sections of Australia because divided we will not survive. We will not survive if we continue this. I might add that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland is one of the greatest culprits in this regard. He has been likened in this House to a poor man's Marcos. I say he is a latter day Papa Doc.

Arising out of multiculturalism has come our immigration policy. I believe that Australia owes no regard to consideration other than national interest in terms of immigration policy. What we need is a dynamic economy. Into a dynamic economy we can fit far more refugees than we presently take, and they can be fitted into the economy without any disruption. The overriding consideration for Australia must be national interest.

The policy of family reunion in Australia at the moment effectively discriminates against a very large section of immigrants. They are the traditional immigrants upon which this country was built. It is difficult these days for German, Dutch, Yugoslav and British people, and some others, to get into the country because they no longer comply with the guidelines. Their parents are dead and their brothers and sisters are their age-they are middle-aged now-and they do not want to move. What they need is a policy that recognises their need to be able to bring in nephews, nieces and younger people.

I have on my files the names of literally dozens of people with entrepreneurial flair and $100,000 or $200,000 who want to come to Australia. It is extraordinarily difficult to get these people into the country. The ones whose names are on my files are principally British but some are from Germany. It is not in the national interest to discourage these people. Immigration is neutral in its effect. We can devastate our economy if we bring in the wrong sorts of immigrants; we can enhance it if we bring in the right sorts. We ought to have a policy that allows us to bring into this country immigrants who are going to contribute immediately to the country and to employ other people. Instead, I find myself having to fight rearguard actions to prevent the deportation of many immigrants in this country, albeit illegally, who are making a substantial contribution.

Recently a case in Geraldton was drawn to my attention. A family had settled in the town for three years. The kids were at the school, the parents were gainfully employed. At a moment's notice they were given two weeks to get out of the country. I have another case on record which I will go into greater detail about later on. I do think we have to face this fact: The policy that we have does discriminate against the large source of traditional immigrants to this country. I believe that if this policy is not changed or ameliorated there is going to be a backlash, a back-lash of significant proportions, and I would not like to be on the receiving end of that.

There are many, many attempts these days to deny our heritage. I think there is some belief that Australia must create for itself a brand new image, an instant ersatz Australian. We are all products of our past; none of us can escape that. In our past there is good and bad, but I would say that, on balance, our culture has absolutely nothing to be ashamed of. In an historical concept, there are things of which I would not approve and I do not think anyone would approve of them today, but by the standards of the time our culture was probably more enlightened than other prevailing cultures. I think it is a great tragedy when we try to seek a future by neglecting the past. It is a dangerous course. It is a course which can, in fact, lead to getting lost on the way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the House to the economic and social tragedy taking place in rural Australia. The whole structure of family farming is under threat and with it the infrastructure of small business and vibrant rural communities. This infrastructure has been built up, despite the harshest conditions of climate and economic conditions, over many generations to become highly efficient units working long hours and, in many cases, earning a fraction of the average wage. By contributing 40 to 50 per cent of our export income this rural sector still has the most potential of any sector to reverse our foreign debt explosion, yet this Government has allowed our primary sector to be exposed to adverse circumstances to a degree not contemplated by any other agriculture intensive nation. Of course, low commodity prices and aggressive trading and market corruption by many of our competitors are significant factors. Poor seasons in particular regions such as the Central Mallee of my electorate have produced a crisis for grain growers and the communities that serve them of a magnitude worse than any experienced since settlement. These factors are mainly out of the control of the farmers or of governments.

SPEECH.PARA: These conditions are not the prime reason for the economic plight facing rural Australia. The Australian farmer's ability to adapt, to innovate and continually to improve productivity has kept us ahead of our competitors and has provided a source of cheap and high quality products for our domestic population. Increased productivity and improved farming techniques will no longer ensure the viability of agriculture. Governments throughout Australia today must act with real understanding and restore equity in agricultural policies. The seriousness of the situation has to be recognised. This Federal Government has that responsibility and apologists in the Government or for it in the community must be exposed to their role in this national debacle affecting the total small business community.

The real problem is twofold and it is domestic: Firstly, the effects of national economic policies that have acted against and discriminated against our productive industries; secondly, an anti-rural attitude, that has already drawn hundreds of millions of dollars away from the farm sector, by the Hawke Labor Government. It is incredible to the extent of being provocative that this process is continuing, the recent fertiliser rort being the most noticeable, not to mention, of course, the petrol price situation. If the 7c per litre drop in fuel prices is not passed on it will cost each wheat farm $1,685 next year and each dairy and horticultural property $610 each year. It will rob the rural sector of another $140m and, of course, will rob massive amounts from the average motorist.

The Government, I believe, has embarked on a dangerous economic course in using high interest rates and foreign borrowings to support a sick dollar and to fund our excessive public expenditure. The self-employed, the export-competing sector simply cannot live with these policies and are now totally left out in the cold. Government and its advisers may argue that the monetary policies being pursued are considered appropriate for the long term benefit of our nation's economy, but there is no justification for destroying the primary sector along the way. At the time of recent visits I have made to banks in my electorate top farm loan rates stood at 21.75 per cent. The average farm loan of all borrowers was 20.25 per cent. This Government is now suggesting that these people, who in good faith entered into realistic borrowing arrangements in the 10 to 12 per cent range, should not receive compensation for the massive escalation in rates, or assistance to remain in the industry. The current loan repayment problems are worse than they were during any period of tight liquidity, during drought or during previous recessions.

I stress that every Labor Budget and mini-Budget and the accord have worked against small business and the self-employed sector. Labor has already withdrawn $440m directly from Federal Government outlays since coming to office in changing the deductibility provisions and the depreciation allowance and, of course, the emasculation of the income equalisation deposit scheme. It has imposed additional costs with the indexation of fuel and, of course, the sales tax on petroleum products. We are yet to face Labor's proposal to limit the amount of farm losses that can be written off against other income. This becomes significant at this particular time when many families, in an effort to survive and to meet debt repayments, are forced to take off-farm employment. Add to this the new capital gains tax, the assets test, the fringe benefits tax and we see a recipe for disaster.

Why are we facing this consistent attack on thrift and productivity and a planned attack on this nation's capital base? The seriousness and impact of this attack by the Government is highlighted by recent Bureau of Agricultural Economics figures which show the increase in, and the extent of, farm debt. It increased by 50 per cent between June 1980 and June 1985 and has escalated massively since then. We see today that total rural institutional debt is $7 billion. We see that the average debt on all farms throughout Australia is $80,000, and even this figure does not reflect the true position of most of those in trouble. The cumulative effects of low prices, high costs and escalating interest rates coinciding with three disastrous years out of four that have occurred in my electorate have produced a state of crisis and will lead to a disastrous future unless significant support and assistance is urgently provided.

What must be done? I must stress that this is a human problem of great magnitude. We are not dealing with just statistics, finance and figures; we are dealing with human lives and families who are facing personal tragedies of the highest order. If what has taken place over a period of years in the Mallee had taken place in one year somewhere else it would be recognised as a natural disaster. Governments, both State and Federal, therefore, must see this crisis as they would a bushfire or an extreme drought and meet it with understanding and a desire to assist, above party politics and individual differences between States and industries.

The lead is being given by local communities, who are responding to the crisis by forming local support groups and committees, assisted by church leaders and professional people from our government departments. Their support for each other is commendable and typical of the community spirit which has lifted rural regions out of similar difficulties in the past. Many families are eligible for family income support and in order to meet the basic requirements of the household women are reluctantly registering for employment and some will receive unemployment benefit. Already there have been in excess of 100 such applications in my area and they are increasing daily as conditions deteriorate. While this is entirely their right, such approaches are foreign to these people and are placing great stress on their dignity and pride. The lasting solution to our problems cannot be found through social welfare and we must reject this. It will be to the everlasting shame of this nation if lack of government support and concern forces our self-employed people, particularly our older citizens and women, into the dole queues in a desperate bid to meet their basic living requirements for their families.

The underlying difficulties confronting Australia's farmers and small businesses and the scores of people in the rural work force now being stood down are interest rates, the escalation of costs and bureaucratic red tape. This is an on-going question and I do not wish to discuss much more of it here. It is clear that existing programs are not meeting the specific needs of the Mallee community. The Rural Finance Commission has been able to assist only a percentage of applicants because the rural adjustment scheme provides support only for those considered to have a long term prospect. These families then face the prospect of having to walk off their properties. Farms are on sale at unreasonable prices and if these families were sold up by creditors they would be left with only clothing and personal items. Land values would crash if a large number of properties were forced on to the market in this way and banks would then readjust their equity levels, which would mean that another group of farmers would become marginal and be placed under severe economic restrictions by financial institutions. This situation must be prevented at all costs. The Rural Finance Commission must meet this situation and any constraints due to the criteria, the rural adjustment scheme or the amount of funds available must be removed.

There is a clear need for additional specific programs to be developed for the affected areas, such as the central Mallee with its boundaries extending from Ultima in the east, Birchip in the south, Hopetoun and Patchewollock in the west and the Murray River in the north. Sea Lake is central to this area and is the most severely affected district. I ask for special initiatives as a matter of urgency to meet this crisis. It is in order for the survival of individuals and families and for the grain industries in the communities that service them in the Mallee. We need an immediate and appropriate increase in Commonwealth and State funding from the rural adjustment scheme. We believe that the existing program will be fully committed by mid-February and there will be unprecedented demand on it in the weeks ahead.
