Both of these programs in the rural adjustment scheme would allow time for farmers to reassess their position and it would stop properties from being forced on to the market. It would prevent a crash in land values and would save many farmers from certain economic disaster.

Rural Australia is saying in no uncertain terms that it will not accept defeat, that it is not going to be made redundant and that it will not allow the callousness or the ignorance of governments, no matter which they are, to throw away this nation's rural heritage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would firstly like to offer you my congratulations on achieving the office of Deputy Speaker and my best wishes. The Australian War Memorial in Canberra serves as a permanent national shrine to those who have served their country in times of war. As such it is an important venue for the remembrance of the courage of those who have fought and died. The continued popularity of the Memorial's displays and educational activities has ensured that many people from both Australia and overseas are aware of the immense human sacrifice made during wartime.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, however, another dimension to the role of a national war memorial that has not been consciously developed in Australia-the link between war and peace. Peace is the ultimate objective of war and this connection is manifest in every conflict Australia has been engaged in since Federation. Veterans and war strategists agree that peace is the result for which armed forces struggle. Indeed, the soldiers, sailors and airmen immortalised in war memorials around the world fought not for glory but for peace. Power and greed are the triggers of war and governments and individuals carry the blame; but I do not propose to debate this issue today.

Regardless of cause and effect, there is a need for the nation to remember not only those who fought and died but also why they fought and died. They died in the pursuit of peace. I would therefore argue for the creation of a peace memorial sited in Canberra which would embrace the spirit of the Australian War Memorial while recognising the primacy of peace in the precipitation and settlement of armed conflict. The relationship between a peace memorial and a war memorial is a logical one and is reflected in the mutual association of war and peace. A peace memorial established adjacent to the Australian War Memorial would give the fullest expression to this association and would extend the process of education already undertaken by the Australian War Memorial by providing a visible statement on the reason for the sacrifice of the lives-particularly apt in this International Year of Peace.

The education section of the War Memorial with its numerous classroom activities, information and learning programs has been one of the most successful aspects of the Memorial, with over 60,000 school children alone participating every year in education programs. Given this level of accessibility, the Australian War Memorial is in a uniquely advantageous position to incorporate demonstration of the steps which must be taken to achieve peace in the future. By selling books, giving pamphlets and mounting displays to recreate the scenes of specific battles, the War Memorial is educating young people in the history of Australia. It is already involved in the process of teaching the anguish of war and the desirability of peace. It fulfils this role objectively and with sensitivity. Staff members are superbly equipped to cope with its natural extension, which I am proposing. The funding base of the Memorial would then also, of course, require extension relative to its extra function.

The concept of a peace memorial is by no means new, the possibility having been explored in many countries overseas. The desire to promote the association between war and peace has led to the establishment of major peace memorials in Japan and the United States. In addition, the Canadian Government has taken steps to incorporate a peace memorial as part of the National War Museum. Perhaps the most graphic and comprehensive example of a peace memorial is in Hiroshima, Japan, the site of the first atomic bomb attack. A special peace centre exists in Hiroshima and consists of a peace memorial park and a peace memorial hall. The hall contains offices, meeting rooms and a museum with the information on the bomb blast and its effects, while the Peace Memorial Park faces the Atomic Bomb Dome, the site of the actual explosion. In addition, the Peace Centre includes a memorial cenotaph for atomic bomb victims. As well as the names of the victims there is an inscription on the cenotaph that reads: `Repose in peace, for the error shall not be repeated'.

The need to recognise remembrance of war and peace has also been taken up by our traditional allies, the United States, as a peace museum has been set up in Chicago. This museum was established in 1982 through a United States Federal Government grant. There is another memorial and a peace park at Nagasaki. Proposals for a peace memorial were also made in Ottawa, Canada, the site of the Canadian National War Museum. In addition, the Royal Canadian Air Force has planned a peace memorial in Trenton, Ontario, but a lack of funds has so far prevented the completion of the project.

While a peace memorial in Australia could draw on some of the features of the memorials of other nations, an Australian peace memorial should be uniquely Australian in character, reflecting Australian values and the efforts and desires of Australians' own initiatives in attaining world peace. Given the role of Australia as one of the leading nations in the remembrance of peace, this commitment to establishing a national character within a peace memorial would indeed be appropriate.

Secondly, an Australian peace memorial should have an educational function but should not involve peace education classes as such. The educative lessons of peace transmitted through a peace memorial should be made through implication rather than direct instruction. An Australian peace memorial should illustrate rather than indoctrinate and a suitable format of display could be developed that would go no further than an explanation of the horrific effects and consequences of war, particularly nuclear war. In this respect an Australian peace memorial could be in the spirit of the Hiroshima memorials, illustrating a peace message in an indirect way, with the archives and relics of war telling their own stories. An Australian peace memorial could therefore be educational to the extent that it records the results of the nuclear course we are now following and, like Hiroshima, it should not comment in any way on the actions of any other country. Particularly, an Australian peace memorial should be uniquely Australian, giving talented Australians the opportunity to design a fitting complex.

The real question to ask is: Why should Australia have a peace memorial? I believe that it should because attitude underlines all human endeavour. Remembrance of past sacrifice, history, art and science are all essential to the enrichment of our culture but peace is essential to the very survival of our culture. Without a proper respect for and understanding of the need to put the pursuit of peace at the top of our ladder of aims and achievements, memorials and institutions dedicated to the pursuit of history, art and science will be as nothing.

What is the cost of a lack of peace in the world-the real cost? Every minute 30 children die for want of food and inexpensive vaccines and every minute the world's military budgets absorb $1.3m of the public treasure. The world's stockpile of nuclear weapons represents an explosive force over 5,000 times greater than that of all the munitions used in World War II. The cost of a single new nuclear submarine equals the annual budget of 23 developing countries with 160 million school-aged children. According to a United Nations report which was presented in 1982, one-half of one per cent of one year's world military expenditure would pay for all the farm equipment needed to increase food production and approach self-sufficiency in food deficit low income countries by 1990.

How is this related to an Australian war memorial? Certainly a memorial would not rectify the situation of hunger and need-and indeed there is an urgent necessity for all governments to give the problems of developing nations high priority-but attitudes of electors underlie government action. We have an Australian War Memorial superbly run; we should have an Australian peace memorial. It need not mean an enormous amount of expenditure which could better go to feeding people, but it could prove part of an educative process which is needed. Our institutes and memorials fulfil the role of formulating attitude. Every concrete action in society finds its nucleus in an attitude or a desire. If our attitude towards life is built on the accumulation of material goods as the ultimate goal, power will reign. Great buildings will be erected and war will continue.

There is a build-up of arms which should be reversed. To find the path to this reversal, to find peace, we need to have a standard-we need to have a memorial which has an educative process which extends the process of the Australian War Memorial and provides our school children with information which shows the irreversible link between war and peace. To find peace we must want peace. It is up to us, it is up to adults and up to governments in our society to ensure that the information necessary for formulating the correct attitudes is available.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I add my congratulations on your election to your high office. I wish to use this grievance debate to raise the issue of local government amalgamation, which the State Labor Government in Victoria is forcing on municipalities across the State and which is causing grave concern to ratepayers and councillors across the electorate of Corangamite.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that local government is referred to as the third tier of government in our national democratic system and the tier often considered to be closest to the people. In my electorate-and I know this goes for many electorates across Victoria-innumerable hard-working citizens have given many years of their lives in an honorary capacity to serve their local community. They have done so with honour, pride and integrity and often to the disadvantage of their own financial and family situations. Yet this Labor Government is hell-bent on forcing amalgamations, for what we can only assume are blatant political reasons, on the system which has generally served Victorian ratepayers well.

The Federal Parliament has a substantial financial involvement in local government and therefore should be actively interested in its future direction. The 1985-86 Budget showed that Federal taxpayers contribute to local government through State grants, road building projects, community employment programs, JOLOR-jobs on local roads-programs and, more specifically, $487m through the 2 per cent Federal income tax sharing system.

There may well be instances when amalgamations could prove to be in the interests of ratepayers, but it is up to the local communities to decide where those amalgamations are necessary-not State government or politically biased commissions. A poll of ratepayers within the municipal boundaries would seem the only fair way to determine the views of ratepayers, but in Gippsland, where such a poll was undertaken resulting in clear opposition to an amalgamation plan, it was totally disregarded by the Labor Party in Spring Street. The State Government has argued its case on the grounds of greater efficiency; in other words, centralisation of service and decision making works better than the smaller, decentralised approach. This is typical of how the Labor Party approaches policy formation generally. But big is not necessarily better and a number of documents, such as the report by Coopers and Lybrand and W. D. Scott, management consultants, expose the flaws in the Government's assumption of the economic benefits of amalgamation as put forward by the Victorian Grants Commission.

The Victorian Government has relied heavily on the findings of the Commission to substantiate its case for fewer councils, yet the Coopers and Lybrand report found that the recurring economic benefits likely to flow from the State Government's wholesale restructure are likely to be relatively small. This report states that by and large the apparent economies of scale discovered by the Grants Commission are illusory.

I believe that, due to intervention in the role of local government by State and Federal governments that has taken place over recent times, local government has been losing control over its decision-making autonomy, while at the same time having provision of services imposed upon it which ratepayers neither require nor can afford. Originally local government provided the very essential services of road and street maintenance, garbage collection, building and planning supervision and infant welfare. Of late, however, more and more services have been thrust on to local government and, as a consequence, local government is now responsible for a wide range of so-called human services. These are often costly to maintain and many are of questionable benefit when one looks at the cost involved relative to the number of recipients of the service. Frequently these services have arisen out of hasty election promises during State and Federal campaigns where a capital grant is generously offered to local government and then, after a structure is created, we find local government has been left to carry the ongoing recurrent expenditure.

The recent debacle of unutilised child centres provides a perfect example of this. The State Government decided on the location of child care need. The Federal Government put up the capital for buildings, local councils provided the land and then the Federal Government changed its funding arrangements; and now the centres remain unopened because local government has not the funds to meet the recurrent expenditure of the centres. The human service areas of community education, recreation and arts offices; aged people's services; child care and pre-school centres, welfare and financial counselling; and unemployment supervision are just some of the areas which have led to the increasing administrative burden of local government and escalating cost in provision. Many local councillors and their executive officers have been almost as guilty as State and Federal politicians in proudly announcing the provision of such services with little or no regard for the long term implications of the costs involved. Responsible municipalities which have not embarked headlong into many of these services, which the State Labor Government would no doubt include in its social justice strategy and who have consequently kept their rates low and had minimum borrowing requirements, now find themselves included in proposals for amalgamation with less financially prudent councils. It is simply not fair that ratepayers within the cost-conscious municipalities now find their council's savings and creditworthiness used to offset the extravagance of less responsible councils.

While extra services have been imposed on to local government, they have by and large lost control over their own decision-making process because we now have regional planning authorities, consultative councils, State appeals tribunals and Federal and State policy departments which ultimately decide local government direction. It is my view that local government has been deluded into trading its decision-making autonomy for capital grants and, as a consequence, is left with a whole range of costly and often questionable human services which neither the taxpayer nor the ratepayer can afford.

Forced amalgamation as currently proposed by the State Labor Government in Victoria will worsen this situation. Local government will become no more than an administrative tentacle of the State Government with highly paid bureaucrats in command. It does not surprise me that a survey of the metropolitan town clerks in Melbourne found no dissent to amalgamation. After all, they will not be disadvantaged by amalgamation and, for most of them, their salaries and positions will be improved.

In proceeding with amalgamation the State Government has obviously paid little regard to the costs involved. For instance, in the Launceston city amalgamation in Tasmania the cost of staff redundancy payments was in the vicinity of $3m. The State Government in Tasmania was approached to make up these costs but refused and, therefore, the ratepayers of the amalgamated city of Launceston will have to cover the $3m. The University of New England has done a study and found that the benefits were less than certain when in New South Wales there was amalgamation to 15 councils of formerly 34 under an Act of Parliament in 1980.

In my electorate of Corangamite there have been a number of meetings where this local government issue has become very important for the local people. Issues raised have been local representation, the borrowings of surrounding councils and the rate increase potential. Traditionally well-run, responsive local councils are now concerned about the problem of being amalgamated with less financially prudent councils. The Minister for Local Government, Mr Simmonds, well known for his left-wing tendencies in the Labor Government, is pushing forward with his amalgamation plans with a view to centralising the power in Spring Street so that the policies of social justice can be implemented by the Australian Labor Party.

In the United Kingdom the amalgamation of mega-municipalities has seen a reverse to this policy and we now see a return to the old boroughs of 30 years ago. The Government there is finding that there are no advantages in having the bigger municipalities. Prime Minister Thatcher, having seen the extravagances of local government, is on record as making some attempts to curb these excesses. Likewise, even the Labor Party is concerned about the excesses of local government.

I pay tribute to the harmonious relationship that I have had in Corangamite with local municipalities and pay tribute to the work and dedication of the councillors in the shires of Otway, Colac, Winchelsea, Bannockburn, Leigh, Bellarine, Queenscliffe and Barrabool and the cities of Colac and South Barwon, and I hope that they will continue to be their local representatives in the truest form of democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me begin by congratulating you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your elevation to your high office, and I wish you well. It is an index of the way in which economic thinking in Australia is dominated by conservative forces that the only responses to the current account problems that one hears about at the moment are the knee-jerk and right-wing ones. I was especially disappointed to read the comments of the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr Bernie Fraser, in which he suggested that a renegotiation of the prices and incomes accord is necessary to further discount wages and reduce Australian living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the most common response of conservative economists, when faced with any economic difficulties, to call for reductions in the wages of working people. This has been the response of conservatives for the last 150 years. But this response is not a panacea. Even though the Liberal-National parties have no wages policies except reduction, reduction and more reduction in the wages of workers, the fact is that that is not the way in which to run a modern economy and it will not resolve our problems. One has to consider the causes of the current situation in detail, and they have evolved over many years-I might say over many years of mismanagement of our trading situation, of our industry policy and of the macroeconomic strategy in general of previous conservative administrations. They have created and caused the crisis that we are facing at the present time, including, I might say, the so-called rural crisis, because they have created the circumstances in which our trading situation was bound to deteriorate. When they had the opportunity to create a viable export manufacturing sector for this country, they failed to take up that opportunity; and we are now paying the price.

Rather than reflecting on the past, it is better to talk about what might be done in the current situation. In order to look at this matter we must first recognise that it is disappointing that the impact of the devaluation on imports in particular has not been as good as might have been hoped. It is important to recognise that the devaluation provided much increased competitiveness to Australian manufacturing industry. In fact it was equivalent to an increase in tariffs of between 10 and 20 per cent, so it was certainly a substantial change in that respect and made the competitive position much better for Australian manufacturing industry.

Although there has been some increase in manufacturing investment and intended manufacturing investment, unfortunately that increase does not seem to have resulted in, and does not appear to be resulting in, a turn-around in terms of a reduction in imports. So the J-curve effect, that is, the effect whereby there would have been an increase in domestic production and a reduction in imports, appears to be further away than most people in this country would have hoped. One of the problems that we have is: What are the causes of this situation and what can be done in the future to resolve it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your interest rates are to blame for that; 21 per cent.

—I hear the interjection from the honourable member opposite that interest rates are the cause of the situation. I remind him that he has got his causes and effects back to front. It is because of the high current account deficit that interest rates have remained high. I suggest that he study some more economics and come back with a viable solution to the problem. The high interest rate situation has been forced on the Government partly because of the worsening situation in relation to the balance of payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go to the hub of this problem. The fact is that, like the Mitterrand Government in France in 1981, we have put into place programs which have led to substantial growth in the Australian economy and this has led to substantial growth in demand, as one would have expected, in particular in substantial growth in imports and especially in durable imports. That is the situation we are faced with. It is a serious situation because it has resulted in this deteriorating balance of trade position. When there is an increase in growth in the economy, it is almost inevitable that there will be pressure for increases in imports. We have to deal with the situation in a sensible way so that we are not forced into the sort of position which France was forced into of adopting a series of deflationary and negative measures to deal with a crisis situation that arose. The honourable member, rather than interjecting, would do well to recognise that this is a problem for the whole of the nation and that it would be better if we sat down and thought about how we are going to get out of this problem rather than throw out pat solutions such as the kind which suggest that, if we merely reduce wages, we will solve the matter.

Let me say something about this notion of reducing wages. The fact is that workers in this country have taken a discount in their wages already as a consequence of the devaluation. That has already occurred. That has already put pressure on the prices and incomes accord. Further pressure on the prices and incomes accord and attempting to further discount the wages of workers, firstly, will not resolve the crisis and, secondly, will put us in danger of undermining the central tenet of the economic strategy of the Government which is the prices and incomes accord. As Mr Fraser himself said, this is not an option for the Labor Government.

One has to ask: Why is there this pressure for imports? Why has this increase been occurring, given the devaluation? Why have there not been increases in the prices of imported goods, or sufficient increases in the prices of imported goods, so that we could have the offsetting effect? The answer is that, in fact, importers were existing previously on very large margins; they had very large margins with which to play. Consequently, rather than increasing their prices or reducing the amount of goods being imported into Australia, they have cut their margins. Imports are continuing to penetrate Australia at an unacceptable level. This is the problem we have to deal with.

We hear honourable members opposite saying that the only resolution to our current problems is a reduction in wages, rather than looking at doing something about the continuing penetration of imports. This is the serious matter which they refuse to come to, nor do they have any policy for increasing investment in manufacturing and taking up the increased competitiveness which has been created by the devaluation of the dollar. These are the problems that the Government has to address.

There are two things that the Government needs to be looking at and is looking at. The first is the continuing implementation of the Labor Party's industry platform. With the implementation of that platform and the development of further plans in different areas of industry we will go forward and further develop manufacturing investment. The second thing we need to do is to look at the nature of the protection mechanism and re-evaluate the situation. We need to re-evaluate it and to ask ourselves whether it is not time for the Government to be considering alternative protection mechanisms that do, in fact, result in reductions in imports. One of the mechanisms that we ought to look at is quantitative limits on the number of imports. Unless we look at mechanisms of that kind, we may not be able to achieve the J-curve effect, the turn-around in the balance of payments and the situation of continuing growth that we want.

Let me repeat the point with which I began. It is not an option for the Labor Party and the Labor Government to look at reductions in the real level of wages. It is not a solution to the problem. We will not be adopting it in any of our deliberations in relation to the current economic situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I also add my congratulations to those of others in this chamber and wish you well in the post that you now occupy. I am glad that the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) is in the chamber at the moment because the subject which I am going to address today, I think, will be of particular interest to him. I refer, of course, to the announcement by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) at the end of last year, on 13 December, to close the Albion explosives factory. It is interesting that the Minister chose to make that announcement after the Parliament rose. I suggest that probably he did not have the courage to make that announcement while the Parliament was actually sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: Ostensibly, the factory has been closed after a review of explosive factories throughout the Commonwealth. I can speak with some knowledge of the history of the area because, as Chairman of the Opposition defence committee, I visited the factory in the winter recess last year in company with the secretary of the committee. It is interesting to note that from the outset there has been a prolonged campaign by the Left activists of the Australian Labor Party branches in Calwell to close down that factory. That is in fact the whole purpose of the exercise. It is interesting to note that, when the closure was announced just before Christmas, the first couple of people to welcome the closure were none other than our colleague the honourable member for Calwell and one of his State colleagues. As reported in the local newspaper, the Keilor Messenger:
Federal MHR Dr Andrew Theophanous welcomed the decision. He said he had sent an immediate telegram to the minister, thanking him on behalf of the local community.
His State colleague, apparently, was similarly quoted as `ecstatic'. To continue:

Both said it would be particularly gratifying to the community of the district and particularly to local Labor Party branches which had been striving for years to have the factory shut and made available for recreation and residential purposes.
Dr Theophanous said that the factory had been seen by many as a potential pollution and safety hazard for people living in the area.
`Closing it will not only remove this risk but will release much needed land for housing, recreation, community services and industrial development'.

It is a pity that his concern for the people of the area does not extend to the work force of that particular factory. It is interesting to note the change in terminology in relation to that factory. We find that the wording relating to what is to happen to the people who are to be retrenched from the factory has changed substantially between the Press release put out by the Minister and the letter subsequently sent to the consultative area committee of the 16 unions who represent employees on that particular site at the Albion explosives factory. I quote from the Minister's Press release of 13 December as follows:

In the period up until the closure in September, there will be intensive and extensive consultation of all those affected and their representatives to ensure that satisfactory alternative employment is available for those who desire it and acceptable termination arrangements are made for those who would prefer redundancy or early retirement.

Subsequent to that, we find the Minister taking a totally different line in the letter that he sent to the consultative area committee, as I said, representing the 16 unions on site. That wording has changed and taken on quite a new and distinct interpretation. I quote from the Minister's letter:

I have given an assurance to the ACTU that every effort will be made to find suitable, alternative employment for AEF personnel. Where such redeployment is not possible, appropriate termination arrangements will be made.

We had a situation where the Minister was undertaking to place people. That situation has now moved to one where he says: `If there is not a job for you, too bad fellows, there is nothing we can do about it'. As I said, it is a pity that both the Ministers and the honourable member for Calwell do not show the same concern for the employees of that Albion explosives factory as they do for the wishes of the left-wing activists in the ALP branches of that particular area.

I also point out that, despite the earnest hope of the honourable member for Calwell to establish, as he hopes, an institute for post-secondary studies on the spot, the Andrew Theophanous Memorial, that is highly unlikely to take place as a re-establishment process is going to take some 10 years. Another most extraordinary feature of this whole exercise is that this Minister for Defence, while of course announcing that he is going to close this particular factory with effect from September of this year, at the same time announces jointly with another Minister of this Government that a community employment program grant is going to be made to the Albion explosives factory to beautify the site. I quote from the Melbourne Herald of last week:
The Federal Government has announced a $98,700 grant to improve the appearance and environment of the Albion Explosives Factory in Deer Park.
The Government hopes the grant, which comes under the Commonwealth Employment Program, will create 10 jobs for a 26 week period.

I suppose those 10 jobs are some compensation for the 200 people who will lose their jobs in the Albion explosives factory. But what a confused government we have. On one hand, the Minister for Defence is closing the factory to take effect from September of this year, yet at the same time, co-jointly with another Minister of this Government, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, he announces a grant to beautify the factory. So we are going to beautify the factory while we are closing it down. I guess that pretty much typifies the general confusion of policy and lack of co-ordination between departments that is going on in this particular Government. What an absolutely paradoxical and ridiculous situation!

I am also aware that there is considerable concern about the alternative site to which eventually the facilities of the Albion explosives factory will be moved. The Minister proposes that over a 10-year period the facility will be re-established at Mulwala near Yarrawonga, in southern New South Wales and northern Victoria respectively. There are several disquieting aspects of that because, as we have seen from the statements made by the honourable member for Calwell, one of the things that concerned him was the aspect of pollution and safety. At Albion over a very long period very good waste disposal programs have been developed that worked very effectively. What waste there is is fed into the Melbourne sewerage system, a very vast sewerage system that can easily cope with that problem. In Mulwala-Yarrawonga we are talking about a town of only 4,500 people with a very limited sewerage system. I know that the Defence Department has had a number of representations from that area expressing grave concern about whether the limited facilities of Mulwala-Yarrawonga, with a population of only 4,000 to 5,000 people, has any hope at all of coping with the waste that will come out of Mulwala on an advanced scale when the facilities presently at Albion are re-established there.

The final area of concern is the loss of expertise of some very skilled professional personnel at Albion. It is, for instance, a fact that one of the key areas they have been working in is the testing of TNT samples. It has taken some 14 years to develop to a high state of art the testing of those particular samples. The professional staff who have developed that now look like being lost, unfortunately, to the Defence Department because many of them will not be prepared to move to the new location, quite apart from the 200 people generally in the factory who have no guarantee as to where they are likely to go in the future.

Summing up, given the general confusion about this whole exercise, including the most extraordinary situation of giving a CEP grant to this factory at the same time as it is being closed down, with the employees having no secure guarantee of where they are to go, I suggest that the Minister needs to look very carefully at exactly what is being done in relation to the closure of this particular factory, and understand perhaps more clearly exactly what he has embarked on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

—I refer the Prime Minister to the advice to his Government from the Joint Economic Forecasting Committee that this year's current account deficit is predicted to be $12 billion. I also refer him to the quarterly balance of payments figures released today which show that, for the first six months of this financial year, the current account deficit has been $7.5 billion. I ask the Prime Minister: In the light of that advice and those figures, does he still maintain as he did on 24 January this year that interest rates would come down and that the right level of the Australian dollar was between US72c and US75c?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As usual-it is a pity it has happened again on this occasion-the Leader of the Opposition cannot get his facts straight. The premises of his question are inaccurate. Let me prove that very quickly. He says that I asserted what the right level of the Australian dollar should be. He is wrong. I will read the transcript so that everyone in this House can see that he is wrong. In the interview with Carlton, I was asked:

ANSWER.PARA: He was talking about the dollar. My reply was:

Well, you ask six economists, you'll probably get six different answers. But I guess the range of opinion, Mike, is of the order of 72 to 75c. I think that would be the sort of order that the majority of economists would say is perhaps the appropriate level. In other words they're saying that when it went down to the 65 and 66 there'd been an overadjustment. But you'll get different answers, as I say, to just precisely what it should be.
For the Leader of the Opposition to say from that that I have asserted that that is the right figure is manifestly absurd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, ha!

—The hyenic laughter that comes from the other side of the table does nothing to dispel the observation that was made this morning by the person the Leader of the Opposition has appointed to the tactics committee. The honourable member for the Northern Territory said:

ANSWER.PARA: that is the Leader of the Opposition-
doesn't seem to be coming across in the media and to the Australian people as a decisive leader.

This stupid laughter will not help the honourable gentleman in that lack of image. I must say that that is one of the more incisive judgments that the honourable member for the Northern Territory has made of late.

On the question of the level of the current account deficit, both the Treasurer and I, as from last November, have indicated that in fact the Budget figures may look as though they were going to be somewhat exceeded. The statistics to which the Leader of the Opposition refers confirm the indication that the Treasurer and I made. Let me say this quite clearly: As far as the Government is concerned, we assert that the economic fundamentals of policy making in this country are right and will continue to deliver to this country the economic and the employment growth which has put the performance of this country so far ahead of anywhere in the rest of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister inform the House of the latest labour force statistics and indicate whether they are consistent with the Government's long term economic strategies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would hope that all people in this House, irrespective of on which side of the House they sit, will join with me in welcoming the employment figures that were released this morning. The preliminary labour force statistics for January issued by the Australian Statistician this morning indicate that employment rose in January by over 60,000-60,200. That large increase in employment, I believe, is most encouraging. It means now, of course, that the increase in employment since April 1983 is 608,300. And we have these people on the other side of the House complaining about economic policy making! That means that so far this financial year employment has grown by 3.4 per cent compared with a Budget forecast of 2 3/4 per cent for 1985-86 as a whole. The latest figures, therefore, point to an employment growth in 1985-86 of the order of 3 1/2 per cent, a result which everyone can see is consistent with very strong economic growth in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is also important to note that the bulk of this very strong employment growth continues to be in the area of full time employment with strong increases in both male and female full time employment. It is interesting to note that the participation rate has returned to the near record level of 61.6 per cent. Despite that strong increase in the participation rate, the unemployment rate has remained steady at 7.8 per cent which compares with the 10.2 per cent that we inherited from these economic geniuses on the other side. It is quite clear that there have been very substantial improvements in the employment situation which now exceeds by more than 20 per cent the promise I made to the people of Australia on behalf of the Australian Labor Party in the beginning of 1983 that we would deliver half a million new jobs in three years. We have now exceeded that by more than 20 per cent in less than that period.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. Where a husband and wife partnership own a farm and, in accordance with a long standing tradition, they bring a family member into the partnership, will the new partnership have acquired the family farm for capital gains tax purposes? Does this mean that a farm that has been in a family for many years before 19 September of last year will therefore be subjected to capital gains tax simply because a son or daughter is introduced into the family partnership?

—I have no intention of offering tax advice to the honourable member. The honourable member asked me a question the other day which went to basic tax principles which, of course, I referred to the Commissioner of Taxation and on which I will be furnishing him a reply. I am not about to satisfy some of the germination of tax schemes which will obviously hatch around on the honourable member's side of politics. If the honourable member wants advice on technical questions involving the change of tax status of taxpayers in tax arrangements, let him put them on notice and I will give him a reply.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. Is the Minister aware of the proposed new fee scales circulated by the Australian Association of Surgeons to its 1,600 members last week? Is it a fact, as reported, that the Association is recommending that surgeons charge up to nine times more than the present schedule fee? Can the Minister give any possible justification for such astronomic increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to those massive increases in fees. I can only say that they seem to have been made without any consideration of the welfare of the patients themselves. If those massive increases were adopted generally by surgeons there would be very heavy out of pocket payments by patients. Although surgeons are quite free to charge what they wish in this country, patients, of course, are only paid benefits on the basis of fees set by an independent arbitral inquiry. Therefore, if these fee recommendations were followed through there would be very heavy out of pocket bills to be paid by individual patients.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government has demanded of the whole community wage restraint. I find it extraordinarily difficult to understand that this particular group seems to take no notice whatsoever of these wage restraint guidelines. Nobody has ever argued that the medical profession--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, here are their defenders, the people who are willing to support these outrageous claims, yet are not prepared to listen to any justified union demand. Nobody has ever argued in this country that the medical profession as a whole is somehow a disadvantaged group which needs special augmentation under the wage fixing guidelines. Everyone recognises that the surgeons themselves are a peculiarly advantaged group within the medical profession itself. The 1985 fees inquiry, in which the Australian Association of Surgeons participated, determined that surgeons should not increase their fees by any more than 3.5 per cent. This current action is a complete disregard of that arbiter's decision. Ordinary workers must simply stand back in amazement when a profession for which an independent arbitrator sets what is regarded as an appropriate fee schedule, a schedule accepted by the Government, goes ahead and decides to charge above schedule fee and still have the bulk of that fee underwritten by the taxpayer. What I would do is to call on surgeons in this country not to follow through those outrageous recommendations. I also ask patients who are compelled to suffer heavy out of pocket fees because of this to let us know so that we can at least publicise the way these people behave.

—Has the Minister for Primary Industry alerted his ministerial colleagues, in the context of the present consideration of the application of fuel excise, to figures that flow from the submission by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to the Industries Assistance Commission inquiry into petrol taxation which shows that if the Government passes on the full 7c drop in the fuel price an average wheat farmer would save $1,680 in a full year, an average cane grower $1,100, an average wheat-sheep-beef producer $1,570, and an average trawler operator $4,400? Will the Minister acknowledge, especially in the current rural crisis, that these figures demonstrate the absolute necessity of passing on in full the fall in the price of crude oil?

—My colleagues and I are very well informed by the BAE. I, as Minister responsible for the BAE, strongly stand up for its independence. It has made a submission to the IAC with respect to a reference before that body. Of course, we are very well informed. We are aware of those figures. All other departments concerned with this issue are putting forward submissions. All those matters will be taken into account. We can read.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Health. I refer to this Government's ongoing commitment to and commendable policy of constantly reviewing the adequacy and effectiveness of delivering Commonwealth services in rural and non-metropolitan areas. With specific reference to Medicare offices and agencies, what action is being taken to expand the Medicare services in country areas? Will the introduction of an Australia Card have any effect on the provision of Medicare services? Finally, has consideration been given to the use of toll free phone calls to supplement Medicare services in non-metropolitan areas?

—Let me point first of all to the ability of the Health Insurance Commission to provide a very fast turnaround postal service; secondly, the use made, particularly by many country people, of the pay doctor cheque system; thirdly, and the welcome further increases in bulk billing. All this means that many pressures on Medicare offices in those areas are reduced. However, we do maintain a constant review of the network of Medicare offices across the country and where there are justified needs for further offices they will be established. Since the original network was established there have been a number of additions to Medicare offices in provincial centres. As the honourable member for Capricornia mentioned, if the Parliament accepts the Australia Card proposition-which, of course, would be operated through the Health Insurance Commission-there would have to be an expansion of the Medicare network. On present planning there would need to be some further 24 offices in provincial and country centres. On his last point, we have looked at issues in relation to toll free telephone numbers. They usually have been used by government in explaining a new program rather than in providing a continuing service with an existing program. I will certainly take the suggestion made by the honourable member to the Health Insurance Commission for consideration in improving what are already its excellent services.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister and it relates to the Belconnen Mall affair. Will the Prime Minister deny that in the draft sale contract forming part of the tender documents the total value of depreciable plant and equipment aggregated $4,003,327, but that surprisingly in the executed sale contract this figure rocketed to nearly $9m, thereby bestowing on the lucky purchasers a windfall tax benefit well in excess of $2m by allowing them to claim an extra $5m for depreciation? Will the Prime Minister now immediately table in this Parliament the executed sale agreement for the Belconnen Mall?

—As the United States of America does on another matter which is well known, I will neither confirm nor deny something of which I have no knowledge. The particular details to which the honourable member refers in his question are not within my knowledge. Let me say two things which are relevant to his question, however. It is appropriate that I repeat again the processes that were followed in this matter. With the probable exception, I guess, of the honourable member who has asked this question, no one in this House would have any doubt as to the propriety of this matter. Nevertheless-
—Wrong again.

—All right; honourable members can identify themselves. That suits me fine. If honourable members opposite want to be identified with this fellow in this sort of approach, it suits me fine. If the honourable member for Ryan is one of them, very good. Let me say two things which are relevant. First of all, for the benefit of the honourable member for Denison, in the hope that it may finally get through his thick skull, I will repeat what the processes were. As I said to this House yesterday, the tendering process for the sale of the Mall was determined by an interdepartmental committee established for that purpose after reference to the general tendering procedures laid down by the Purchasing and Disposal Division of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services. The tendering process was then supervised by the interdepartmental committee in accordance with the procedures it had laid down. The final decision on the tender was taken by Cabinet on the unanimous recommendation of the interdepartmental committee. Secondly, I will inquire as to whether, given the confidentiality which normally attaches to this matter, it can appropriately be tabled. As far as I am concerned, if within the procedures that are normally followed it is appropriate to do that, I am more than happy to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science. In view of the considerable public criticism of the Bureau of Meteorology over the monitoring of the movement of tropical cyclone Winifred, will the Minister take immediate steps to establish a tropical cyclone warning centre in Townsville?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Herbert for his concerned question, which affects his electorate. While a tropical cyclone warning centre at Townsville would provide moral reassurance for people in the local area, it would make no significant contribution to improving the accuracy or time limits of cyclone warnings, particularly for areas distant from Townsville. A second warning centre in Townsville would require duplication of the specialist meteorological staff and facilities located in Brisbane. Such a centre would be more vulnerable to destruction and total or partial loss of forecasting ability and communications during a cyclone threat to Townsville. I believe that resources and effort would be better directed to improving the existing cyclone warning system-better observations, communications, and improved facilities and staffing of the Brisbane Tropical Cyclone Warning Centre.

ANSWER.PARA: There has been criticism, for example by the honourable member for Ryan-it has been the greatest resurrection since Lazarus in his case-that this Government and the Bureau of Meteorology are insensitive to the need of people in north Queensland for accurate, timely cyclone advice. Let me reassure the honourable members for Herbert, Capricornia, Leichhardt and Kennedy and their constituents that this is not the case. Last month I opened a new meteorological observing station with weather radar at Gove in the Northern Territory. A new weather radar has been installed at Karratha in Western Australia through the co-operation and assistance of the mining companies. A new weather-watch radar is planned for Weipa in Queensland, together with the placement of the wind-finding and weather-watch radars at Cairns. Obsolete wind-finding radars at Townsville and Charleville have been replaced.

A Darwin receiving station, linked to the Brisbane regional forecasting centre, has been established to receive data from the Japanese geostationary meteorological satellite covering all northern Australia. Telephone recorded announcement systems have been established at Townsville, Cairns and Rockhampton. We are doing everything possible to upgrade the cyclone weather-watch service.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is still an hour and a half's delay.

—Unlike the Fraser Government, of which the honourable member for Ryan was an ornament, which budgeted only $1m a year for re-equipping the Bureau, the Hawke Government has provided $3.5m for the Bureau's capital re-equipment program in each of the last two years.

—May I offer my congratulations, Madam Speaker. I hope that your stay in the chair will be very fruitful. That is the reason I gave you the apple yesterday. My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is he aware that most low income families derive most enjoyment from the use of the family car, even if it be the most inexpensive available? Will the Prime Minister give an assurance that his Government will reduce the price of petrol to the ordinary families of Australia, not just the farmers, who instead of benefiting from his Government's policies are paying through the nose at the petrol pump?

—I accept the sincerity of the honourable member in putting his question. I just say that it is a pity that in the period in which he was a member of the previous Government he was not associated with doing much more for the ordinary families of this country and was part of a government which presided over the disintegration of prospects for so many low income families in this country. I assure him that we will be taking all these matters into account when we make our decision. I am sure that it will be a decision which will be greeted with approval by the people of Australia as a whole.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS INTERNATIONAL YEAR OF PEACE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the fact that this is the United Nations International Year of Peace. Can the Minister advise the House of Australia's program of involvement in this United Nations International Year of Peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —A budget of $3m has been set aside for the total programs which are associated with the International Year of Peace, which is a United Nations program, and 1986 is the International Year of Peace. In this financial year an amount in excess of $2m has been allocated in support of the promotion of the International Year of Peace. Some of that money is being provided for the production of educative materials, including a video for schools and other interested bodies. Some is being provided for works which will promote the cause of peace. For instance, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is conducting research into theories related to the nuclear winter, the concept that the Southern Hemisphere would be as devastated as the Northern Hemisphere in the event of a major nuclear attack because of the toxic fallout and the environmental disintegration which would take place in this part of the world as much as in the Northern Hemisphere.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of the money is being provided for the purposes of promoting community involvement. In this financial year $500,000 has been provided for that purpose. Of that amount, $200,000 will be allocated for grants to national projects and $300,000 for State and Territory grants. A fairly wide range of community initiatives are being supported. An advisory council has been set up at the State and national level to assess applications which have been made. An amount of $200,000 has been provided by the Government to the Australia Council in 1985-86 to fund involvement in the IYP by visual and performing artists. A completely separate function has been a recently taped what I might describe as television spectacular involving the honourable member for Warringah and myself. It is a Hypotheticals program which will go to air at some time in the near future. It involves a fairly wide panel of people who are concerned about this issue and an extensive range of views are put forward. I have the uneasy feeling that members on my side of the House will applaud the performance of the honourable member for Warringah and members on the other side of the House may well applaud my performance, in which case neither he nor I will have promoted our own ambitions greatly. Nonetheless, we went about the task with great commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, may your term in the honourable position of Speaker be a long and rosy one. I ask the Treasurer a question concerning the disastrous state of the Australian economy and in particular the trade balance. I wish to know in Australian dollar terms, exactly, what amount the Treasurer is paying Queensland Mines Ltd not to export uranium from Nabarlek in the Northern Territory, thus making our balance of payments situation that much worse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are seeing at the moment in the Australian economy is the substantial change and rebalancing of the economy from an almost exclusive reliance upon the primary export sector to a situation in which it resembles once again a modern, sophisticated industrial economy. The industrial wasteland which emerged from the years of coalition rule, with the absence of a wages policy, the overvaluation of the exchange rate and the erratic application of monetary policy, has done nothing other than destroy our manufacturing structure, leave us totally susceptible to imports, see the country hooked on imports through the 1970s, and now see the terms of trade declining in the primary export sector, not only--

—I rise on a point of order. I refer you, Madam Speaker, to the Standing Orders, particularly chapter 11 on questions seeking information. I referred yesterday to standing orders 142 and 145. I submit to you that the Treasurer's answer to the question is not relevant. The honourable member for Maranoa asked a question about Queensland Mines Ltd and the Treasurer has not mentioned Queensland Mines Ltd once yet in his answer. I ask for your ruling.
—I suggest to the honourable member for Higgins that the question of relevancy is sometimes a matter of opinion. I presume that the Treasurer is getting to his answer in his own way.
—The honourable member for Maranoa inquired about the balance of payments and the state of the Australian economy.

—Order! Will honourable members on the front bench on my left remain silent. They will heed the Chair. I draw their attention to standing order 303. Like the honourable member for Higgins, I have been reading the Standing Orders. Perhaps the Opposition front bench members would all like to read clause (e) of standing order 303.

—Not only was the Government left a disastrous fiscal inheritance by the former Government, with the economy in negative growth for the first time in 30 years, but also we were left a disastrous trade position. Indeed, the current account deficit in 1981-82, in the days of the former Treasurer, was 6 per cent of gross domestic product. The question relates to the balance of payments in the current account. What we are seeing now, by the floating of the exchange rate and the fall in the value of the Australian dollar, is the chance to put the Australian economy on its most competitive path in 20 years, to see a resurgence and renaissance in Australian secondary industry and structure and to see the Australian secondary structure again emerging as a sophisticated player in the import-export competing scene. The result will be that over time we will end up with the kind of economy that we should have always had.

ANSWER.PARA: I might just add that the question was prefaced by comments about the `disastrous Australian economy'. The so-called `disastrous Australian economy' has now delivered nearly 5 per cent of economic growth on average for three years, has provided employment for--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Speaker: I am concerned that the Treasurer does not seem to have very good hearing--
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

—Not only have we had three years of strong non-farm growth in the economy at 5 per cent, but we have had 9 per cent employment growth, a re-establishment of investment in industry and, of course, unemployment declining from 10 1/2 per cent to just under 8 per cent--
—I have a point of order, Madam Speaker. It is obvious that the Treasurer has not heard the question because--
—Order! The Treasurer heard the question; I heard the question. In his preface, the honourable member for Maranoa referred to the Australian economy. The Treasurer is being quite relevant.

—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: You have just ruled on the basis of the preface to the question. Had the Treasurer referred to the preface in his answer, that would have been within the meaning of relevance within the Standing Orders. It is fundamental that, for an answer to be relevant, it must go to the centrepiece or the substantial nature of the question--
—Order! The Treasurer has gone to both the centrepiece and the introduction. There is no point of order.

—I do not think I need to say more about the relative state of the Australian economy. That has been lauded by every international forecasting group, by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, by the International Monetary Fund, by the Conference Board in New York and by almost every respected international commentator. If honourable members opposite want to deny that, they are simply denying facts.

ANSWER.PARA: Perhaps I could use this opportunity on the balance of payments question to make this point: On the question earlier about the balance of payments, in the revision of the six-monthly figures issued today by the Australian Statistician it is shown that import value increased in the six months to December and this was due heavily to investment goods. In the six months to December, despite increased retail sales the value of imported consumer goods has remained unchanged. This is true of both quarters, indicating both that the volume of consumer imports is likely to have fallen and in consequence that the depreciation of the dollar was beginning to bite. By contrast, there has been a strong increase in imported investment goods over the six months, again in both quarters. The Statistician has noted that about three-quarters of the December quarter endogenous import increase was in investment goods, and the same applied to virtually the whole of the September quarter increase. This is a reflection of the strong investment recovery that is under way, which in itself is a product of the new competitiveness of Australian industry both in Australia and overseas.

In referring to the Statistician's Bulletin issued today, I note that he says that the 8 per cent fall in seasonally adjusted exogenous imports largely reflected the fall in imports of fuels; seasonally adjusted endogenous imports rose 9 per cent, with about three-quarters of this rise attributable to investment goods; and consumption goods showed little change from the previous quarter. This simply confirms what the Government has been saying about the change which is taking place in the underlying balance of payments and it damns as economically illiterate the interpretations by Opposition members about L-curves, their failure to understand the operation of the market, their denial that a 25 per cent depreciation in the exchange rate will change the balance of payments and their total failure to comprehend the fundamental and important changes that are taking place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also is directed to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the proposal by the present Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia to legislate in that State to allow income splitting for taxation purposes. Can the Treasurer inform the House which government would bear the financial impact of this policy? What is the Government's response to it?

—I made it clear in the election campaign that the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia was proposing a set of illegal arrangements for issues of policy over which he would have had no control as Premier. The whole proposal was a farce and a hoax on the Western Australian public.

—My congratulations to you, Madam Speaker, on assuming your new office. My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Can the Minister confirm that the report on fraud against the Commonwealth, commissioned following the Review of Australian Federal Police Resources, details precisely the $300m per annum that is lost through social security fraud and the fact that 1,000 new fraud cases are being perpetrated each week against the Government, which is now proposing amnesty, albeit the reduced amnesty operating from today? How does the Minister reconcile the report with recent statements made by the Minister for Social Security suggesting that social security fraud is not a serious problem? Will he table the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Firstly let me say that the report that I had put together in my Department came on top of an earlier report which I requisitioned from both the Australian Federal Police and my Department about police resources in Australia and which has already been made public. According to the report done mutually by those two departments, an extra 1,400 AFP people would be required to overcome all of the problems we are facing in Australia. Breaking that down, it showed--
—I am talking about the report that followed.
—I ask the honourable member to be quiet for a minute. He has been away for a few months.
—The honourable member has asked his question.
—It showed that something like--
—Stop avoiding the question.

—What is the Opposition's tactics committee doing? The only people left unemployed in Australia must be the people on the Opposition's tactics committee. Fair dinkum. I ask honourable members whether they have even seen a Question Time like this.
—How are we going for relevance now?

—Honourable members opposite talk about the economy, interest rates, petrol and what is going to happen and they have Boofhead asking about the Belconnen Mall. So much for the great national issues. I ask honourable members to let me finish and I will tell them what happened.
—Stop avoiding the question.
—The honourable member for Bruce will be quiet.

—Bring back Andrew, for God's sake! Honourable members opposite are eventually getting back to his policies. It reminds me of the old American dance, the hokey-pokey; you put your left foot in, you take your left foot out; you put your left foot in and you shake it all about.
—How are we going for relevance now?

—Honourable members opposite do not know which policy to follow. They do not know whether to follow the Liberal policy in Tasmania, the Liberal policy in Victoria or the Liberal policy in South Australia.
—Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is the fifth answer that has not been relevant. The Ministers really must come back to being relevant.
—I am sure the Special Minister of State is intending to do that.
—If you mob want to interject all the time we will give you a bit of curry about it.
—Don't you start that.
—If you want to bust up Question Time you can. It is your Question Time.
—You will get a few more quorums.

—I am trying to answer questions sensibly. I am not going to put up with your hocus-pocus. We can read your tactics from over here. You want to upset the Parliament because you have got nothing to ask. You bunch of boofheads.
—Order! The House will come to order. I now ask the Special Minister of State to answer the question.

—Madam Speaker, I was answering the question and giving the details to the honourable member when honourable members opposite started interjecting. Even though they ask questions and want the information they want to abandon Question Time.
—Get on with it.

—Honourable members opposite do not seem to have any rhyme or reason to their questions. The report said that we needed an additional 1,400 members of the Australian Federal Police to overcome all the problems with which we were confronted. I looked at the report and spoke to the people who had prepared it. A number of those people required by the Australian Federal Police were required to deal with the problems of drugs in this country. Honourable members will know from the priorities tabled in this Parliament late last year that the Australian--
—I am not talking about that. I am talking about fraud.
—The honourable member for Bruce is out of order. If he interjects again I will name him.
—Honourable members will know from the priorities set by this Government that drugs are the No. 1 priority set for the Australian Police.
—That is not the question.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I name the honourable member for Bruce.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the honourable member for Bruce be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bruce is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for Bruce thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Special Minister of State to complete his answer to the question.
—What are you hiding?
—What am I hiding?
—Yes, I would like to know.

—The right honourable member for New England wants to know what I am hiding. It is said that he was at the Tamworth country and western music festival singing his latest song entitled Do They Have Cheque Books in Heaven.

ANSWER.PARA: I did ask for a report on the question of fraud, because I was looking at the resources of the Australian Federal Police. I can tell honourable members that that inquiry disclosed what the Minister for Social Security has been saying. The big problem of fraud in this country lies not with payments from the Government but with payments to the Government. According to the people who prepared my report, over 99 per cent of people say that the fraud applies to that area of government and not to overpayments. The Federal Police do deal with all serious questions of fraud relating to overpayments. The actions that have been taken by the Minister for Social Security are commendable and have the support of every decent-thinking Australian.
