—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time (b) Call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal members of Parliament and senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as is duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Robert Brown and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth: Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not `windfall gains', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement.

Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Fife.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that `the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Milton and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains Tax
Hidden Death Tax described as ``Capital Gains Tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company Tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately reject these tax proposals. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. The Federal Labor Government's retirement income policies are piecemeal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirement;
2. The Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
1. Scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. Either institute a broad inquiry into Australia's income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and,
3. Following the report of such a wide inquiry institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornography
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that your petitioners are greatly concerned at:
(a) The ready availability of X-rated video and other pornographic material; and
(b) The increased tendency to highlight as many forms of sexual activity in the media without regard to the susceptibilities of the general public; and
as a consequence, Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should take action to:
1. Prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography and grossly obscene publications.

2. Require the censorship authority to more appropriately reflect responsible community attitudes in determining classification and suitability of films and videos to be shown to Australian audiences; and
3. Ensure greater propriety in television productions, local and overseas, telecast to Australian audiences.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Marine Band Radio Licence Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, Parliament House, Canberra, ACT 2600.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

That we, the undersigned, are greatly concerned by, and totally opposed to, paying a licence fee to operate a marine band radio which is carried in any craft, and which may be relied upon to summon assistance in emergency situations.
We wish you to rescind the Regulation under the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1905, which prescribes this fee.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Commonwealth Government of Australia will protect us from payment of this fee, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Dairy Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the introduction of the Kerin Plan for the Australian Dairy industry which would destroy the livelihood of many thousands of dairy farmers.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will reject the Kerin Dairy Plan.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth: We deplore the tax threshold of $5100, as the proposal adversely affects welfare recipients and low income earners. We urge that the figure be $7500 to enable these citizens to have some chance to live with dignity.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescribed Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petitions of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth;
That the Federal Government's report recommending aged pensioners pay for prescribed drugs be not acted upon.
The aged are more likely to be using prescribed drugs than others and this outrageous suggestion will only deprive the aged pensioners of money they need for living expenses.
Due to any increase in cost of prescribed drugs, pensioners may not be able to have prescriptions filled.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that no action be taken by the Government on this matter and that free drugs remain available to the aged.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Exports of Live Sheep
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that: According to the Senate Select Committee report 1 million sheep have died during export to the Middle East in the last 5 years. At least 2 per cent die on each voyage, in addition to the large numbers which may die as a result of particularly adverse conditions, for example 40,000 due to fire, 15,000 due to cold at Portland and 15,000 recently due to humidity near Jedda. Beyond the mortality figures, all sheep endure the stress of the voyage and the cruelty of halal slaughter (which has recently been banned in Britain).
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should accept the findings of the Senate Select Committee. In particular:
1. to phase out the live sheep export trade over 5 years and to substitute for it a refrigerated sheepmeat trade,
2. in the interim, to give the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service responsibility for the welfare of export sheep in Australia, including the power to stop abuses,
3. in the interim, to implement the Senate Select Committee's recommendations regarding the improvement of current conditions and husbandry practiced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tropical Rainforests, Northern Queensland
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That consistent with our Christian faith, being concerned for the natural environment and the responsible and nurturing use rather than exploitation of the earths resources ask that the Wet Tropical Rainforests of North Queensland because of their rare, ancient and irreplaceable nature be protected for the long term benefit of mankind.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
(1) Immediately nominate the region for the World Heritage List and protection under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.
(2) Give full support to the implementations of the recommendations of the Commonwealth Working Group on Rain Forest Conservation including the full funding proposed by Mr Cohen for the program.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paterson's Curse
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Your Honourable House (the Government) act to implement the biological control of Paterson's Curse.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and the honourable members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned electors of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Services in Illawarra Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to force, at the expense of viewers, the transfer of WIN TV (and any future local broadcaster) from VHF to UHF transmission, while excluding Sydney metropolitan T.V. stations from this requirement, has placed in jeopardy the future of the Illawarra and South Coast region's only local commercial T.V. operator.

Your petitioners request the House of Representatives to protect the interests of the hundreds of thousands of television viewers within the area from Wollongong to the Victorian border served by WIN TV, by preventing the government from taking this unwarranted and discriminatory action which disadvantages both viewers and advertisers on the South Coast to the benefit of the metropolitan networks.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (ie, set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of ABC listeners and viewers showeth that the autonomy and non-commercial independent broadcasting services of the ABC is in jeopardy because the ABC is currently having to bear additional costs involved in the AUSSAT satellite operation.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that:

1. The Government restores $20 million to the ABC's budget for 1985-86 to ensure that the services the ABC provides the Australian public are maintained and improved, particularly in terms of educational and rural programs, and that ABC staff are not needlessly retrenched.

2. The Government will not introduce corporate sponsorship or any form of advertising into the ABC since this would destroy the independence and autonomy of the ABC. The non-commercial independent broadcasting service provided by the ABC is fundamental to Australian democracy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that: Your petitioners pray that Your Honourable House will reject the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for the following reasons:

1. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and its implementation will result in attacks on the Christian church and the promotion of a State religion based on secular humanism;
2. That there is no need for legislation of this kind since the principles of freedom are already enshrined in Common Law and that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve;

3. That there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of which do not share a common heritage and do not practice many of the principles that they have covenanted to uphold;

4. The methods being used to introduce this legislation are secretive and a blatant misuse of the external affairs powers under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution and that furthermore are contrary to the spirit of the Constitution;

5. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Student Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the assembled parliament.
The humble petition of concerned members of the Swinburne Student Union in the electorate of Kooyong, respectfully pray:
That the levying of Overseas Student Charge for all Overseas students is a form of academic fees and should be abolished;
That the quota system for overseas students be abolished to increase the rate of participation and equality of opportunity in education for all people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Peel Barracks: Tamworth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

We, the undersigned, citizens of the City of Tamworth, and surrounding region in the State of New South Wales, hereby humbly pray that the Federal Government release that part of the premises known as the `Peel Barracks', Cnr Peel and Darling Streets, Tamworth as would be sufficient to allow the citizens of Tamworth and the surrounding region to establish a Community Centre incorporating an Army Museum and an activities co-operative.
We, the undersigned, hereby humbly pray that the Federal Government views such a release as a Bicentenary Gift to the people of the said region.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Gains Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limit the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right of Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundament requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade union.

5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fisher respectfully showeth:
That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's `White Paper' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital gains tax,
Hidden death tax described as `capital gains tax after death',
Gift tax,
Increased company tax,
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

The total disallowance by the Hawke Labor Government of tax deductibility for entertainment and hospitality expenses will unfairly penalise Australian business and cost thousands of jobs for young and unskilled people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Abandon its total ban on entertainment expenses and allow tax deductibility for legitimate and necessary expenses.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;

And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's discrimination against rural Australians and its failure to adopt policies to reduce the crippling impact of the financial crisis facing farmers.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The cost-price squeeze facing farmers in rural communities has intensified into a major crisis since this Government came to office in March 1983. World prices for many of our commodities have fallen. With the bulging subsidised surpluses in the European Economic Community and in the United States of America and with the prospects of a trade war, prices are likely to fall further. But that is only half of the story. The Hawke Labor Government has systematically discriminated against rural Australians. It has ripped $442m from the farmers and $648m from rural communities in general in its Budgets and mini-Budgets. The Forward Estimates indicate that the Department of Primary Industry's budget will be cut by a further 12.5 per cent in 1986-87, so Labor's axe is poised again. Needless to say, only one other department will be treated as severely, and that is the Department of Trade, at a time when our balance of trade is deteriorating month by month. The two departments which are fundamental to our export earnings, to our major export industry, agriculture, have been singled out again by the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is bankrupting Australia in an even more spectacular fashion than the Whitlam Government ever did. It is discriminating against the farmers of Australia in an even more cruel fashion than the Whitlam Government ever did. Time and again the Government's economic decisions have accelerated the transfer of resources from country Australians to other sectors when the rural sector can least afford it. Farmers and small business operators are shouldering a disproportionate burden of the monetary policy of pushing interest rates to record levels to stop the dollar falling to its real level. The banks have estimated that the Government's monetary policy is adding 6 to 7 per cent to interest rates, forcing them up in some instances to 23 per cent to maintain the dollar above its real level.

The Government boasts that it has freed up the financial system. Nothing could be further from the truth. This dirty float is protecting Labor's accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The farm and small business sectors are footing a huge share of the bill. Yet the exchange rate has now fallen to its lowest trade weighted level ever, in spite of the monetary policy protection given the accord. It is an unmitigated disaster. World fuel prices have fallen and consumers in every Western country except Australia are receiving the full benefits of the fall in those prices. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) refuses to tell this Parliament whether he will abide by import parity pricing now that the change favours the consumers-the biggest per capita users, of course, being the farmers and the fishing industry. I warn the Government that if it does not return the full benefit of the fuel price drop to them it will incite a rural revolt.

The tax reform package of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has torn at the heart of rural land values and rural and small business incomes. The ultimate madness of these actions is that all Australians will suffer in the years to come. How can Australians repay a foreign debt which has more than doubled in two years-it is probably close to $80 billion, with interest payments the third largest item in the Federal Budget-if our major export industries are bled dry? This Government is destroying the ability of this nation to repay those debts.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Government's advisory body, has been warning the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) of what is happening to the country regions: The Bureau, at its recent Outlook Conference, gave a further grim warning to the Government. While the ACTU is demanding a retrospective wage rise across the board, average farm incomes this year will slide to 18 per cent of the average wage. Wheat and other crop growers will suffer a minus 10 per cent average real rate of return to their capital. The real rate of return to farm capital generally is estimated at minus 6.2 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Minus 6.2 per cent. The Minister, in defending the Government's damaging monetary, wages, fiscal and tax policies, suggests that average figures do not paint a true picture of the rural crisis. The Government has tried to blame world commodity prices. It seeks to ignore the domestic costs. Now it has removed the departmental head. It is outrageous that the Government has made the Secretary of the Department of Primary Industry, Mr Duthie, a scapegoat for the failure of Labor's rural policy. The Prime Minister barely disguised his attack on one of Australia's most senior and highly respected public servants by stating that this change would mean greater efficiency. The Government must stop making scapegoats. If any- one is to blame it is the Minister, who has failed to kick a goal for the farmers of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I return to the most outrageous action the Government has yet taken in deferring a decision on a full flow-on of the benefits from falling world oil prices. Farmers and fuel users begrudgingly accepted the import parity pricing policy because of the explosion in world oil prices in the 1970s. Yet today the import parity price is $US28 a barrel while the actual spot prices have crashed to as low as $US15. In Europe a fortnight ago some were predicting a fuel price drop of between $10 and $15 a barrel. Since November the retail price of fuel in West Germany, for example, has come down by 10c a litre. How can the farmers of this nation compete with farmers whose exports are subsidised, with fuel prices that are reflecting a fall in world oil prices and yet the flow-on has not occurred in this country? Today the Government's rural members of parliament have stated, according to the media, that there should be no special consideration for farmers even though a full flow-on of the fuel price cut is unlikely. May the people of the rural areas of Australia not forget this Government because it has let them down. Our farmers are amongst the hardest hit fuel users in the Western world.

The Prime Minister is on public record as having said that some fuel price cut can be expected-we were told about 3c a litre in a leaked report last night. The denial of the full benefit to farmers will come as a cruel blow on top of all the other discriminatory actions of the Government. Wheat growers using an average of 24,000 litres of fuel a year would save $1,680 in a year from a 7c a litre price cut, a saving of $1,680 when their average income this year will be minus $3,700. Struggling sugar growers would reduce their average income loss of $13,000 by $1,100, but they are not likely to receive the benefit of the flow-on. The Government has provoked an unprecedented anger amongst farmers, anger that could lead to serious civil disorder. Honourable members should not underestimate it.

The Western Australian election result has forced the Minister to prepare a policy review paper for Cabinet later this month. The Opposition calls for positive and urgent measures to restore the resources that have been ripped away from farmers. It is outrageous that the Minister is running around inferring that there needs to be a shake-out of farmers as a solution. The truth of the matter is that with the quarantining of farm losses and with a capital gains tax hardly a farm in my district that has been put up for sale has been sold. The government has locked the people in to their difficulties.

There are ways and means of this Government coming to the aid of the farm sector of Australia. I believe that the Government should acknowledge the advice that it has received from the Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Dr Stoeckel, who has been bold enough to go public on a range of measures that should be implemented to try to overcome these problems. I will quote from Nigel Austin's article in the Bulletin of last week. He stated:

The blueprint encompasses savings to the rural sector of hundreds of millions of dollars. Included are savings on fuel-$140m annually; a reasonable reduction in tariffs-$150m; savings in transport and handling-$150m initially; and bounties on chemicals-$20m.

They are realistic proposals, but it is extraordinary that the Director of the BAE is giving up and having to go public to get his message across. Dr Stoeckel stresses the critical importance of adjustment taking place at a proper speed. How on earth can it take place with a quarantining of farm losses that we expect to see in operation with a capital gains tax? The Government's economic and anti-farm policies are threatening the family farm and the vital export industries and, in the long run, the standards of living of all Australians. Honourable members should not forget it. Throughout last year I warned the Government of the need for a series of actions to avert a national crisis. I submit a 14-point plan which the Government could implement to avert a serious disaster: Pass on immediately the full benefits of the lower oil prices to the community, including embattled farm, fishing and timber industries; the abolition of fuel price indexation; the removal of sales taxes on fuel and lubricants used on farms and fisheries; the restoration of a more equitable fuel freight equalisation scheme, which the Government has gutted; scrap the Government's quarantine farm losses proposal and the capital gains and fringe benefits taxes on the farm sector; back off the 3 per cent productivity superannuation deal which neither the farmers nor small business will tolerate. If ever there was proof that the centralised wage system is inequitable, this general productivity proposal is proof.

The Government could also implement greater flexibility on wages policy to take account of industry and capacity to pay; change the economic strategy to ease interest rates; implement a clean float of the Australian dollar and not the dirty float that we have got at present; an immediate injection of substantial additional funds for debt adjustment carry-on purposes and reconstruction; the replacement of tariffs on agricultural chemicals, farm machinery and parts with bounties; the abolition of export inspection charges which this Government has increased by 200 per cent to produce the steady predictable cuts for tariff protection and the restoration of the tax benefits of the income equalisation deposits scheme which the Government has gutted in its first year of office. How can the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) sit there in comfort knowing that that was done? On the subject of trade, the Government should launch a major assault on world markets and, in particular, lead the fight in the new round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to have agriculture brought under the rules of GATT.

The Government's response to the fall in world fuel prices will test the real attitude of this Government. Unless there is an immediate change of approach our farm industries will suffer on a scale not seen since the 1930s depression. This year Australia's relatively few farm businesses, about 170,000 in all, will set in train a production cycle worth $15.5 billion to the Australian community. It is an income of great significance to Australians, but the farmers will receive only a 7 per cent share. I do not think it is understood by the Australian people generally how important agricultural exports are to this nation. A total of 70 per cent of its products are exported overseas and very few imports are required to produce them. The viability of the farm sector remains of vital importance to all Australians. If the Government lets them down it will let all Australians down. Farmers are simply asking the Government to get off their backs. They simply ask for what has been taken away and to ease the burden of government imposts at a time of difficult overseas marketing conditions. Mark my words, Mr Minister: Watch out, if you do not do the right thing by them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do they hate farmers?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Before the Minister begins, let me say that if the honourable member for Maranoa interjects again he will be warned.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I must say I am a bit struck dumb by the fact that I have hardly uttered a word since I have been in here.
—The honourable member for Maranoa shall not test the Chair. That is not a point of order. If he does that again he will be named as well.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. For your guidance, it was I who committed that mortal sin.
—The honourable member for Groom may be willing to confess to another sin. However, I saw the honourable member for Maranoa interjecting.
—With respect, I interjected.
—If the honourable member for Groom also wishes to confess, I will warn him at a later date as well.

—I thank the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) for the moderation in his comments. This is far too serious a debate to trivialise it with point scoring at a political level. It is a pity some of his back bench also did not take this debate as seriously as he obviously did. Before I answer the points raised by the honourable member in his speech, point by point, I would simply like to take him on, first of all, in terms of what he alleges is the discrimination against rural Australians.
—It is true. You hate farmers; you hate Tasmanians.
—This Government does not discriminate against any Australian. The thrust of our activities is and will remain to govern fairly for all Australians.
—Disgraceful!

—We do not have the word `hate' in our vocabulary like you do, you fool. We acknowledge the seriousness of the farm debt servicing situation in some industries, and I will expand on those facts later. We acknowledge also the adverse effect this is having on the morale of country towns and businesses. I have been at pains to say that it does not help for me to run around like a chook with its head cut off, screaming: `It's a crisis, it's a crisis'. I, above all people, have to reflect the true position, which is a balanced one. Simple-minded simple solutions might make everyone feel good and get nice articles in the newspaper, but they do not work. I must give away thoughts of simple fixes because there are none except those that will make the situation worse in the long term. The simple solutions were those so beloved of the National Party and previous governments; those that are in part responsible for the state of agriculture today.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has acknowledged for months the seriousness of the situation in some areas. There is undoubtedly a severe problem facing a number of rural industries and producers. The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) has quoted some of the figures from the recent National Agricultural Outlook Conference. Those figures come out every three months. The real net value of rural production is projected to fall by 24 per cent in 1985-86, due mainly to projections with respect to the revenue from wheat and the effect of the United States Farm Act as it comes into place. That will cause problems for many individuals, but it does not apply to all farmers.

The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimates that some 7 per cent of farmers will be at risk in financial terms in 1985-86 and the risk measure is for farmers who have lass than 70 per cent equity in their property and are also faced with negative farm income. This figure is up from 5 per cent about a year earlier. While this represents a large number of individuals-some 12,000 farms-it by no means indicates a massive crisis across the entire sector. The reason for this is that conditions are diverse and across the sector and within industries in the whole sector. Farm cash operating surpluses are forecast to increase to 10 per cent in beef in 1985-86, in contrast to the overall fall. There is a wide distribution of debt across the sector. Twenty-eight per cent of farmers have no debt and a further 18 per cent have less than $20,000 debt. These people are net lenders to the rest of the community and if they have their funds free they will actually benefit, for example, from higher interest rates. On the other hand, 12 per cent of farmers have debt levels exceeding $150,000. There is a crisis, but it is only for a number of people; it is not a crisis for the sector as a whole.

We have to develop policies that are sensitive, as well as some policies right across the sector. Far from discriminating against farmers, the Government has adopted positive policies. It reduced the inflation rate of farm costs from 11 per cent in 1982-83 to a forecast 7 per cent this year. If the previous Government's 11 per cent inflation rate had continued for the past three years, farm income this year would be $1.1 billion lower than is currently forecast, or about 33 per cent. We floated the currency, resulting in a depreciation of the trade weighted exchange rate by some 25 per cent in the last year. If the previous Government's overvalued exchange rate-the previous Government deliberately followed a policy of overvaluation of the exchange rate-had continued, farmers would be some $2 billion, or well over 50 per cent, worse off. We reformed the statutory marketing authorities to improve marketing. As a result the Australian Wheat Board, for example, is achieving record sales and record shipments. In terms of the flexibility we have given it to raise money overseas on international markets, the reforms we have put in place have saved tens if not hundreds of millions of dollars for the industry already.

The Opposition does not like to talk about world markets. We do not use those as an excuse. The Opposition does not like to talk about them because it would expose the Opposition's weaknesses. The fact is that the decline in world commodity prices in 1985-86 explains over 90 per cent of the decline in farm incomes.

We have reformed research and soil conservation arrangements. We took specific cost reducing measures in last year's Budget in the areas of tariffs on inputs and fuel prices, and through other portfolios, such as Industry, Technology and Commerce, and Transport, we have acted to reverse the previous Government's high protection policies and blithe acceptance of cost imposing inefficiencies. I have indicated previously that I will be bringing a further submission to Cabinet on future measures to bring further gains in these areas. My Department and I started last November to develop this package of policy options. This package will be before Cabinet in a couple of weeks.

We have been approached by farmers and rural people, as is obvious-it is in the newspapers daily. I had the Canowindra Seven to see me yesterday and I will see the Livestock and Grain Producers Association this afternoon. There is no way that anyone can really say that the Government does not understand or is heartless or unfeeling towards the rural sector. Understanding is one thing; finding the right solutions is quite another. We must protect those in the greatest need now without stopping necessary structural change in some of the farm industry. We must ensure the future of the industry but without allowing the farm sector now to bear more than its due share of the pain of adjustment. When I speak like this I will be accused of not appreciating the psychological stress on those farm men and women and their families who are in dire straits, or the trauma being experienced by families. I appreciate it-I have seen it, I hear about it daily. The Government cares. All industries in the turmoil of change throw up victims. I know this, but I will not be diverted from the proper course, the balance between short term assistance and long term development.

We have been developing a range of policy responses since before Christmas. Cabinet will consider them and all Australians, not just rural people, will benefit when we take balanced and long term policy decisions. No Australians will benefit from the wrong responses; the sorts of responses apparently sought by the lunatic fringe in agro-politics, the sensationalism of parts of the media and those who would politicise our present problems. It does no credit to people in the agro-political organisations when they one day want $5 billion and an immediate end to secondary industry protection, three or four days later they send down a bill for $3.6 billion and an unspecific accord; then, I am told, a week or two later they have another list of demands on the way. I must say also that demands and threats that the farmers will stop all our exports and bring the economy to its knees do not do much for the thinking farmers, nor do the thinking farmers back that.

It took 25 years for the previous governments to get the Australian economy into the mess we inherited in 1983. We now have an economy that is growing faster than any other in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and we have created 600,000 jobs in less than three years. That is of benefit to the farm sector because the domestic market is the best market for many of our agricultural industries. It took 25 years for previous governments, dominated by their Country Party farmer members, to give us the hotch-potch, knee-jerk reactions which they trumped up as being agricultural policy.

In the time available to me I will comment on some of the charges of the honourable member for Gwydir. I emphasise that we understand the present situation. We will not react in an ad hoc way or take on board simple-minded simple solutions; we will take correct political decisions. We sympathise with those being squeezed. We have taken significant initiatives and we have additional policy responses in train. We will not overreact or take the wrong decisions. The honourable member for Gwydir in his opening remarks acknowledged the world price situation and said that there will be a 12.6 per cent-do not hold me to the figure-cut in the forward estimates of the Department of Primary Industry. Part of the reason for that is that in the last Budget we paid to the wheat growers $100m, which was their money. Then it became a book item. If we deduct that $100m, as we must, from the forward estimates, they will show an increase.

Other assistance comes within the areas of other Ministers' portfolios. We do not know yet what the full bill will be for the recent decisions on di-ammonium phosphate and mono-ammonium phosphate fertilisers but the amount will appear under Senator Button's portfolio. So it is very difficult to measure total assistance to the agricultural sector just by looking at the estimates of the Department of Primary Industry.

In my speech to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics Outlook Conference, I said that it is very important for us to have some understanding of the realities if we are to find the real solution. We hear a lot of nonsense and see a lot of confusion about some of the key macro-economic variables that the Government has to deal with in managing the economy. At the end of the day the number of demands coming from the rural sector can be reduced to two. There is either the big subsidy or compensation argument, or there is the argument that we have to direct the whole Australian economy-our total production and total economy-in such a way as meets exclusively the basic interests of the primary industry sector. There are all sorts of variations to that. People are saying in terms of the second collection of policy options that we should scrap the accord-that is wipe out the incomes policy that has delivered such beneficial results to this economy-that we should not continue to bear down on tax avoidance, that we should not move towards needs based social welfare systems, that we should not have consistent industrial policies in place and that we should not continue with Medicare. In other words, they are saying that we should go back to the old overall approach to the economy. The Government clearly rejects that proposition because it believes that we must continue to have domestic growth in the economy. We cannot do anything in a country such as ours unless we get the people back to work. We have to direct our policy approaches to each and every sector.

I would like to turn to the whole confusion about the relationship between interest rates and the exchange rate. The policy concerned with the present level of interest rates is not directed so much at holding up the exchange rate as it is to tempering the rate of domestic growth in the economy which is higher than we expected and, more importantly, to squeezing down on imports. Those who would say that the interest rates have to be deliberately brought down-that is, by an expansion of money supply-really have to answer one question. That question is: Why is it that when the exchange rate eases up interest rates ease down? I am not saying that the policy is incontrovertible, that it will never be changed. However, that relationship between interest rates and the exchange rate is of crucial importance to the rural sector. It seems a nonsense to try to misrepresent that relationship.
The accord is not a disaster, as people are saying. The accord has given us an 11 per cent drop in real unit labour costs in this country since 1983.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true. Of course, part of that drop is the result of some flow-on from the wage freeze. If one looks at any data on the growth of real wages in this country one can see the occasions on which wages were indexed and non-indexed. It is interesting to note that under the previous Government, wages were non- indexed for two years. In those years-1980-81 and 1981-82-real wages rose by nearly 4 per cent and by over 4 per cent. In 1983-84 during the accord, real wages, taking into account some of the effects of the wage freeze, dropped by 4 per cent. In the next year they rose by less than 2 per cent. In the present year they will rise by something less than one per cent in real terms. That is why we have a drop in real unit labour costs in this country of some 11 per cent. That is why we have another 600,000 jobs and that is why profitability is being restored to this economy. In time, investment will flow from private business and that, too, will stimulate the economy to the benefit of the farmers.
-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I congratulate you on your election to the elevated position you now hold. Despite what the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has just said, the Government has discriminated against rural Australians in a very cruel and vicious way. It has removed incentives to produce. By its own decisions it has added to the cost of farm production thus further reducing the viability of Australian farmers. It has taken decisions that make it more difficult for those who choose or need to leave the land to sell their farms. It has caused extreme anguish and torment to countless numbers of farmers and their families who are facing economic ruin. In my view, the Government has acted with malice and has failed dismally to adopt new policies to reduce the impact of the financial crisis facing Australian farmers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), has detailed on behalf of the Opposition many of the sins and omissions of the Australian Labor Party regarding its handling of the rural crisis. If he had had more time he would have provided the House with more alarming information. My colleague listed a 14-point plan of action that the Government should follow immediately to ease the economic burdens of farmers. They are all responsible proposals. Most can be implemented quickly and this positive action by the Government would restore a little of the confidence of farmers and people who live in the country.

For 18 months, the Opposition and farm organisations have been drawing the Government's attention to the parlous state of Australian agriculture-even to the extent of holding massive demonstrations in Canberra and elsewhere in Australia. Throughout all of this period the Minister for Primary Industry has been insisting that farmers were merely `caught in the downturn of a cycle and would recover'. At last he has conceded that there are real and fundamental problems and that the rural families of Australia are facing a financial crisis. However, we have still seen no proposals to meet the situation. Today he said that there is a crisis for some. He said that according to the Bureau of Agricultural Economics 7 per cent will be at risk, that is, up to 5 per cent more than last year. He said that 12 per cent have debts of over $150,000. Is the Government going to wait until that 7 per cent becomes 14 per cent and the 12 per cent becomes 24 per cent? He said that he and his Government care. Mr Deputy Speaker, I put it to you and to the House that the proof and the extent of the Government's caring will be shown by what it does in relation to fuel pricing. Far from developing crisis management measures to assist farmers, the Labor Cabinet has been among the most significant causes of the present crisis. The Labor Party has a philosophical and psychological hang-up about farmers. It does not like them as a group. It would like them all to become peasant farmers. This attitude, of course, is not new. As well as once telling farmers that they never had it so good, former Prime Minister Whitlam once said that people live in cities and peasants live in the country.

After the Second World War, the New South Wales Labor Government's closer settlement policy was to design farming blocks as small as possible. The result of this disastrous and mean policy is part of today's rural economic problems. Many of these blocks were barely a living area at the time and are now, of course, far too small. On election to government, the Whitlam and, indeed, the Hawke administrations, moved with indecent haste to cancel programs developed by Liberal and National party governments to assist farmers. To add insult to injury, late last year during the debate on the Australian Bill of Rights the Government rejected an Opposition amendment which was designed to protect the rights of people who had freehold land. After all that, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says to farmers, their wives and their families: `Trust me'. The men and women who work in the country areas of Australia do not trust this Government and cannot understand why the Labor Party treats them with contempt. What is referred to as the rural crisis is now of great national concern. Not only are farmers affected, but the crisis is now also seriously affecting country businesses and people who are employed in these undertakings. In time the large cities will feel the impact as the industry that is responsible for about 40 per cent of our overseas earnings is flattened by Hawke Government policies and low world commodity prices. In the country the demonstration of concern is taking on a new dimension. Next Tuesday morning a public meeting of women will be held in Junee, in the Hume electorate, to determine ways and means of getting positive action from the Government. Not all in attendance will be farmers' wives; there will be women from all sections of the community. One of the organisers of the meeting, Mrs Margaret Alston, told me this morning that the meeting is being called out of frustration and anger. She said that some families are in a desperate financial position and they are not going to go down without a fight and without the support of the wider community.

Farm costs have been pushed up by record high interest rates. During last year interest rates rose to their highest real levels since the Great Depression over 50 years ago. Current interest rates of 20 per cent or more are sending farmers and small businesses broke. When the Labor Government floated the Australian dollar the Opposition welcomed the decision. As shadow Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said:

The dollar float imposes a new discipline on the Government. The Government can no longer `fudge' the exchange rate in order to protect it from the consequences of inappropriate and irresponsible domestic fiscal monetary and wages policies.

The Leader of the Opposition was right on target. The Government trumpeted the float and said it was content to see the Australian dollar find its own level. When the dollar went down because the market lost confidence in the Government's economic policies, the Government panicked and tightened the money supply, forcing up interest rates to a record high level.

The Prime Minister is all over the place on the issue. A week or two ago he said that he thought US72c or US75c was the appropriate level for the Australian dollar. Today, he qualified that statement. At present it is about US68c and at an all-time record low when measured against the Japanese yen and the German mark. On 24 January on the Mike Carlton program on 2GB the Prime Minister said:
The conditions for a downward movement in interest rates has emerged.

The weakening of the Australian dollar since the Prime Minister's US72c to US75c valuation has made the likelihood of any sustained fall in interest rates as remote as ever. The Prime Minister has been caught out again and it is bad news for farmers, home borrowers and small business. This demonstrates clearly that the Government has lost control of the situation. The failure to pass on the benefits of falling world fuel prices represents yet another broken promise on the part of the Government and higher than necessary fuel costs for Australian users. For farmers it is another slug, an unnecessary input cost, and a further indication of the Government's mean attitude towards people who live and work in country areas. The Deputy Leader of the National Party (Mr Hunt) pointed out very clearly that wheat growers using an average of 24,000 litres of fuel a year would save $1,680 in a full year from a 7c a litre price cut.

For those farmers who have no alternative, or judge that they should leave the land, the task is now more difficult because of the decisions of this Government. The Labor Government's discriminatory tax package, with a capital gains tax, quarantining of farm losses, and a fringe benefits tax, makes farms far less attractive for people with capital to invest who would otherwise be interested in purchasing farming property. The Treasurer's answer to the question asked today by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) concerning extensions of family partnerships that own property is further evidence of the Government's intention to widen the capital gains tax net on a `gently gently catchee monkey' basis. Not only has the Government let down the industry upon which this nation was founded and which is responsible for about 40 per cent of our overseas earnings, it is also delivering a severe blow to individuals and families who live in country areas-

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) and the honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife) today have attempted to paint a picture of discrimination. Right now we are watching their colleagues leave the House in the middle of this debate. They are not interested, of course, in the rural sector and in seeing the debate through. They are not interested in listening to members on this side of the House, who now hold 22 out of the 41 rural seats. We represent more seats in the country than do Opposition members at any time. We also have the ear of the country and we are listening very carefully to what it has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in his speech in this House today clearly outlines the Government's concern. We are concerned with the problems being faced by the rural sector because of the downturn in many of the world markets. We are also concerned to see that discrimination-the word those opposite used in the matter of public importance today-is eliminated. I put it to members of the Opposition that they should have a good think about just where they stand on this, which farmers and which rural people they purport to represent. For many years their policies have discriminated, putting farmer against farmer, rural person against rural person. How many of the farmers whom those opposite say they represent have been able to take advantage of some of the Opposition's own tax evasion measures, which went to the Pitt Street and Collins Street farmers so that they could transfer some of their income across to losses on farms for which they paid inflated prices. Such prices are way out of reach of the ordinary farmer and have created enormous problems for young people who have attempted to get on to the land.

Those opposite should go out to their electorates and talk to the farmers who are in diabolical trouble. They are in trouble for one reason-they have a low equity and a high debt on their properties. They have a high debt because they paid excessive capital prices for farms, attempting to buy properties in competition with people who were coming out of the cities and using the land for taxation evasion purposes. Those people who will be out the front tomorrow, those people who attempted to demonstrate in my electorate last week, have one thing in common. They have lost confidence in the members of parliament who claim to represent them. They have lost confidence in the farming organisation which they put in place to speak on their behalf.

I take the House back to 12 months ago when the Minister for Primary Industry attempted to assist an Australia-wide industry with proposals to deregulate the dairying industry and put it on an economic footing. Who opposed that in this House? Who opposed it in the Senate? It was the National Party of Australia, and the Liberal Party of Australia had to go along with it. The cockies' friends opposed the Minister's proposals. They put on a big demonstration in Warragul in Victoria when the Minister for Primary Industry went there to explain the proposals. What have the Victorian farmers done now? They have told their National Party leaders: `Pull your heads in. We will have a special conference and vote on whether we want the Kerin plan'. They did that and they sent a message back to John Kerin and the Labor Government saying that they do want that deregulation process, they do want this legislation put through. Those opposite are out of touch with the constituency they claim to represent, and that is one of the real problems of the dairying industry and other rural industries. (Quorum formed) Members of the Opposition have taken up some of our time in which to put the case on behalf of the rural people, but I will continue on this line of discrimination.

For the benefit of honourable members I wish to relay a couple of cases that have come to me and in which, quite clearly, there has been some discrimination. We have attempted to change the discriminatory practices which were put in place by some conservatives. I had a visit from two groups of people who were involved with one property in my electorate. One was a genuine farmer who had 100 acres. He was leasing 200 acres of land next door to him from the State Electricity Commission. He had an economic unit. He was paying $20 an acre rent for that land. Those fine market forces about which honourable members opposite talk about were in operation. Two investors came in. They were able to get a tax reduction which would be paid back at the end of the financial year. What did they do? They did their figures. Their accountant advised them that they could pay $30 an acre rent for that land because they had the benefit of this tax lurk. Those people made a bid to the SEC and took over the 200 acres. They put the genuine farmer out of business. They made him unviable and, in the finish, he had to walk off. The investors then stepped forward. They want the taxpayer to subsidise their tax cut to push up the price of land.

Which farmer is the Opposition defending-the genuine one or the tax evader? Two groups are involved. I think it is time that honourable members on the other side of the House decided which members of the farming community are genuine and whom they really want to support. We on this side understand. We know that if we put the economy into the proper perspective we will get the economy going again. The group which will be outside this Parliament tomorrow has given a message not only to the Government but also to the Opposition and the Opposition's organisations.

Let me inform the House of a few of the things that we have put into operation. On this side of the House we hold 22 out of the 41 rural seats. We have the vote in the bush. Last December the Primary Industry and Rural and Provincial Affairs Committee set to work and, with the support of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), we established a task force which is going around Australia. We are not going around talking big publicity and big demonstrations. We are getting the message from the Australian people.
