TALK.START.PARA: —It has taken you a long time.

—It has not taken us a long time. We are working quietly and efficiently. The people of this nation know that we are doing that. We hold 22 out of 41 rural seats. After the next election we will hold 30 seats, including Maranoa. Perhaps that is extending it a little further than is possible in one go. Even if the honourable member for Maranoa produces flowers all the time he will eventually lose popularity, especially if he continues in the way he is going at present. We on this side of the House are genuine. Our Minister is possibly well named when it is said that he is the Bob Hawke of the bush. The organisations out there listen to him. If one looks at yesterday's newspaper one sees that the President of the Country Women's Association talked to the Prime Minister. That association was quite happy to deal with the Labor Government. This is the new attitude in rural Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite can stop talking down the economy. They can stop talking down the rural sector. We will talk it up. We will work darned hard to lift it up. At the next election not only will we hold 22 rural seats but we will not be able to fit them in on this side of the House, because the economy will be on an even keel. We will do to the Opposition what happened to the Liberal Party in Western Australia. It will be rejected. It will continue to be rejected if it carries on with its stupid policies.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the House take note of the statement relating to foreign policy made in the House by the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 26 November 1985.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) made the statement in November last year, shortly before the House rose. Straight after he made the statement I took the opportunity to reply at length on the failures of this Government's foreign policy. It is not my intention today to go over that same ground. Regrettably though, nothing that has happened in the three months since November has indicated that anything has changed from the criticisms that the Opposition made only a few months ago. The Government's foreign policy continues to be marked by the same weakness and factional compromise. It continues to be marked by a lack of any broad vision of the values that underpin Australian foreign policy and by a spurious even-handedness which makes no distinction-did someone say `good'-between countries whose interests and values are complementary or similar to ours and countries whose policies conflict sharply with our interests. It continues to be marked by an inability to stand by our friends or to understand the role we ought be playing. It is a foreign policy of neglect and increasing isolation. It is an abject, self-serving, faction motivated, puerile foreign policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government continues to take absolutely no action over ANZUS. Our most basic defence treaty remains in some form of legal and operational limbo. The fact remains that Labor has made no attempt to try to mediate, to work for a solution to the crisis, and has done nothing to try to dissuade the New Zealand Government from proceeding with its anti-nuclear legislation. To see how hollow the words and how irresolute the actions of the Hawke Government have been one only has to listen to the New Zealand Prime Minister himself. It is David Lange who has acknowledged that Australia would be `considerably aggrieved' by what has happened. It is David Lange who said that `the Australians have been absolutely consistent; they have not been intermediaries' and Australia has been `conspicuous in not advocating any position'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very proper.

—The honourable member says: `Very proper'. This is my country's and his country's most basic defence treaty. It is unravelling and he thinks it is proper to do nothing. Nothing typifies the more abject lack of interest about our fundamental treaty than that form of interjection. No wonder David Lange was moved to respond, when asked whether Australia was an honest broker: `I was going to say that it was neither honest nor broker'. So much for the honourable member's interjection. We are not talking about some scrap of paper here. We are talking about the cornerstone of our foreign and defence policies for 30 years. The fact is that we still do not know the Australian Government's position on the New Zealand legislation. We still do not know the Australian Government's position on the proposal by the United States of America for a review of the pact should New Zealand proceed with the legislation. We still do not know the Australian Government's view of any proposal to suspend New Zealand from the ANZUS Treaty. The reason why this Government is determined to muddy the waters, to confuse and to obfuscate over ANZUS is patently clear. It has put the successful management of Labor Party factional concerns ahead of the successful management of the national interest.

SPEECH.PARA: It is time the Government came clean and clarified the legal and operational status of the Treaty. At the end of this debate I hope the Foreign Minister takes the opportunity to answer these questions. What we do not want is his usual nonsense accusing us of bashing the New Zealand Government. We are not bashing the New Zealand Government. I find its policy repugnant, but I am not bashing it. What the coalition is talking about is commonsense diplomacy where we put Australia's interests first, not the Australian Labor Party's or the New Zealand Labour Party's.

While talking about commonsense diplomacy, I also hope that the Foreign Minister can assure us that the Government has not been stabbing New Zealand in the back. The Foreign Minister has yet to make any comment at all on the statements following the recent visit by the United States congressional delegation led by Mr Stratton. Perhaps the Foreign Minister can tell us what Mr Stratton meant when he said:
On the basis of conversation with leaders in Australia it might be possible to suspend New Zealand's membership in the (ANZUS) Pact.

The Government might tell other people one thing in private, but it has not told the Australian people; and it is their treaty, their basic cornerstone of defence, which has unravelled before our eyes. The Government might say one thing to visiting United States congressmen, but this Parliament and the public are entitled to know. We have heard nothing. The Defence Minister (Mr Beazley) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have been hiding behind spokesmen and the Foreign Minister is saying nothing.

The reality is that this Government does not want ANZUS debated in this country because it knows that its record will not stand examination. It has allowed our basic treaty to unravel and it has not lifted one finger to stop it. As this matter moves on to its finality in New Zealand, when that legislation passes no amount of arguing will stop this three-country treaty from having one leg of it knocked from under it. No amount of arguing that this was simply a matter between the United States and New Zealand will wash with the Australian people. This was our treaty as much as anybody else's and no country in the world had a greater capacity to exert some leverage or some purchase on the situation as it unravelled than Australia. But leftist pressures and the fears of those who are not in the Left of that pressure ensured that we did nothing. A decision not to do something ought to be as well thought out as a decision to do something. It was not thought out in this case, it was mere fear of the factions.

Let me now look at another critical issue facing Australia, namely, the Philippines. Here again the Government's record is one of inaction. We should not fool ourselves about the importance of a stable Philippines-that speaks for itself-and the consequences for our security of the possibility of an eventual communist takeover. It is still too early to comment on the results of the Philippines election and how Australia should respond. One thing, though, is very clear, and that is that we will have to make crucial judgments about this election. Yet once again we had inaction from the Australian Government. It refused to send any official observers to see what would happen. It ignored a bipartisan call-Labor, Liberal and National Party-from the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of this Parliament to send observers and it ignored repeated calls from the Opposition to do the same thing. It is patent nonsense to suggest, as the Minister has done, that the presence of observers was susceptible to allegations of unwarranted interference in the internal affairs of the Philippines. The Philippines Government and official Opposition both made it clear that observers were welcome. Formal invitations were not being issued; but, if one were sufficiently concerned to go, one would have sought an invitation and gone. That is the normal thing in international diplomacy. If a country wants to participate, its ambassador or a member of the mission advises that government and an invitation is sent.

It happened with others. I was able to send Senator Hill, on behalf of the Liberal Party, to participate in an observer team. There was an official team of congressmen from the United States who went on the President's behalf. It was made clear that those who wanted to go and observe could do so. But, oh no, we did not want any part of it again. What will happen? Only this morning the Foreign Minister was being asked to comment on the elections themselves. Correctly, at this stage, he says that we will have to wait. But whose advice will he rely on? He cannot rely on his own government-appointed advisers who went there; he will have to rely on others. They may be sane, sage men and women. But why did we not have our own observers other than Senator Hill? He is a significant figure in the Opposition ranks, but why did we not have the Government's own appointed persons there to give it the advice over and above what the mission may report? The Government will have to make determinations on the nature of those elections; yet it refuses to have any part of it because it means that it can work out a deal within the Labor Party, its factions and members of the Left who would like to see significant changes in the security relationships between our country and the Philippines. Once again the Government has abstained from any activity. The coalition is very concerned that what has happened in the Philippines is the worst possible outcome. Equally though, we do not believe that we can walk away from that country. Geography alone rules out such an option. Security considerations compel a continuing interest.

Let us also take a look quickly at the other main recent issues, where again the pattern is all too predictable. International terrorism has now become one of the greatest threats to the fabric of democratic societies. It is an attack on the rule of law and on the basis of civilisation. Australia cannot take refuge in silence or inaction. Yet this is what this Government has done again. It refuses to take any sort of lead in confronting terrorism. In the Achille Lauro incident the Acting Prime Minister was forced to make a humiliating backdown from his indications of support for United States actions. Instead, at the urgings of the Foreign Minister, he said that he simply `understood the matter'. More recently, when it came to confronting Libya, the Government again opted out. The Government must be under no illusions about Libya's use of terrorism as an instrument of state policy; yet it continues to be prepared to sit back and do nothing.

In yet another area the Government's continuing failings have come to the fore. The propaganda exercises are to the fore on the question of disarmament to placate groups in, and on the fringes of, the Labor Party. The Foreign Minister's various efforts at appeasing the peace movement could succeed in creating a Frankenstein for his Party's National Conference in Hobart later this year, and to hell with the national interest. Just work out the deals for the Party. Already this year, Australia has adopted a spurious even handedness in Geneva. We have been President of the Geneva Conference on Disarmament, which ignores our position in the western alliance and the historical reality of the Soviet military build-up. After almost a year the Government is still refusing to respond formally to the Weinberger invitation to participate in strategic defence initiative research.

On top of all this-the unravelling of ANZUS and all those factors that I have mentioned-this week we have had Senator Gareth Evans's renewal of the Foreign Minister's threat to close down North West Cape were it to develop a first strike capability. I do not comprehend the Government. Its basic treaty is falling apart; yet its closest ally, the United States, is being called into question by the Foreign Minister reiterating through his representative in the Senate that the Government may close the bases down if it determines that the United States is developing a first strike capability. This does just not add up. The coalition reiterates its belief that disarmament policies must be based on consistency and credibility, and that one cannot negotiate on disarmament questions from a position of weakness. It is because deterrence must be preserved in a viable form that we support the necessary decisions to technologically upgrade, and we support research with the strategic defence initiative.

Finally, we have had the Foreign Minister's refusal to involve himself in the ban on South African Rotary students by the New South Wales Government-a ban which is bigoted; a ban which is ignorant. Is there anything more abject than that? It is justified on the basis that it contributes to the Government's foreign policy and is analogous with the Government's policy on sporting sanctions on South Africa. The Foreign Minister should have told the New South Wales Government that this was completely wrong, that the Rotarian students did not come to Australia as representatives of South Africa, but came as representatives of the ideals and aspirations of Rotary International. These children are the victims of the intolerance and bigotry of a New South Wales Labor Government. The decision will do nothing to increase the pressure on South Africa for reform. To the contrary, such a decision is likely to be counter-productive. It is no business of the State Government to interfere in the conduct of foreign policy.

What has happened since my reply to the Minister's statement in November has been a continuation of all the same themes, weaknesses and inconsistencies of the previous three years. The reality is that what we are seeing is nothing less than a major transformation of Australia's foreign and defence policies. There is nothing dramatic about the way this is being done except in relation to ANZUS. Rather it is almost like a campaign of attrition. It is a brick by brick demolition of Australia's traditional role in the world. The Government ought to be condemned for its inaction, its weakness, its inconsistency and its endangering of Australia's security-particularly over ANZUS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I move on to the few remarks which I am going to make during this short 15 minutes I would like to say that once again the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), has come into this House and spoken about ANZUS as he did when he initially replied to the statement of the Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden) last year. Although the honourable member has had about one hour's worth of reply, at no stage during this debate or at any other time in this House has he said what he would do. We might be able to drag a horse to water but we cannot make him drink. This Government has done a lot in the course of the ANZUS ruckus. However, actually changing New Zealand's policy is for the New Zealand Government as a sovereign state to do. What would the honourable member opposite do to change that? He has not offered one solution in the hours he has been on his feet in this Parliament. I would like to concentrate my remarks today on the Pacific and South Pacific region. The Pacific is a very complex and very exciting region.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I think the honourable member needs an audience; so I call your attention to the state of the House.
—Order! The honourable member for Indi will recall that I warned the honourable member for Groom about prefacing his points of order.
—I am sorry. I did not hear it. Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House. (Quorum formed)

—I will revert to the subject of ANZUS seeing that honourable members opposite do not want to hear about solutions. They are inept. As I have said, in the hours which they and their spokesman on foreign affairs have had, they have been unable to put any solutions forward. This Government has consistently and continually put forward its policy in regard to ANZUS. It does not back away from the fact that it disagrees with the New Zealand policy. It has spoken on that on many occasions. The situation is that New Zealand, being a sovereign state, makes it own decisions. I hope that it will now and forever continue in that course. It so happens that on this occasion we disagree with its policy. We would hope that the three members of ANZUS are able to get together to find a successful solution to the problems that exist now. As I have said to my American friends, in some respects some of the problems have come about because at the initial stage when New Zealand came forward with its policy the United States jumped in, I believe, a little too quickly and forcefully. The United States is now backing away to try to let the waters calm down. I think the United States might have helped the situation a little more if it had done that initially. The ANZUS problem would not be any better today if, heaven help us, we had had a conservative government. Look at the botch-ups we had from one end of the world to the other during the 30 years of coalition government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the South Pacific nuclear free zone. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty was introduced to the South Pacific Forum by this Government. It was held in high regard and has been passed by the South Pacific Forum recently. Nearly all members of that Forum have signed that Treaty. It is a step forward. It puts the situation in the Pacific today into concrete form. It ensures, among other things, that there is no nuclear testing or dumping of waste in the Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk to your socialist friends about that.

—If the honourable member wants to come forward and say that he agrees with the dumping of nuclear waste and the testing of nuclear bombs and missiles in the Pacific that is fine. I ask him to put that to the people of Australia. I assure the honourable member that members on this side of the House do not agree with him; nor do the majority of states in the Pacific. In fact, Vanuatu, which has not signed the Treaty, has not signed it because it is not strong enough.
—It is French, socialist.

—For the information of the honourable member, Vanuatu is an independent country which these days the French Government has nothing to do with. However, I am sure the honourable member will catch up. Like other honourable members opposite he is a few years behind what is happening. I come back to the South Pacific. I think an important thing that has happened in the Parliament is that the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee has decided, as its next reference, to inquire into Australia and the South Pacific. I will have the honour of being chairman of that inquiry. We have sent several hundred letters already.
—We are all holding our breath.

—I hope the honourable member is able to participate in the inquiry. I will give him plenty of flexibility and latitude to participate in that. Several hundred letters already have been sent to every part and nation of the Pacific and throughout Australia asking for submissions. The incredible interest that has already been shown in this inquiry which has not yet even officially started augurs well for its success. As I mentioned earlier, the Pacific is a complex region which not many people understand. It is an area of different personalities, different cultures and traditions and different ways of life. Some Pacific states face inherent economic problems as they march towards the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to personalities, the changing face of the Pacific was emphasised recently by the election of Mr Paias Wingti as Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea. Mr Wingti, university educated and a man only in his mid-thirties, has the potential to be a force in Papua New Guinea and Pacific politics for a long time. I was fortunate enough to meet the Papua New Guinea Foreign Minister, Mr Vagi, on his recent trip to Australia. Like the Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea he was born in the post-war period and looks upon life and the role that his country will play in the world today a little differently from some of his predecessors. Papua New Guinea is changing rapidly, with the advent into government of the younger generation of well-educated people.

Various cultural groupings in the Pacific, such as the Melanesians and Polynesians, also have great influence on day to day occurrences in the Pacific. There is a unity amongst some of the people of the region that crosses international borders. Their heritage and traditions go back a very long way into history. The July edition of the Pacific Islands Monthly in its editorial stated:

Newcomers to the Pacific have frequently made the error of assuming that just because island people are friendly, smiling and hospitable, that their affairs tend to be uncomplicated and serene. Nothing could be further from the truth.
The editorial went on further:

No Australian or New Zealand politician has anything like the complexities of floor-crossing, no-confidence votes, clan-allegiances, tribal enmities and racial sensitivities, with which an Island leader must deal virtually every day.

That sums up quite succinctly the position in most parts of the Pacific. Unfortunately, the intricacies and various power plays in the Pacific are not understood by many. Further, having spoken to a number of United States Congressmen and others in positions of political importance, both on a recent trip to the United States of America and here in Australia, I am a little surprised at the lack of knowledge of Pacific matters of many of our American friends and at their lack of understanding of why certain decisions are made and how they are arrived at. However, I am sure that they are not alone. It would also be fair to say, notwithstanding what I have just said, that there are a number of people in positions of influence in the United States, both within and outside the Congress and the Administration, who are making a concerted effort to learn and understand more about the Pacific region and its people.

Excluding Australia and New Zealand, the biggest state in the Pacific and one of Australia's closest allies is Fiji. Since independence Fiji has had a fine record of management and stability under its Prime Minister, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara. However, with the introduction into the Fijian political arena of another new political force observers will be watching carefully to see that this very important country does not have a period of political instability because of any new political developments. However, if I were to predict the future, which is a hard game in the political world, I believe that Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara will be at the helm for some time to come.

With regard to New Caledonia, hopefully it is moving towards a peaceful and true independence. In contrast with previous French governments, the Government of President Mitterrand has made a genuine move towards independence for New Caledonia. While this move should have been made much earlier and different policies should have been instituted by earlier administrations, we cannot change the past. We must look at the position in New Caledonia today. I congratulate President Mitterrand on his constructive moves towards independence for the territory. That process must continue, and independence must be achieved within the next few years. If there is a change of government in France and that new government halts this process, it will move New Caledonia down one path and one path only-the path of bloody revolution. That will occur as sure as I am standing here today. Independence is inevitable and, therefore, a peaceful and true independence incorporating all the different groups within the territory is essential. I wish the French President and his people all the best in their moves to bring to the territory of New Caledonia the solution of which I have spoken.

Another issue I wish to touch on is the important issue of tuna fishing. There has been a lot of discussion about tuna fishing, a lot of unrest because of the tuna fishing policies of the America tuna fishing association and the Americans' attitude in general to tuna fishing and their belief that they are able to fish wherever they want to and whenever they want to. In recent times, we have seen moves towards a solution. Various meetings and conferences have been held between all the interested parties-the Americans and the Pacific states, and I believe that Australia has been represented. Another recent meeting in Hawaii just a few weeks ago brought the possibility of a solution a little closer. However, that is still some time away.

Whilst I believe the American Administration wishes to find a solution acceptable to all the island states as quickly as possible, there are other forces such as the Van kamp and Star-Kist corporations behind the scenes that do not want an early solution to the tuna fishing problem in the Pacific. Failure to find a solution would be a political disaster not just for the island states but for the United States and the Western alliance in general. The Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has already signed a tuna fishing agreement with Kiribati. Unless a good, acceptable solution is found for the benefit of the island states, not just for one tuna fishing association in the United States, there will not be peace in this important area in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), in the statement we are debating and in many other statements, has perfected a technique of balancing the factional pressures on him by saying one thing but moving in the opposite direction. He does not really speak English, or if he does it is a sort of dialect of English; he speaks in Haydenese. He probably has little choice. He is the Foreign Minister in a Labor government which has to satisfy its various factions with their conflicting foreign policy programs. But at least we should see clearly what he is doing, or what he is trying to do. For example, he says in typical Haydenese that his Government supports the ANZUS Treaty and that it disagrees with the New Zealand Government. Of course, he will do absolutely nothing about it, and pleads with the United States Administration to pretend that nothing serious has happened to ANZUS. I quote from his statement:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to review the course of events in the United States-New Zealand relations over the past 18 months-
One could say in passing that of course he does not want to do that; it would open up too many issues. He goes on:
I do wish to make some points about the ramifications of these events . . . The Australian Government recognises the serious implications for the United States and New Zealand of their disagreement.
There was no reference to any serious implications for Australia. The Minister continues:
It disagrees with the policy of New Zealand. The suggestion, however, that we should or could force New Zealand to change this policy is stupid and primitive.
Apparently, the only suggestion of any influence on New Zealand is one of force, which of course is not in issue. The statement goes on:
It trivialises a serious matter. It ignores the fact that New Zealand is a sovereign nation--
no one has ever challenged that--
proud and independent, whose prompt response at any attempt to use this bully-boy tactic--
that is how the Minister describes any attempts to influence another country--
would prove how mindless and counter-productive it was.

What has happened is that one of the three countries who joined in the Treaty-a treaty which is Australia's most fundamental treaty and was solemnly adopted by the parliaments of the three countries-has withdrawn from it, has damaged the Treaty, has withdrawn from any serious commitment to the Western alliance, and it has espoused a sort of isolationism to the cheers of Moscow. It has done this under the pressure of the Moscow-leaning left wing of New Zealand Labour. The United States has to decide what its policy towards the New Zealand Government should now be.

As I have said, the Foreign Minister has done nothing to influence the New Zealand Government. To do so, he says, would be to be a bully boy, it would be primitive and stupid. In other words, any attempt to influence the New Zealand Government has been ruled out in advance on those ridiculous grounds. The Minister not only does not attempt to influence the New Zealand Government, to draw New Zealand's attention to the full ramifications of its actions, but also goes on, speaking as a South Pacific expert, to ask the United States to do nothing. `Cool it', he says, adopting the pose of a statesman; `If we do nothing, if we pretend nothing has happened, it will all come good in the end'. Of course, the Minister has to do this because the left wing of his Party is delighted with the New Zealand Government's decision and has sent it messages of congratulations and encouragement. In fact, it would like the Australian Government to adopt the same posture.

If the Foreign Minister were as serious about ANZUS as he says he is and tried to influence the New Zealand Government-not by adopting bully-boy tactics which are not in question, but by drawing New Zealand's attention to the full implications of what it has done-and if he also tried to influence the United States in the same direction, he would enrage his own left wing, and he dares not do that. That is why there is no real government sponsored ANZUS debate in Australia in light of this crisis. The Foreign Minister is terrified of the idea of a debate. All members of his Party will adopt this view: `Cool it. Put our heads in the sand like ostriches and it will all go away. We can pretend to be statesmen and dress it up in Haydenese'.

I hope the United States Government rejects the Foreign Minister's advice. That advice-to pretend that nothing has happened and to do nothing about it except to exclude New Zealand from naval exercises-if adopted, would have disastrous consequences. If we hope that in due course the New Zealand voters will see the folly of their Government's actions and vote it out, the certain way to ensure that that will not happen is to pretend that New Zealand's withdrawal from ANZUS has made no difference, that the ANZUS Treaty, which incorporates New Zealand in its title, remains untouched and that New Zealand's defences are basically unaffected. The only way to influence New Zealand voters so that they will in due course throw out their present Government is to make it plain that the New Zealand Government has abrogated ANZUS and that the only sensible course of action is for Australia and the United States to enter into bilateral negotiations for a new treaty.

Further, if the United States now accepts our Foreign Minister's advice and does nothing about New Zealand's abrogation of the Treaty, this will obviously be noted by other governments around the world which are under pressure from their anti-American Left and they, too, will soon adopt the New Zealand path on the grounds that the United States will not take any action in this regard. Ultimately the Western alliance will be far more seriously damaged than it has been by this irresponsible New Zealand measure. But we cannot discuss this in government terms because it is presented in Haydenese, which says one thing and moves in the other direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like Hawkespeak.

—A bit like Hawkespeak, yes. Another example of Haydenese is seen in his remarks about the Middle East. The Foreign Minister in his statement expresses his `profound concern' about `the bitter turbulence engulfing Israel, Lebanon and the other nations'. It is, of course, a matter of profound concern. But what has the Foreign Minister done about it? He is encouraging the turbulence that he condemns or is concerned about. He does this particularly by stepping up criticism of Israel. When in opposition he was a bitter opponent, we all remember, of the then Government's decision to join the Sinai peacekeeping force. The House will remember that the Foreign Minister when in opposition called the Begin Government the greatest threat to peace in the world today. He dismissed the Sinai peacekeeping force-the Multinational Force and Observers-as dangerous to Australia, dangerous to trade and as something that should not be required except under United Nations auspices, even though there was no possibility of United Nations sponsorship because of the Soviet veto. In government he felt obliged to praise the Sinai peacekeeping force in very strong terms and then turned around and committed Australia to withdrawing it from Sinai; withdrawing it from the only peace agreement in the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: More than that, on United Nations committees and on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, Australia under this Foreign Minister is adding to the bitter turbulence that he deplores by supporting the most extreme and mendacious anti-Israel resolutions. For example, at the recent UNESCO conference in Bulgaria, the Australian Ambassador, Mr Gough Whitlam, voted for two odious anti-Israel resolutions moved by the Soviets and the Arabs. They were hardy perennials which had been on the agenda over the years, and they had always been voted against by Australia, but not now. One of them condemned Israel for its archaeological work in the old city of Jerusalem, presenting it as the act of barbarians, despite the fact that UNESCO had approved the work earlier on. Only after the work was completed did the UNESCO conference decide to condemn, or try to condemn, the work that it had encouraged and approved. Another resolution condemned Israel for closing a university that had become a base for Palestine Liberation Organisation terrorism. As I say, these were perennial resolutions which Australia had always opposed in the past, but not now, under this Foreign Minister. No wonder Israel feels a cold wind blowing from Australia, as Israelis put it to me last year.

Australian citizens are now being targeted for execution by Middle East terrorists. Yet it has taken over 10 years, since the infamous Iraqi loans affairs, for the Australian Labor Party to expel from its ranks one of Australia's chief apologists for the terrorist states, Mr Hartley. It is worth noting that the major ground used to justify the expulsion of Mr Hartley from the ALP was not his outrageous foreign policy statements, but his disagreement with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Premier Cain on the issue of deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation.

Another example of Haydenese is in relation to South Africa. Although the Foreign Minister talks of working towards a more positive and constructive relationship with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, there will be no constructive relationship with South Africa. I spent a couple of weeks in South Africa late last year. I was invited there by the South African Tourist Commission in my capacity as editor of Quadrant magazine. I spent a good deal of time talking with politicians of the Opposition party, opposition editors, officials of opposition sporting organisations, and with students and academics, black and white, as well as with what one might call ordinary South Africans. The one thing one can say about South Africa is that it is a country in which one does not have delicately to raise questions on politics. Within seconds of meeting a South African, he raises the political questions. There is an almost universal commitment to or acceptance of the need for change, for power sharing, however that may be done in an ethnically complex country. But reform, against the background of the frightful events of recent times, is the agenda.

There are two things that can slow down reform. One is sanctions and disinvestment, with all the consequent hardships and destabilisation that they imply. The other is the boycotting and isolation of all reform movements, individuals and organisations in South Africa. But these are the two policies which the Foreign Minister espouses. In the true spirit of Haydenese he calls for reform but adopts policies which undermine or weaken them. I know he is not responsible for the fatuous decision of the New South Wales Minister for Education, who is banning exchange visits by South African school students-the very people we want to influence in a liberal democratic way-but that decision is a perfect example of Haydenese.

There are many other examples, from the Philippines to Cambodia. He speaks of his concern for human rights in Central America, but has nothing to say about the attack on them by Sandinista pre-totalitarians in Nicaragua. In an article in this morning's Age the courageous editor of La Prensa calls for support from the outside world. He states:
Solidarity with the free world is the oxygen necessary for our continued existence.
The Australian Foreign Minister has never shown any inclination to supply that oxygen.

Let us turn to some major and fundamental issues: The role of the USSR and its relations with the West and its allies. The Foreign Minister says, in Haydenese, that we are not neutral; we are part of the Western alliance. But when it comes to the crunch we get, at the first stage, the doctrine of moral equivalence, the idea that, balancing every evil in the USSR, there is some evil in the United States of America, so they are equivalent-a sort of Haydenese neutralism. If Russia attacks Afghanistan the Hawke Government deplores it, but it is equally quick to deplore United States intervention in Grenada, without any consideration of which action more advances democracy in the world. It says: `The USSR is an unpleasant regime, but we have to live with it'. So we get no demands, such as those that are made on South Africa, that the Soviet bloc nations adhere to the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights, the Helsinki Accords or to the USSR's Bill of Rights, however comic it may seem that it should have one. We get no persistent call for the USSR to allow its citizens to emigrate and no persistent comment on continuing Soviet persecution of its peace movement. Six months ago, for example, Dr Brodsky was gaoled for peace activities. Last year Kiril Popov was arrested for peace activities. During the summer two 17-year-old girls were incarcerated in a mental hospital for trying to join in a demonstration with some visiting Dutch peace activists.

The USSR remains a totalitarian state. There is no better word for a state which has total powers over all aspects of the life of its people. But our Government would, it seems, not dream of saying so.

But when it comes to commenting on US activities, it is not so reticent. When it comes to significant decisions, it is those with an anti-American bite that are adopted, such as the decision to refuse to allow the US to use Australian airfields or ports to refuel while monitoring the flight of an inert US MX missile in 1985.

The basic point about the Australian Government's policy is that it is designed not to strengthen the Western alliance, but to appease the ALP's left wing and the peace movement generally, no matter how dangerous this movement is in its constant undermining of the Western alliance and of the concept of deterrence which has kept the peace for so long. The peace movement should be exposed as a threat to peace. Its advocacy of unilateral disarmament is only encouragement to aggression. The more concessions made to it, in armaments or in morale, the weaker the Western alliance becomes, the more likely an attack on it becomes.

The Government is giving encouragement to unilateral disarmament. It is doing this in the programs it is sponsoring in the International Year of Peace which will flood the country with the sorts of illusions which it is the duty of a responsible government to combat. And it is doing it in its cancellation of the PADEX defence fair in my electorate. More importantly, it is doing it in its unremitting hostility to President Reagan's strategic defence initiative which, if successful, will make nuclear war obsolete. This hostility even includes cancelling Australian research with the electromagnetic rail gun. What it would call its most positive peace achievement is the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty which will have no effect on French testing--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) has attempted to coin a new word-`Haydenese'. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) is entirely capable of defending himself and I am sure he will when he sums up this debate, but I think a more accurate use of the term `Haydenese' would be a description of witty and intelligent comment. I would also like to make one other comment on the honourable member's remarks; that is, thank God for the peace movement. Without the peace movement Reagan would not have met Gorbachev, we would not have Gorbachev's proposals and we would not have the signs of hope in the arms race that we do.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs covered scores of topics. I want to concentrate on just one of these, the international economic environment, and touch on one other, the arms race. There is little discussion of international economic issues in Australia apart from attention generally narrowly focused on our own trade and balance of payments. The world is increasingly economically interdependent and the state of the economies not only of North America, Japan and Western Europe, but also of the developing and communist countries, particularly in our region, have a strong influence on us. At present we are in the midst of a period of severe, chronic disorder in the global economy, illustrated most dramatically not only by the shocking famine in Sub-Saharan Africa, but also by the massive Third World debt and by the current slow growth of Western countries. For example, since 1973 economic growth rates in most Western countries have averaged about half the rates of the previous decades and there was a severe global recession in 1982 and 1983.

The mutually reinforcing full employment strategies of the 1950s and 1960s gave way in the mid-1970s to beggar my neighbour deflation. One country's attempts to restrain demand in order to control inflation reduced growth of its imports, causing falls in exports from other countries. Mutually reinforcing deflation became entrenched. The effect of recent unco-ordinated attempts by single countries such as France, the United States of America and Australia to break out of slow growth using expansionary fiscal policy has led to large deficits in those countries' current account balances. The strong stimulus from the massive US Budget deficits since 1982 has assisted many countries exporting to the US, but even that stimulus had less impact last year and the US growth rate fell to 2 1/2 per cent in 1985.

Several major factors are currently retarding global recovery. Major Western European countries and Japan continue to be cautious about stimulating expansion. Non-tariff barriers to trade have been increasing throughout the last decade in industrialised countries. Commodity prices are deeply depressed, in some case to the lowest level for 50 years, largely because of the slow rate of growth of demand in Western Europe.

The US Budget deficit has both great benefits and costs, the principal cost being that, when linked with the pincer of the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, interest rates have been kept extraordinarily high. This has caused impossible and quite unsustainable problems for many developing countries. Third World debt totalled over $US700 billion in 1984. Almost half of the total interest bill of developing countries during the period 1980-82 was directly attributable to the increase in interest rates in that period over the levels of the late 1970s. The juxtaposition of unprecedentedly high interest rates with the steep drop in commodity prices has caused staggering foreign exchange losses for most developing countries.

From the end of the 1970s the climate of official and private banking opinion in Western countries opposed further lending to the South and aid stagnated, so developing countries were forced to sharply contract domestic demand, to reschedule their debt or to default. Third World deflation reduced growth rates to the stage that in 1983 output in developing countries actually fell. This also transmitted deflationary impulses to the West through reduced demand for exports. For example, during 1984 total Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development exports to developing countries were $US46 billion below their 1980-81 level, resulting in a loss in Western countries of two million to three million jobs. As well, in 1983-84, $US164 billion of official and bank debt was rescheduled at the Paris Club. The South cannot service or repay its debt, because the West will not buy its exports, and Western exports to the South have fallen because the only option for developing countries is either severe deflation or default.

Australia is fortunate to be located in the region with the fastest growing developing countries. Estimated growth rates in East Asia have been 5 per cent in recent years and China has grown by around 10 per cent in each of the last two years. However, each of the dynamic newly industrialising countries in East Asia experienced severe recessions in 1985-Singapore's output, for example, falling for the first time in 20 years. The stagnation of demand for their manufactured exports in the US was a powerful influence, combined with high interest rates and with depressed commodity prices.

The immediate global prospects are for continuation of slow growth. The OECD predicts economic growth of about 2 1/2 per cent per annum until the middle of next year, while the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development forecasts 3 per cent growth this year for the world. Two major changes since these forecasts were made will have complex effects-the passing of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings Bill in the US, which aims to reduce and eventually eliminate the US Budget deficit, and the collapse of world oil prices. The reduction of the US fiscal stimulus will remove the principal global engine for growth of the last two years, but the decline in oil prices will reduce inflation and lift effective demand in oil importing countries in the West and South so that in the short term the net effects are likely to be positive. These forecasts and events show that severe problems will continue unless there are new initiatives. The only immediate sign of hope is a shift in US Administration policy shown by the Treasury Secretary Baker's proposals announced at the World Bank annual meeting in Seoul for renewed lending to developing countries. Another important change is President Reagan's announcement in his State of Union address last week. He stated:

We've begun co-ordinating economic and monetary policy among our major trading partners. But there is more to do, and tonight I am directing Treasury Secretary Jim Baker to determine if the nations of the world should convene to discuss the role and relationships of our currencies.

It is noteworthy that Jim Baker is given the power to determine what the nations of the world should do. It is significant that after several years of support for such a conference from President Mitterrand, the Commonwealth Finance Ministers and the Economic Committee of the Socialist International the US Government is at last recognising the benefits which such a conference offers. Mr Muldoon also called for such a conference, but his unrealistic suggestions should not be allowed to discredit the idea. An essential foundation for global recovery is recovery in the West. To be fully effective this requires co-ordinated action by all Western governments. United States monetary policies should be relaxed to reduce interest rates and to allow the overvalued United States dollar to depreciate. The stimulus to demand in Japan in particular, but also in Western Europe, should be increased. The fiscal stimulus in the United States should not be allowed to dissolve. In combination, these measures would increase aggregate Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development demand, reduce interest rates and correct exchange rate imbalances by reducing the value of the United States dollar and increasing that of the yen. Opportunities for this type of co-ordinated action are already available through meetings of the Group of Seven. It might be effective if new institutional arrangements were established to make the co-ordination more effective.

Faster aggregate economic growth in industrialised countries would increase the volume of exports from developing countries and perhaps also increase commodity prices, but that alone would not be enough to allow developing countries to service and repay their debts as well as to increase the per capita incomes of their peoples. A range of other immediate and medium term steps are required. These include renewing and increasing the flow of private and official credit to debtor countries; resumption of the issuing of special drawing rights; authorisation of increased World Bank and International Development Association lending; increasing overseas development assistance; allowing the write-off and restructuring of debts for the poorer and most indebted countries; and reforming the International Monetary Fund. Reform of the IMF is essential. At present it has an asymmetrical, deflationary bias because deficit countries are required to constrain domestic demand in order to correct current account imbalances, but little action is taken with surplus countries. The effectiveness of the IMF in improving exchange rate stability must be increased.

As the Minister for Foreign Affairs said in his statement, factors affecting the international economic system are largely beyond the control of a country such as Australia. Nevertheless, we have some influence which could be used for encouraging reform of the international financial and trading systems. It is important that we use what influence we have effectively to achieve global economic recovery, relief of poverty, malnutrition and disease, and so sustain improvements in the living standards of peoples everywhere. An important contribution Australia can make which is entirely under our control is our own overseas aid. That is a significant addition to the resources of developing countries and is particularly important at present in the drought-stricken African countries, to the developing countries with large debts, and to all low income countries with development plans. Therefore the Minister's announcement in November that the decline in Australia's aid during the last couple of years will be stopped and `the real level of official development aid' increased in all future years is welcome.

To summarise, global reflation is required in the context of planned co-operation between like-minded governments, so that the competitive beggar-my-neighbour deflation of the last decade is replaced by mutually reinforcing better-my-neighbour recovery to the mutual benefit of all nations.

I want also to touch on the economic consequences of the arms race, because the profligate waste of resources on military expenditure is one of the causes of the current chronic economic problems. The world spent in the order of $US800 billion on military activity in 1984 and the rate has been increasing. The economic consequences of this military expenditure are, on balance, destructive. The principal damage is the opportunity cost of investment and consumption forgone to make way for military expenditure. A second major opportunity cost is the diversion of scarce scientific personnel into military research and development. The cost of this diversion of creative scientific talent is a permanent loss of dynamism in non-military research and development. The contrast of the United States with Japan in the imaginativeness of civilian innovation is rapidly apparent to consumers in Australia. Military expenditure also is a less effective stimulus to employment than other more labour intensive forms of public expenditure. It also tends to stimulate inflation. All these factors contribute to reducing the rate of economic growth in countries with high military expenditure. The contrast between the economic performance of Japan and, say, the United States is due to many factors, but the low level of military expenditure in Japan-less than one per cent of national income-is certainly a contributing factor.

In view of these costs it is surprising that military expenditure is so high and that it is increasing. The reasons are complex and certainly include the power of the military-industrial complex's lobbying, the momentum of research and the real and/or perceived threat of aggression. Military expenditure is the symbol of political responsibility for national security. Political arguments about commitment to national security are commonly about the proportion of national income allocated to military activity rather than about the more important but complex issues of defence strategy and appropriate armaments. Reduction of military expenditure is an extremely complex task involving confidence-building between the superpowers, negotiation of effective arms control and disarmament agreements, and more rigorous and careful targeting of defence strategy. The Australian Government's strong support for disarmament is contributing to this task. For example, when I visited the United Nations General Assembly in New York in October, I was impressed with the vigour with which Australia's representatives were arguing the case for a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty.

Increasing military expenditure is a symptom of the hostility between nations, but also adds to the threat of global Armageddon. Never before in peace time has there been such massive spending on weaponry. The availability of that weaponry increases the danger that it will be used. Therefore it is crucial that maximum pressure be put on both superpowers to reduce their military expenditure. Success with such a goal would release desperately needed funds for constructive economic and social programs. This goal is one aspect of the moral sensibility of which the Minister spoke in his statement. It is a goal which requires the support of every person concerned for peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I begin by congratulating you on your election to your high office.
—Did you vote for him?

—No, I did not vote for him. The year 1986 has been designated the International Year of Peace and I would like to address my remarks to the Government's so-called disarmament policies, as expressed in the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), and their relevance both to Australia's security and our goal of global peace and stability. All Australians, regardless of age and political complexion, are committed to the goal of peace. No political party or political movement is the sole custodian of peace and peace policies in this country. The Liberal Party of Australia is as much part of the peace movement as the People for Nuclear Disarmament and the Nuclear Disarmament Party and all their factions. The differences are only about the means of achieving the end-that of peace.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition believes its passion for peace can be satiated only through the maintenance of an effective balance of power and deterrence. The Australian Democrats, the Nuclear Disarmament Party and their various factions and splinter groups just shut their eyes to the world and hope that its changes will have vanished when their eyes open. The Government, while professing from time to time to support the concept of peace through security, while professing to support the ANZUS alliance, the Western alliance, and I suppose the United States, in fact is schizophrenic. On the one hand it understands the strong community support for ANZUS and the policies of peace through security. On the other hand, it is anxious to win the approbation of the so-called peace groups. The Government fears the electoral consequences of the Nuclear Disarmament Party, but it is crippled by its own internal factionalism. The Government's public statements on peace and disarmament often are made in consultation with the pollsters rather than consultation with its conscience.

Yet behind the rhetoric of the Government there is a clear direction to its foreign policy decisions and its peace policy. It is a government quietly shuffling towards neutrality and non-alignment, while all the time trying to hide its true intentions-intentions which lack public support-behind the veil of conservative rhetoric. This unspoken ambition of the Government needs to be understood by all Australians and needs to be rejected. The actions of the Government, not its words, reveal its underlying commitment to neutrality; only occasionally do its words actually reveal its actions. Thirteen years ago, during the famous roller-coaster years of the Whitlam Government, Mr Whitlam told the then British Prime Minister, Mr Heath, at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in London that his ambition was to make Australia the leader of the non-aligned movement. Such a fantastic and absurd ambition was dismissed at the time as arrogant nonsense. However, it was a guide to the Labor Party's true direction and, since 1983, that direction has resumed. One has only to look at a series of examples to show what the true direction is today of the Government's policy.

The centrepiece of the Government's Pacific policy, that region so vital to Australia's security, is a South Pacific zone of peace. The Government has introduced no other serious initiative in that region. Indeed, as far as I know, the Minister for Foreign Affairs has not strayed into the Pacific beyond Papua New Guinea and New Zealand. It is a region, however, which over the years has been a peaceful and successful region through the balance of power and effective deterrence. Australia almost exclusively has been the guardian of the interest of the Western alliance in the South Pacific. There are great dangers in that region-the buildup of the Soviet Navy, the use of Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam and instability in the Philippines. Yet, the Government has in effect turned its back and promoted only the South Pacific nuclear free zone. I regard that as a very clear example of the direction of the Government's foreign policy and its shuffling towards neutrality.

The approach to ANZUS and the whole issue of New Zealand and New Zealand's involvement in ANZUS, which has been well documented by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), is yet another example. On the part of the Government, it is a policy of negligence. Instead of going out to try to persuade New Zealand to support ANZUS and to support the security of the Western alliance in the region, the Government has done virtually nothing. It has been stunned into inertia by the club of the Left. We saw the same sort of approach by the Government on the MX missile issue where the Government refused to allow United States of America planes to refuel in Australia and denied beds to United States servicemen who wanted only rest and recreation in our country.

The Government has also pursued this shuffling towards neutrality in the United Nations. It voted for the nuclear freeze in the United Nations contrary to the position taken by nearly all other nations in the Western alliance. It denied that there was any danger of the United States having strategic inferiority to the Soviet Union, especially in the field of intermediate range nuclear weapons which, of course, presented a very real danger to the continent of Europe, particularly Western Europe. On another occasion the Minister for Foreign Affairs made the quite alarming statement that the United States bases in Australia would have to be withdrawn unless the United States Government made positive developments in the disarmament negotiations-a statement subsequently abandoned by the Foreign Minister but a statement which, however, revealed the true attitudes of this Government towards the United States and towards the whole issue of the Western alliance.

Closer to home, one can look also at the International Year of Peace program and the way that program is so far developing. There again, we can see a government which is not dramatically leaping to neutrality but a government which is shuffling in that direction. The publicly funded programs for the International Year of Peace are going to run up a bill of approximately $3m. This expenditure would appear to be designed once more to promote neutrality. In my own State of South Australia the so-called advisory council has now met and has put together a series of recommendations which have now gone to the Minister for approval. Amongst those recommendations is a proposal that taxpayers fund something described as a peace bus. The peace bus is to be manned by the People for Nuclear Disarmament-people whose whole attitude to the issue of defence, deterrence and international security is at variance with at least the rhetoric of the Government but perhaps is closer to the underlying theme of what the Government is about.

Similarly, there is to be a peace officer who doubtless will be employed to promote the interests and views of peace groups. We have the very controversial issue of peace studies being established and promoted through the education system. Once more, there is the very real danger that those peace studies will be used simply to promote one point of view, the point of view again of what some people describe as the peaceniks. However, the greatest failure of all by the Government so far in its approach to the International Year of Peace has been its failure to make a case for ANZUS and its failure to make a case for the Western alliance. It is letting support in this country for the Western alliance and ANZUS die through neglect just as it did in New Zealand.
Seventy per cent of Australians have been born since the Second World War. Few people in Australia now remember the world of the Cold War in the late 1940s and the 1950s.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you know about it?

—Few people remember the Korean War. Few, of course, would remember the Cuban missile crisis. It is true, of course, that I have no clear memory of the Korean War or the Cold War. However, unlike some honourable members opposite who choose to interrupt, I have at least taken the time to find out something about these times. However, for one reason or another, the vast majority of people in the Australian community may not be interested in these issues and the way they have developed. Consequently, when they look at the security institutions which evolved from these events-institutions such as ANZUS and the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation-they do not see those institutions as instruments of peace which is, of course, what effectively they are. There is an urgent need for the Government to go out into the Australian community as a government and explain the importance of the Western alliance, the importance of NATO and the importance of ANZUS so that the community knows that these things are not threats to its security and stability but are things that will guarantee and store up its stability and security.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike some of the peace groups and, I am afraid, some members of the Labor Party, we on this side of the House understand the obvious fact that nuclear weapons cannot be uninvented. Our starting point is a world with nuclear technology which must be harnessed to secure peace and prosperity, not unleashed to destroy mankind. They are the only practical options. There is no third option of a world without nuclear power and weapons. Such a situation will never exist again, desirable as some people think that may be. Unlike the Left of the Australian Labor Party, unlike some of the peace groups, we on this side of the House also understand that peaceful co-existence within our own shores demands the existence of a system of order, the rule of law, democratic institutions and so on. Internationally, peaceful co-existence also requires some sort of order. Attempts to establish order through supranational authorities such as the United Nations and the World Court have, of course, so far proved relatively ineffectual. Sadly, but realistically, the only tool available to maintain order between in particular the competing philosophies of liberal democracy, Marxism and militant Islam is deterrence. Unilateralism would destabilise the present delicate global order with potentially disastrous consequences. Effective deterrence, on the other hand, is based on a balance of power which leaves neither side or no side vulnerable to a pre-emptive strike. There is no doubt that it lead to substantial arms arsenals. Those arsenals are currently far too large and that is a cause for very great concern. However, it is not the large arsenals themselves which cause wars; it is a breakdown in international order. France and Britain, for example, co-existed between 1815 and 1914 with massive arsenals which, for most of that period, were directed towards each other. But they never fought each other in that period. Indeed, ironically, at the end of that period they ended up admittedly fighting but as allies on the same side. In other words, weapons are a symptom of tension between nations but they are not themselves a cause of that tension or a cause of war.

Disarmament is a necessary process if we are to redirect some of the $800 billion that is annually spent on weapons perhaps to assist developing countries, as was suggested by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore). However, agreement on a new order with a supranational authority may well be an impossible dream. Sadly, deterrence is the only alternative means to guarantee peace until that dream is realised. That is why ANZUS is so vastly important to Australia. That is why our isolated and vulnerable part of the world needs security ties with the United States. It is why we need the security of involvement in the Western alliance. They are the reasons those things are so vital to this country, and these are the messages that the Government should be propagating through the International Year of Peace. ANZUS and the Western alliance will secure our peace in this country; not a lot of phoney and naive policies that have been promoted by so-called peace groups and by the left wing of the Labor Party. These are the messages government-funded peace officers should be propagating through the community. These are the messages that peace studies in this country should be propagating, and these are the messages which should be persuasive in this country through this International Year of Peace. But, instead, those messages about the importance of ANZUS and the Western alliance have been ignored and the Government is surrendering our security in the interests of its policy of creeping towards neutrality.

No one would deny the statements of the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that Australia is apparently committed to ANZUS, that it is committed to the Western alliance. But when one looks at the actions of the Government, at the actual implementation of its policies over the last three years and during the period of the Whitlam Government, one can see that the true direction of the Government is towards neutrality, towards-perhaps in the years ahead-dragging Australia into something such as the non-aligned movement. That was Mr Whitlam's ambition when he was Prime Minister, an ambition which was greeted with horse laughs around the world, but an ambition which perhaps should be thought about and recognised by the community because I believe it is one of the underlying desires of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cross Mr M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting to follow the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) who was taking us down the track, as some of his colleagues did previously in this debate, of reflecting on the Labor Government's commitment to ANZUS and to the Western alliance. He suggested in the closing stages of his speech that we were going down the road towards neutrality, that we had some hidden objective that was behind the thrust of the Australian Labor Party activity over a considerable period. I suppose that one of the pertinent things he said was that there are a lot of people who were not around in the days of the Second World War and Korea, and through many of the things that happened in the days of the Cold War. It would not do any harm to remind the honourable member and the House that it was the Labor Party that established the American alliance.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a young boy in 1942 when John Curtin made that celebrated appeal, without any inhibitions, to the United States. The people on the same side of politics as the honourable member for Mayo criticised that approach to the United States by the Curtin Labor Government because in those days patriotism was determined by the British connection and not by the United States connection. John Curtin was attacked in this House by people on the coalition side who suggested that making an approach to the United States was in some way reducing our association with what was then called the British Commonwealth-and by some people the British Empire-and is now called the Commonwealth of Nations. At the end of the Second World War the Labor Government sought to bring about a Pacific pact. Initially there was a treaty between Australia and New Zealand. Then, for a considerable period, our very vigorous Minister for External Affairs, Dr H. V. Evatt, the then member for Barton, pursued with the United States the idea of a Pacific pact which would involve the United States and other Pacific countries. That Pacific pact idea was rejected by the United States-there being strong isolationist trends in the United States-and many people felt that America was going back to its pre-Second World War policies.

When the American Government decided to enter into what was then described as a soft peace treaty for Japan, it became necessary for America to come to arrangements with other Pacific nations in order to ensure that they would be protected against the resurgent Japan. ANZUS arose from that situation as did the pact between the United States and the Philippines and other arrangements. In whatever policy document one looks at from the various national conferences of the Australian Labor Party from that period and since that time, one sees that the Labor Government is committed to an association with the United States and New Zealand through ANZUS. We were sceptical about the South East Asian Treaty Organisation, the Manila pact, which was designed to contain communism in South East Asia. Whilst that pact is in place, the formal organisation disappeared more than a decade ago. Through all of that period the Labor Party has not only paid lip service, but also it has struggled vigorously to make the ANZUS pact a reality. That does not mean that we should be subservient to the United States; it means that we should be an equal partner in the alliance because however close our relations are with the United States, Britain, New Zealand and other countries, we have our own point of view, we have Australian interests to protect, and we have our own perspective.

So, there have been occasions when we have differed with the United States on the assessment of some particular situation, but our views have been conveyed to the United States discretely, and they have been treated with respect. It is one of those things which are obvious to those of us who have a great deal to do with both United States diplomats and visiting congressmen and serving personnel who have come to this country, or those of us who have gone to their country in recent times, that Australia's views are treated with respect, that this is very much an active alliance which means a great deal, not only to people in this country but also to people in the United States. Again, the same trend comes through from people on the other side when they talk about the recent decisions made by the New Zealand Government to reject visits by war ships which are either nuclear powered or nuclear armed. Of course it has been very clearly said by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) and by other Government spokespeople that Australia differs from New Zealand in regard to policy positions. We are asked to be the bully-boys in this situation, to interfere in the internal political processes of New Zealand and to try in some way to heavy the New Zealand Government into changing its policy. If we were-again I make it clear, as previous speakers on this side have, that the views of the Australian Government have been very clearly conveyed to the New Zealand Government over this period-to enter into internal New Zealand politics, any chance of the New Zealand Government altering its position on nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered ships would be made much more difficult because New Zealand does not see itself to be under the same threat from Asia as we have seen ourselves to be under many times in the past. New Zealand is a lot further away and, quite frankly, it has a different view towards the whole nuclear question because it is much closer to where the French are testing nuclear weapons in the Pacific. It would be quite wrong for Australia to go beyond what it has done within ordinary diplomatic circles.

Our activities in the Pacific have been misrepresented by the honourable member for Mayo and others. It was suggested that on the matter of peace we are reacting only to pollsters, that we are really about neutrality and non-alignment, and that there is something shoddy about the South Pacific zone of peace concept. I was interested in what the honourable member for Mayo had to say about the buildup of the Soviet Navy in the South Pacific. I must say that I have not heard of that. I have heard of the Soviet Navy being involved in Cam Ranh Bay. I have heard of Soviet fishing vessels being involved in parts of the South Pacific, and they are not alone in that. But I have not heard of any significant buildup of the Soviet Navy in the South Pacific, and I do not believe that there is such a buildup.

Our whole attitude towards the International Year of Peace has been canvassed. We have done a great deal about peace. I am proud to be a member of a Labor government which, on coming into office, normalised its relationship with the Soviet Union which was strained over the period of its intervention in Afghanistan. The Labor Party did not agree with the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan. It is perfectly obvious to us, as I think it is obvious to all thinking people, that if we are going to do something about winding down the nuclear stockpiles, the basic trust of that will come from some agreement and some accommodation between the two superpowers. We have normalised our relationship with the Soviet Union and we have used our very firm and friendly relationship with the United States to endeavour to influence the superpowers back to the discussion table. We know that during the last year that has happened and it is about to happen again in Geneva. It is a very worthwhile endeavour.

It is always easy to suggest that talking about peace is in some way unpatriotic or moving towards isolationism, neutrality or non-alignment. Comment has been made about $3m being devoted to activities to discuss peace initiatives in the present year, the International Year of Peace. It is suggested that some of that money is going to a peace bus, peace offices and the like and that instead government peace officers should go around, in effect, putting to the people of Australia the Government's attitude towards the ANZUS Treaty and towards our connection with the Western community of nations and the like. We would have no credibility if we did that alone. During this period, just as throughout the period of this Government, the Labor Party will be putting its strong commitment to the Western alliance and ANZUS and will be continuing our commitment to deterrence. At the same time, there is nothing wrong in encouraging discussion on peace. We are not a militarist country. We are not a neutralist country. In fact, one of the things in which the Labor Government can take great pride is the fact that we have steadily increased the amount of resources devoted to defence. We have given a lot of attention to many of the very severe problems in that area which we inherited from our predecessors.

I believe that the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs was a balanced statement about the achievements of this Government since March 1983. I pay tribute to the Foreign Minister for the dedication that he has shown and the hard work that he has done throughout the world, but in particular in our region, in making personal contact with Ministers for Foreign Affairs, other politicians and prominent people in public life in order that Australia might have a more vigorous and a better informed foreign policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —All the Opposition does is criticise.

—That is right. Without any doubt, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden), as Minister for Foreign Affairs, has been one of the most dynamic Ministers for Foreign Affairs that we have had. I remember that during the last debate we had of this kind the Minister was criticised for spending so much time abroad. I am cognisant of the fact that the Premier of Queensland, the Honourable Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, has criticised him from time-to-time for spending time overseas when he should be at home. It is funny but the Minister for Foreign Affairs has a particular function to travel overseas if he is to live in the real world. There was some comment in the previous debate about the fact that he had not gone to the Pacific as much as he should have.
