I note from the material that was circulated to us earlier in the week that he proposes to make a comprehensive tour of the Pacific later this year. That is typical of his previous activity. I believe that the document that was put before us last November-the speech that the Minister for Foreign Affairs made-indicates that Australia, with its traditional associations, is playing a constructive role within its own country, in our region and throughout the world. I am very proud and happy to be a supporter of a Labor Government which is playing such a constructive role.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I wish to take this opportunity, which is my first opportunity of doing so, to congratulate you, Madam Speaker, on your election as Speaker. That is sincere. We share electorate boundaries. We share the city of Caulfield. I think it is fair to say that notwithstanding our different approaches to politics we serve the people of Caulfield in a bipartisan way. I look forward to continuing to work with you in that regard. I noted your comments when you took this high office that you would be fair and impartial-I have confidence that you will be-and I also look forward to your future definitions of the word `relevance' as contained in the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) last year, I say at the outset that there has been some speculation as to whether the Minister wishes to continue as Minister for Foreign Affairs or whether there is to be a reshuffle and he will be transferred to a domestic portfolio. I am sure that not knowing whether the Minister who made the statement which we are debating will continue in that office does create some uncertainty in our international relations.

I open my comments on the debate itself by referring to the ANZUS alliance. I commence by referring to a report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which was a bipartisan report, although subject to a minority report on one aspect, tabled in this place in 1982. The report stated:

The Committee would emphasise, also, that the security links between Australia and the United States spring from shared values, compatible institutions and objectives and continuing popular support within the Australian community for ANZUS and the wider Western Alliance.

I think that those comments in that report sum up the importance of the relationship with the United States of America and New Zealand under that ANZUS alliance. Let us look at the words `shared values'. They mean democratic institutions, parliaments, equality and freedom before the law-values that too often in this country we take for granted. We fail to realise that so many other nations do not have those values. They are very important shared values. They mean compatible institutions, parliaments, legal systems and independent judiciaries. They are very important. That is what the Western alliance is about.

Many people in this country feel that Australia is a new country. In one sense, it is. We are coming up to celebrating 200 years of European occupation at the Bicentenary. I point out that we are, I think, the sixth oldest democracy in the world. The only European countries that have a continuous democracy in the sense that we have, in the form of this Parliament, are the United Kingdom, Sweden and Switzerland. Every other constitution in Europe is newer than Australia's. I think that we should be proud of that democratic tradition and background. It is one of those shared values about which I talked.

The ANZUS Treaty is central to Australia's security. It is fundamental to it. I see it as part of the total umbrella of our membership of the Western alliance. Under the ANZUS Treaty, relations, and good relations, with the United States are critical. This Government is operating at two levels. Outwardly, the Government is trying to say that all is well with the United States alliance, but underneath this all is not well. I think that the United States must be concerned, as I am, about the influence of the Left in the decision-making process of this Government. As I said, the Government is operating at two levels. On the surface it has one stance, one position. It is a government of appearances and false perceptions. It is very much a government of public relations and of trying to manipulate and manage the media. Outwardly, it is giving a pretence of support and friendship to the United States, but underneath, in its decisions, one can see that it gives in to the factionalism of the Left. I refer to the Government's decisions, or lack of decisions, on the strategic defence initiative of the United States-its failure to support the strategic modernisation program of the United States-and its withdrawal from participation in the testing of the MX missile, but I will come to that later.

It would also prove my point to say that the Government should have taken an initiative with New Zealand when New Zealand took its position on the visits of United States nuclear ships and on nuclear weapons opposite the United States. Australia should have acted as a friend of both the United States and New Zealand, and mediated. Australia should have sent a signal. We should have tried to seek a solution to the difficulties between New Zealand and the United States. We have had an admission by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that ANZUS is no longer operative and we have this pretence that New Zealand's withdrawal makes no difference. That is not so. Instability is being created in the Pacific region as a result of New Zealand's actions and the failure of the Australian Government to do anything about them-failure to take an initiative and failure to mediate. This picture that I have just painted adds up to a failure by this Government to give a total commitment to the shared values which I mentioned earlier and which underpin our relations with the United States and the Western alliance. This Government fails to give a vision or to have any picture of Australia's role in that Western alliance and what it should be.

As I said, the Prime Minister's admission that ANZUS is no longer operative is an admission of failure and of failure to act. The resultant vacuum which has been created and the instability which has arisen from this failure to act have led to a Soviet buildup in the Pacific and an increasing Soviet presence there. That is very dangerous indeed and I am sure that it is just what the Soviet Union wants. I quote the defence adviser to the Government, Mr Paul Dibb, who said last year:

The Soviet Union would like to see the ANZUS Alliance system disrupted in its favour and the close relationship that has developed between Australia, New Zealand and the United States with the ASEAN countries and with the nations of Oceania destroyed. The importance of ANZUS to the USSR needs to be clearly understood . . .

Mr Paul Dibb is now an adviser to the Government and what he referred to in that statement has actually happened. The Soviet Union must be laughing to see the ANZUS alliance system disrupted. That is exactly what has happened as a result of New Zealand's actions and as a result of the failure of this Government to take any initiatives or to do anything about them.

I referred earlier to the MX decision of the Government in which the Prime Minister caved in and capitulated to the Left of his own Party, to the anti-United States element within it. He reneged on a commitment to the United States Government to offer refuelling facilities in, I think, New South Wales. The US Government intended to test these missiles and send planes out to monitor the tests, and we refused to let it land aircraft in Australia. We refused to allow the crews of those aircraft to have accommodation.

We also have refused to endorse President Reagan's strategic modernisation program. This is a very important program because it was intended by President Reagan to counter the Soviet superiority in nuclear weapons. It was an attempt to restore the balance and to give deterrence to the United States. It also was intended as a general Western deterrence against the Soviet Union. Here we have another back-out by the Prime Minister, who failed to endorse the strategic modernisation program during a visit to the United States. In fact, he had a couple of lines endorsing the program taken out of the joint communique. This strategic modernisation program is a fundamental strategic policy of the United States. How embarrassing it is for an Australian Prime Minister at the last minute to back out of an endorsement of this important policy which is basic to Western security.

The strategic defence initiative is yet another case. We failed to support that; in fact, we have not replied to United States Defense Secretary Weinberger's invitation to participate. We have failed to recognise that the Soviets have their own version of a strategic defence initiative and we have failed to give support to the United States. We have failed miserably. Is this what the Australian people want? Is this in the interests of Australia? Is it in the interests of the shared values of the Western alliance? Of course not. It is a dangerous course of action that this Government has undertaken and is embarking upon. As I said, it is outrageous and negligent that the Government has not responded to Defence Secretary Weinberger's invitation to participate, which was issued last year. If we did participate, it would give us some influence with the United States and would enable us to keep up with the latest defence technology. Also, we might benefit financially by having Australian firms participate.

Recently, we have had a comment from Senator Gareth Evans that the Government would close down the North West Cape base if it thought that that had a first strike capability. This is the scene of relations with the United States, relations with Washington, at present under this Government. It is outrageous. Yet, on this very day, I believe, the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) is in the United States trying to negotiate with the United States Administration on the United States farm Bill. Here we have a government on the one hand taking these anti-United States actions to which I have referred and then on the other hand going to Washington cap in hand and saying `Please help the Australian farmers'. Is the Government's attitude to the United States in the interests of Australian farmers at this time of crisis? Of course it is not. We keep on criticising the United States and failing to stand up for those shared values that I have mentioned. We keep failing to support the United States in its fundamental policies, such as strategic modernisation and strategic defence initiative, on the one hand; yet, on the other, we expect the American Administration to help us when we run into difficulties with United States legislation. I give credit to the United States that it has not raised that point. That is fair enough and the United States deserves to be congratulated.

In relation to the US farm Bill, I believe that it is imperative for the Australian Government to act by sending an all-party parliamentary delegation to Washington to lobby the Congress on possible changes to that Bill. If there is any possibility of Congress changing the farm Bill, individual United States congressmen and senators must be aware of Australia's interests. One important way of doing that is to send a parliamentary delegation. In the matter of foreign affairs, relations between parliaments-in this case between the United States Congress and the Australian Parliament-are very important. The previous speaker mentioned that there had been a number of visits by United States delegations. I think there have been three visits by separate United States delegations to Australia in the last few weeks, but there have been none from here to the United States. It is very important that Australian parliamentarians should go to the United States, to Capitol Hill, to lobby and to put the Australian point of view.

The fact that United States senators and congressmen had little understanding of the United States farm Bill's impact on Australia when it was debated shows a real need for closer links between this Parliament and the United States Congress. It also shows how inadequate this Government's efforts have been in promoting Australia's interests on Capitol Hill. The fact that the Trade Minister is now trying to minimise the effects of that Bill on our primary industry is evidence of the Government's failure to take proper action and to make proper representations at the time that Bill was being debated in the United States. It is very important that Australian parliamentarians should go to Washington on behalf of Australian farmers to put their point of view.

I refer now to the situation in the Philippines. It is in the interests of both Australia and the region that we have a stable government in the Philippines. It is too early to predict the outcome of the election. Events there must be of concern. I criticise the Government for its failure to send an observer team to the Philippines elections. That was negligent of the Foreign Minister. It was very dangerous. I believe that the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-a distinguished committee of both Houses of this Parliament-could well have sent an observer team. It wanted to do so, but the Government refused to make funds available.

I also wish to refer to the attack by the Foreign Minister on the Government of the Philippines in November last year. I think that the Minister was being very dangerous. He embarked on a dangerous course of action because as a result of that-this received little publicity-the Marcos Government has ensured that the Royal Australian Air Force will be denied access to Clark Field, which is the big United States air base in the Philippines. That is very dangerous. I understand that the RAAF does not use Clark Field very often at this stage, but the implications are enormous because there is one other United States base facility-the Subic Bay naval base-which is very important to the Australian Navy for refuelling and for taking part in joint exercises. It is very important that we have access to that as part of our activities in this region. I believe that the statement by the Foreign Minister has jeopardised Australia's relations with the Philippines. If the Marcos Government continues in office in the Philippines, we are prejudiced. Currently we are denied the use of Clark Field and we are placing at risk the ability of the Australian Navy to use the Subic Bay facility--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. Before I call the next speaker, I wish to thank the honourable member for Higgins for the comments he made. We have worked closely together, in harmony and friendship, and I am sure that we will continue to do so. Just to throw one more stone into the pool on relevancy, let me say that the honourable member might cast his mind back to several times in the House when we have had a very narrow debate on a Bill on dried fruit or wheat and honourable members have been able to persuade the Chair that, although they are talking about bluefin tuna fishing or sugar cane, they are in fact being relevant to the Bill. It is a matter of opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, as this is the first occasion on which I have spoken since your election, might I add my congratulations to the many you have received. I think we have seen already that you are a woman not only of charm but of steel. I believe you will handle the deliberations of this House wonderfully well for a long time to come. In addressing my remarks to the statement we are debating, might I also congratulate the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) on what I believe is a very wide-ranging and sensitive exposition of Australian interests and foreign policy which shows a genuine understanding of the complexity and delicacy of relationships in a disordered world, and a genuine understanding of Australian interests and the concerns of the Australian people and how those interests and concerns might be advanced and protected in that world. The statement also is a record of genuine progress in giving effect and expression to those concerns of Australians. Apropos of some remarks made earlier in this debate, the statement is written in English, which is a welcome change from some of the turgid monstrosities one has seen put down in the past passing for statements of Australian policy. In all, I believe the statement repays reading, and I believe the Minister is to be congratulated on it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are certain issues on which I would like to concentrate. The first of those is not one I would have chosen initially to address, but since every Opposition speaker has alluded to it in a kind of crude and insensitive way I thought I should at least begin by talking of ANZUS. Their problem with the ANZUS Treaty is that the coalition parties have regarded it for so long as their private property that it is difficult for them to come to terms with the fact that the stewardship of ANZUS is now in the very best of hands. I noticed that one of the speakers on the Opposition side, the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman), spoke of the attitude of the Australian Government to the difficulties with New Zealand as being, in his words, to `cool it'. For my part, I believe that is a very reasonable approach at this stage. There is nothing the Opposition would like better than to exacerbate and provoke a conflict within this important relationship, to its detriment and to the detriment of all those peoples who depend on it.

The use by the honourable member for Wentworth of that phrase `cool it' reminded me of a letter I received just yesterday. It is a copy of a letter sent by a bipartisan group of United States senators to the President of the United States and to the Prime Minister of New Zealand. The signatories to that letter are Democratic senators David Boren of Oklahoma, John Glenn of Ohio, Albert Gore of Tennessee and Sam Nunn of Georgia and Republican senators Warren Rudman of New Hampshire and John Warner-the former husband of Elizabeth Taylor-of Virginia. They addressed themselves to this very problem of relations with New Zealand arising out of New Zealand's policy towards the visits of nuclear warships. They ended by saying:
While trying to resolve the dispute, ``as they say in the vernacular, `let's cool it for a while,' and pull back from the precipice. Let's try again to find a way out,''
I might add that the letter is addressed not to the Prime Minister of Australia but to the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of New Zealand.

It is perfectly clear that Australia disagrees with the New Zealand policy. It says so in those words, in the statement we are debating. We disagree with the policy New Zealand is following. That is not to say that we believe the best way to resolve the problem is to provoke the kind of confrontation which members of the Liberal Party would wish us to do and which they were very good at in their time in government. One has only to remember Vietnam to see how much they felt that a punch-up was the best way of resolving situations which are much better resolved by quiet diplomacy. If that amounts to benign neglect then I add that greater statesmen even than my good friend the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) have followed policies of benign neglect to the ultimate benefit of the situation they were handling.

It is not widely remembered that the first government in this part of the world to ban visits by nuclear-powered vessels was the Australian Government. I refer to the Liberal Government led by Billy McMahon, which in 1971 banned visits by nuclear-powered vessels. It did so for reasons which I think many Australians would have understood at the time. There was not an adequate safety regime, for one thing, and there was not an adequate compensation regime for another. Nevertheless, that ban stayed in effect for, I would say, about four years. It did not lead to the end of the ANZUS alliance and it was amicably resolved. This attempt to blow up the current difficulties within the ANZUS relationship into some kind of major crisis is one which the Government rejects, which I reject, and which I believe will be capably handled by the approach which the United States senators from both sides of politics have urged on the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of New Zealand, namely, to cool it and try to find a solution. I believe that solution will be found.

I turn now to some other questions of great importance which are addressed in the Minister's statement. The first of those concerns Australia's relationship with the Association of South East Asian Nations. That relationship, I notice, has not been mentioned by any honourable member opposite but it is a cornerstone of this Government's approach to affairs in our region, and, indeed, more widely. It is a matter of some pride to me that that relationship was first formalised by a previous Labor Government when Mr Whitlam, as Foreign Minister, instituted a system of consultations with the states of ASEAN and with ASEAN as an entity, and that relationship has continued and grown stronger since. We need to remember that the ASEAN region is one of great economic vitality and one where great progress is being made. It is a region which will continue to surround us, whether we like it or not, from now to the end of time. It is important to get it right with ASEAN.

Within Australia there is widespread and justified concern at the situation which now unfortunately obtains in the Philippines. I personally have a great deal of sympathy with the Filipino people. I spent three years there, indeed, I was married while in the Philippines. I share that great sympathy which there is in the Australian community with the poverty and misery of many of the Filipino people, with the denials of human rights and the abuses of ordinary people by various groups in the Philippines-which are well documented, I might add, by the Amnesty group.

The Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kooyong, accused the Government of inaction in relation to the Philippines. That is a charge I reject. Only last year the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence set up an inquiry into ASEAN, and I am privileged to be chairman of that inquiry. We have received a large number of submissions from people in the Australian community, from a wide variety of groups and individuals, including the substantial Filipino community in Australia, which numbers over 20,000 people. The Committee will be conducting hearings in capital cities over the course of the next couple of months at which ordinary Australians and concerned people generally can express their views. I might add that that is an indication of the fact that as a government we are not scared to expose our policies to widespread discussion in Australia. We are not scared to listen and we are not scared to consult, nor are we scared to stand up for certain values in our dealings with other countries. I think it is clear that those values are expressed very well in the statement by the Foreign Minister when he mentions his concern at the deteriorating situation in the Philippines. He said that there was dissatisfaction with the political and economic record of the Marcos Government, that there were human rights abuses by some organs of the Government and extensive economic injustice resulting from its inaction with regard to the privileges and the political powers of its wealthy oligarchic patrons. One cannot be clearer than that. We would be wise to recognise that the situation in the Philippines has led to great problems and that in many ways the result of the recent election, or perhaps the non-result, could lead to the worst of all possible worlds. There have been widespread allegations of fraud and intimidation of voters at the stealing of the election, as it has been termed by Mrs Aquino.

I believe that we shall have to display great sympathy for, forbearance with and concern for the Philippines over the weeks to come. I believe that whichever contender emerges as victor from the current process will need to bring about as rapidly as possible some very considerable changes in the social and economic situation of the poverty stricken masses in the Philippines if that country is to have a future which is not very depressing and is not anarchic. The Filipino people deserve much better than that.

I turn to a couple of other subjects. I was very pleased to see the emphasis given in the Minister's statement to relations with China. Again, that is something which has not been mentioned by any member of the Opposition who has spoken in this debate so far. I believe that the Australian Labor Party, both in and out of government, deserves credit for its non-ideological approach to foreign affairs which has borne great fruit. Let us not forget that for 23 years, from 1949, when the revolution succeeded in China, to 1972, successive coalition governments treated China as though it did not exist. It was not until the Labor Government, very early in the piece in 1972, recognised the Chinese Government that the very fruitful relationship we now have with China was brought into being. That was something the Opposition criticised.

I remember that when Mr Whitlam went to China in 1971, Mr McMahon, that great exponent of foreign policy, said that Chou En-lai had played Mr Whitlam like a fisherman plays a trout. I will maintain silence on that comment except to say that very shortly afterwards it emerged that Henry Kissinger was in China at the very same time arranging a visit by President Nixon. To say that Mr McMahon had egg on his face is an understatement.

It is now the case that we have a very firm relationship with China. For the first time, bilateral trade with China topped $1 billion this year. We consult with the Chinese on a great number of questions. The visit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) last year was a great success. I believe that we shall see further benefits of a political and economic kind flowing from that visit.

That leads me to mention very briefly in the time left to me the question of Indo-China. I very much commend the active policy of personal involvement by the Foreign Minister in the search for a peaceful solution to the problem in Kampuchea. The situation in that country has resulted in misery for hundreds of thousands of people. It has produced, amongst other things, the great flow of refugees to this country and others. It has caused continued instability in the Indo-Chinese region and increased entanglements by the super-powers which our country, along with many others, does not wish to see. It is a thankless task to try to get the parties together to resolve this exceedingly difficult problem, and the Minister has not received too much in the way of thanks for the efforts he has made. I commend those efforts, and I believe we have to recognise that progress will be slow, but in my view, it would be criminal for us to abandon those efforts towards a peaceful solution in Indo-China, and I do not believe we are about to do so.

I have not been able to mention the great question of disarmament, which, quite rightly, is the first priority of this Government or the response which this Government has made to the Gorbachev initiatives which, again, I believe, are commendable and right; nor have I been able to expand on my pleasure at seeing the place given to economic questions in the Minister's statement, which are easily some of the most important questions in an increasingly economically interdependent world. However, my colleague the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) covered that subject extremely adequately in his address. I conclude by saying that I believe that this statement is one of the best expositions of foreign policy that I have seen put down in this Parliament. I commend the Minister and I commend the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I commence by joining other members of this House in congratulating you on your elevation to your exalted office and wish you well in it. I am surprised that a man as well versed in the art of diplomacy as the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) should have found nothing to criticise in the statement put down by his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). As we know, the honourable member for Kingston was a distinguished representative of Australia in several diplomatic posts; yet he has found nothing to criticise in the statement put down by his colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I believe he should at least have noted that the Hawke Government took office in March 1983 and it was not until 26 November 1985 that it produced a comprehensive statement on foreign policy. It took about 2 1/2 years to produce a comprehensive statement. In a sense, the statement proved quite successful because it attracted very little interest and it had little quality which would attract continuing reference.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem for the Government in foreign policy is that it has always attracted the ideological Left-that body of anti-Americanism in Australian politics which has its base in the Australian Labor Party. At the Labor Party Conference of 1982-a conference that was chaired by the present Foreign Minister-the Left of the Labor Party was vigorous in committing Australia to a foreign policy bias in support of Vietnam but very critical of the Association of South East Asian Nations and of any resistance to Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia. The Foreign Minister came to his office with a type of diplomacy that required him to import that bias into our relations with South East Asia. He set about that business, attacking in the process, United States policy, Thailand, Malaysia, Japan's self-defence decisions and, of course, he added criticisms of Britain. This was the diplomat whom the honourable member for Kingston has seen fit to praise so highly.

The honourable member mentioned that no honourable member on this side of the House had brought into the discussion any reference to ASEAN. The sheer fact is that the Foreign Minister, in his early days in his job, put Australia's relationship with ASEAN under very great strain indeed because in the context of criticism of friends, he portrayed Vietnam in the best light, apparently with the intent of inducing Vietnam to change direction. It is very clear that any diplomatic efforts to improve relations with Vietnam would have gone off more smoothly if the Minister had not chosen at the same time to attack Australia's friends in and outside the region. Naturally enough, that process is not referred to in the Minister's statement. He merely says and to a degree quite misleadingly:
From the outset of its time in office, the Government has invested the highest possible energy and resources to the development of Australia's relations with all its neighbours.

In the last few days, we have seen how our Treasurer (Mr Keating) and Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are trying to avoid facing up to the reality of the effect of the Hawke Government's economic decisions over the past years. They are doing this by blaming the Fraser Government for the nation's woes. Perhaps they are trying to copy the Vietnamese who continue to blame the `30 years of war' for the economic failures of their administration since 1975.

Efforts have been made to get Australia to give foreign aid to Vietnam on the basis of that argument. The fact is that Vietnam has an agricultural economy geared to producing basic food, particularly rice. The Vietnamese have had a disastrous policy of collective agriculture. Collectivisation of agriculture has never worked in any country in the world, and the program has had to be modified even to achieve sluggish results. In that context the Soviet Union gives aid to the amount of $1 billion a year and, in return, ties Vietnam into the Soviet defence net. The permanent basing of Soviet submarines and air power at Cam Ranh Bay and Da Nang justifies, from a Soviet viewpoint, financial support of Vietnam. It was always a piece of naivete for the Foreign Minister to argue in this House that Australia should try to create the conditions for Vietnam to turn aside from her dependence on the Soviet Union.

It is clear that Vietnam's effectiveness in overcoming international resistance to its penetration into Cambodia and Laos enhanced the growth of Soviet influence. The failure of the Australian Government to appreciate this point led it to question, in a public and most undiplomatic manner, the wisdom of a policy of resistance to Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia. The Minister sought to exploit differences of approach in ASEAN about the handling of this problem. Differences about the direction of ASEAN policy do exist, but there was never an ASEAN interest in betraying the basic position that Vietnamese policy had to be resisted. The position in the statement before the House is as follows:
The Australian Government has condemned Vietnam's invasion of Cambodia and will continue to do so.
That is a welcome statement after the somewhat hair-raising experiences ASEAN and the United States went through during the first year of this Government's flirtation with Vietnam.

In the Pacific the Government has revised its earlier position which was critical of the Fraser Government's emphasis on building relations with that region. Our foreign aid program under the Fraser Government was upgraded and great attention was paid to supporting the Pacific Forum's concerns about nuclear testing and its acute interest in a ratification of the Law of the Sea Convention. That the aid priorities of the Fraser Government, criticised by the early Hawke views, were not misplaced is evident today and is evident from the statement before the House. The Opposition has been very cautious towards the Government's push for a nuclear free zone. Having stirred up expectations, the Labor Government pushed aside the more cautious views of certain key leaders in the Pacific states. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty was designed, quite simply, as a sop to the left wing and it is argued, but it is scarcely credible, that it may deflect France from its course of testing in the Pacific. It may have been a worthwhile sop to the Left, but one can bet one's bottom dollar that the agitation in the New Zealand Labour Party is to push for a treaty which does for the Pacific what New Zealand policy does for New Zealand. Certainly, the reported Soviet attitude that the Treaty does not go far enough is a message that the powerful New Zealand Left would agree with.

The fact is that the Soviet Union has a deliberate policy to debilitate United States influence in the Pacific. We all know of the world significance of the United States Pacific fleet. It must cover the south-about route to the Middle East, where American power is, of course, of enormous consequence. We know too that instability in the Philippines is causing some real attention and concern to be given to the durability of the United States bases there. Following a Soviet naval buildup, the Soviet Union is matching United States Pacific fleet capability. Whilst Soviet base facilities in Vietnam are growing in importance and Soviet political influence in the South West Pacific is increasing, the United States is being put under political pressure by countries such as New Zealand and by the Left in this Labor Government.

The problem for the United States in the Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is that, if it were to be adopted by the island governments of the United States territories in the Pacific, it could create difficulties for a fall-back to those territories were the United States to lose rights in the Philippines. There is a clear risk, therefore, that the Treaty could pressure the United States into falling back to Honolulu. It is in this context that the decision of the last Australian Labor Party Conference to curtail US interest in increasing the use of Cockburn Sound must be seen. The decision of the ALP Conference is thus a deliberate decision by the Hawke Government to narrow United States options in the event of United States failure to keep open bases in the Philippines.

Let us now turn to the New Zealand decision on nuclear ships. It is abundantly clear that New Zealand is inadequately informed of Australian public reaction to its decision to render ineffective the full application of the ANZUS Treaty. New Zealand seeks to place great importance on upgrading relations with Australia as a substitute. Clearly, Australians are basically very strong in their view that ANZUS is basic to the security system of the Pacific. Australians are not happy with a situation in which New Zealand action is quite positively opening the door for an increase in Soviet influence in the Pacific region at a time when the United States position is under pressure. Australians generally are of the view that instability follows an increase in Soviet influence as night follows day.

Australians I speak to are increasingly angry at the fact that the only consequence of New Zealand's position is a dangerous one. It weakens the basic solidarity of the South Pacific with the United States, in a changing world favouring the growth of Soviet power. New Zea- landers, it must be said, live in an unreal world if they misread the impact of their decision on Australia. We should point out that there is a powerful congressional interest in these developments. At the beginning of the year the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence was host to a group from both sides of Congress which expressed serious apprehension about the New Zealand policy. We all know that there are considerable pressures on Congress to raise further barriers to agricultural imports which could seriously affect imports from Australia and New Zealand. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) is in Washington at the moment, exercising an influence to minimise the effects of congressional protection pressure on Australian primary exports. In this, of course, he has the lively support of all Australians.

The prospects for New Zealand to be well received in the corridors of power obviously must look pretty grim. Certainly most Australians accept and support with sincerity the grave obligations the United States has accepted on behalf of the free world to oppose the spread of Soviet power and influence. We want nothing better than that New Zealand should appreciate the relevance of New Zealand in the support that Australia is able to give to the United States and the significance of United States efforts to stabilise the power equation in the Middle East. It cannot be effective in the Middle East if, in the Pacific, it is distracted and its reputation impugned by a former friend and ally.

The United States has had to tough out a very serious bid by the Soviets, under the leadership preceding Gorbachev, to dissolve American counter-response to the Soviet missile buildup in Europe. Since the change of Soviet leadership, prospects for an intelligent dialogue on arms reduction with the Soviet Union have opened up. The Australian Government should react wisely, I believe, to these developments, with neither a loose optimismn or an unreal scepticism. The Government should be more forthcoming in support of United States policy to research the strategic defence initiative. We have seen left wing elements and, sadly, the Australian Democrats in this Parliament try to blame the United States for any lack of progress in arms control negotiations. It is unreal to believe the United States should accept at face value any offers made by the Soviets. The critics of the United States seem to take that view. We are all deeply concerned about the accumulation of nuclear power, no matter which side of politics we stand on. One positive aspect is that the Soviet people likewise are deeply concerned and we should not despair of the fact that the popular demand for arms control will give rise to a demand for rational negotiations in the East, just as it has in the West. Recent moves by the Soviet Union to negotiate arms reduction at the highest level have raised hopes that the prospect for negotiations is brighter in the future than it has been in the recent past.

I draw honourable members' attention to the positive developments in South Asia. Under wise leadership-the new Indian Prime Minister, Mr Rajiv Gandhi is conspicuous in this regard-a new regional association has been formed. It includes India and Pakistan as well as the other regional powers and it could prove to be of enormous significance to the stability of the area. In Africa there have been grave problems. The loss of so many lives to famine has been paralleled by great cruelties which have been visited on the people of Uganda. There is, of course, the potential for deepening strife in South Africa as that nation adjusts to the necessity to bring itself to rid the country of apartheid.

I mention one other point at this stage-that is, that the concept of an independent foreign policy in an alliance framework is a contradiction in terms. We are an aligned nation. We have not moved away from that proposition. What we seek and should seek to do is to think through situations and bring the force of independent judgment to them. But we cannot be both independent and aligned. We must bring that independent judgment to bear in the context of our alignment. I think the Foreign Minister tends to blur that situation in his statements on those points.

I believe the statement is useful. When I was shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs I was continually calling for the Government to bring forward a statement on foreign policy that could be debated. The Foreign Minister, to his credit, has learned from his period in office. He was an utter disaster during those first 18 months, but time has mellowed him a little. Unhappy experiences have proved instructive for him. I welcome at least the fact that the Government, at long last, has brought forward a statement which has given this House the opportunity to bring its attention to an area which is of extreme importance to the future of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I congratulate you on your election to your elevated and esteemed position. I sincerely welcome this opportunity to speak today to the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in this House on 26 November 1985. I welcome it for a variety of reasons, not the least of which is that the statement summarises very clearly the reasons for Australia's growing stature as a middle order nation on the international stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's international policies under this Hawke Labor Government and this Minister have led us further towards our correct place in international influence and, indeed, lifted our international self-esteem, security and sovereignty. The Hawke Labor Government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs have also moved us further towards a significant role in the development of peace far more quickly and far more substantially than has any other Australian government before it. The recognition of these developments and the growing pride and self-respect as a result of them are held not only by those on this side of the House. Despite what we have heard throughout this debate from those opposite, privately many of the more reasonable members on the other side will also acknowledge it. I hope that those who follow in this debate have the integrity to display their true feelings here today. More importantly, I know that the vast majority of Australians respect the actions of this Government and this Minister. Our international policies and actions are one of the major reasons for this Government's electoral popularity and a significant indicator for those opposite to heed-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.

INTERJECT.PARA: A quorum not being present and the bells having been rung-

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! A quorum not being present, the chair will be resumed at 8 p.m.
—A quorum is present.

—The Minister in his statement declared the two paramount objectives of this Government in foreign policy: Firstly, in a highly volatile world it will protect and promote our security and our social and economic well-being; secondly, through this primary objective it will pursue a determined and independent role for Australia in the search for world order, peace and prosperity. By any comparison with previous conservative governments we are visibly and constantly achieving these objectives. However, our voice should be stronger because we are a privileged nation among nations. With justification, we can pride ourselves on the peace, democracy and prosperity we enjoy as a nation and a community. Compared with virtually any other country on this planet we have the greatest freedom not only to be a strong middle order nation but also to be a true leader in the vanguard of efforts for peace and international prosperity. Unfortunately, because of the extremist and subservient policies of decades of conservative governments in this country, our population has been conditioned to hide in our weaknesses rather than to explore our strengths for international peace and development. It is the responsibility of all Australians, through this Government, to accept this responsibility from our privileged position. I do not believe that we have done so yet, so I ask the House and all Australians to consider seriously this picture and the contrasts which can be drawn clearly from it.

SPEECH.PARA: Annual world military spending is of the order of $800,000m. The economies of both the United States and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics are dependent upon their military spending, development and industries. Each of those superpowers and other major league militarist nations use peace and war to the same economic ends. It is their military spending which effectively kills millions of people every year without a shot being fired. People die before every tank, plane or other piece of military equipment leaves the assembly line of the factory in the USSR, United States, France, China or wherever. In the International Year of Peace Australians should consider that for every 100,000 humans on this earth there are 556 soldiers but only 85 doctors. Let us remember also that those doctors are not spread evenly around the world but are concentrated in those wealthy countries which amass those great armies against each other. Across the world, on average, every soldier costs $20,000 annually, yet only $380 is spent on every school-age child.

The international trade in arms trebled between 1968 and 1982-a mere 14 years. Someone is paying for this, but who? The people who are paying for the arms trade and the military spending in the world today are the 800 million human beings living daily in the most dire poverty; the 870 million who cannot read or write; the 500 million who are out of work; the 130 million children without access to primary school. In fact, 2,000 million-about half the world's population-do not have access to a safe water supply, some to any water at all; 450 million live in daily hunger and malnutrition; and every year 12 million babies-virtually the population of this country-die before their first birthday. That is what the International Year of Peace is all about. What are the answers of the Australian people to those statistics? What are the answers of the members of the Opposition-the Cold War warriors, the raving Rambos-to those statistics? We have not heard them answer those statistics today and we are not likely to. Figures of that magnitude numb our minds and hearts. Eight hundred million people in dire poverty and 12 million babies dying before their first birthday are just printed figures until we put faces to those figures-our own faces and those of our children.

The Opposition members come in here one after another and get up and rattle their sabres and wave their flags. They are as empty in their foreign policy, their disarmament and peace policies as they are in their domestic policies. They will need to do a lot more than put a new coat of paint on their headquarters in Barton-the headquarters that look like a gatehouse to the American Embassy-to dress up their act in this country. If we strip away the flags and uniforms, the minds of those in the Kremlin, the White House and the Pentagon and other militarists are all the same. The abuse of power by the superpowers of the world must be curtailed. People today will listen to Opposition members from one end of this debate to the other and will hear time and time again the `commies under the bed' routine and the `must be ready for war to keep the peace' routine, but not one real attempt to reduce effectively arms production and expenditure.

Members opposite talk about international terrorism and most recently have focused on the madness of Libya. All that we see as international terrorism today is totally insignificant compared with the international terrorism of the United States, the USSR and their accomplices. What is real terrorism: A gang of extremists hijacking and killing 20 travellers or a nation invading another for strategic, religious or economic gain? What is the more despicable form of terrorism: To gun down people in an airport; for the United States for years, day after day, to drop bombs and napalm on children in Vietnam, children they never saw; to lay mines in the harbour of a country such as Nicaragua to break up its economy; or for the USSR to use chemical and other weapons in Afghanistan in a similar indiscriminate fashion? Opposition members deliberately took part in that war in Vietnam, that terrorism. They are just as much terrorists as Gaddafi, the Red Brigade or any other terrorist because day after day they condone the actions of the United States. Their condemnation of the USSR is not balanced foreign policy. I do not condone those actions of the United States, nor do I condone in any way the barbarism of the USSR in Afghanistan or elsewhere.

The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) said that he could not remember the Korean War or the Cold War, but he said he had read a lot about them. His youth and limited reading are no excuse for his ignorance or one-sided foreign affairs knowledge. He also criticised the development and implementation of peace studies. He, his colleagues and other misguided and blinkered people in the community understandably feel very threatened by peace studies. They are understandably threatened, not because there is anything to feel worried about but because their own view of peace is structured on who has the most planes, bombs, ships or soldiers and not on how nations across the world can learn to live together without the murderous military expenditure we see today. That is what peace studies are all about: Opening a new door to an understanding by all in the community about how to avoid conflict.

It will surprise many people to learn that peace studies refer not just to nuclear war or disarmament but to other aspects of international and domestic peace and development. The honourable member for Mayo and his colleagues talk about human rights abuse in the USSR, but human rights abuse occurs in all countries. It occurs in Australia to women, Aborigines, the poor, the elderly and the young-indeed, throughout the community. Peace studies look at our own communities, at people and their problems. It looks at how we can learn to solve the problems in our own backyards. If we learn to live better with our neighbours and to see ourselves as a part of the world community, we are better prepared as individuals and as a nation to deal with our national and international obligations.

I spoke earlier of the tragic imbalance between arms spending and the daily human poverty faced on earth. Many members opposite support in various ways respected non-government agencies such as Community Aid Abroad, Freedom from Hunger, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid and many others. Our whole community, especially our young people, responded magnificently to the Aid for Africa appeal last year. It is a great shame and a great disservice to the community that those opposite continually scaremonger and irresponsibly criticise peace studies. In peace studies we talk about development education as well. That is something that members opposite have not considered. This Government has some failings in foreign policy, but nothing that Opposition members have exposed today. In this debate they have exposed, as usual, their own failings yet again. I would hope that this Government will fight strongly for our sovereignty and will use the trust and good will which it has with the electorate to promote the greater understanding of peace issues and peace itself.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In determining Australia's foreign policy attitude to other countries in this world, I believe that we should never lose sight of three cardinal points: Firstly, we should aim to build better relationships between Australia and overseas countries; secondly, we should be consistent in our treatment of these countries, taking care to judge them all by the same standards; thirdly, Australia's foreign policy should be formulated on what we believe is right. We should not be influenced by what is the trendy thing to do in the United Nations or by what is the international flavour of the month. Building better relationships is obviously very important. It is done not just at government level but by the Government allowing the freedom of tourist exchanges, cultural visits, trade, sporting and a whole host of other contacts which lead to the better, more stable and peaceful world to which the previous speaker, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), alluded. We should do that as far as is reasonably possible, not only with our overseas friends but also with what might be regarded as our so-called overseas enemies.

SPEECH.PARA: An example of a friend might be the United States of America, not that we would have gathered that from what was said by the previous speaker. An example of an enemy might be Russia. However, I believe it is in our interests not to shut ourselves off from Russia. If we become friendly with that country, there is less chance of conflict and more chance of peace. Also, there is more chance of understanding between both countries. If we trade with Russia, for example, the standard of living in both countries would be raised. We would become to some extent dependent on each other and that leads to a greater chance of peace in the long run.

If Australia believes in freedom, it is wrong to deny Australians access to travel to and from such countries as Russia. Of course, this does not prevent our Government having a foreign policy attitude which can condemn another country for doing something of which we do not approve. We can condemn Russia for its occupation of Poland. However, short of a situation of war or a national security breach, we should quite rightly allow trade and visits between the two countries. By the same token, we should be consistent. If a country friendly to us commits an atrocity, all other things being equal, we should be as equally critical of it as any other country. In the final analysis we should judge other countries on their actions rather than their professed political philosophy.

Though, generally speaking, we observe these principles, reasonably faithfully, unfortunately I believe we violate all of them when it comes to this country's attitude to South Africa. We have closed off many of our channels of communications with South Africa. I believe that it is ludicrous that members of this Parliament cannot visit two countries on our parliamentary passports-one is South Africa, and, of course, the other is Taiwan. We have gone to ridiculous lengths in this regard. For example, last year South Africans were banned from coming to this country to play in a Rotary golf tournament. We have also gone to ridiculous lengths to stop Rotary exchange students from attending schools in New South Wales. I am unsure why this Labor Government has chosen to single out Rotary, an organisation which is dedicated to fostering good will and fellowship between the citizens of all nations. However, this Government is doing everything to prevent that. Competition in some team sports played between Australia and South Africa such as cricket and rugby has also been stopped. The Government has vilified individuals with tax threats and other violations of civil liberties and is even talking about imposing more trade boycotts.

Apart from the fact that we seem obsessed with chasing the Third World vote, why should we single out South Africa? Other countries are not only equally at fault but far worse. One only has to look at the example of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Afghanistan which was brought up by the previous speaker. Between April 1978 and now the population of Afghanistan has fallen 40 per cent. In 1978, that country had a population of 14 million, the same as that of Australia. Today, the population of Afghanistan is 8 million. The other 6 million people are either in exile or they are dead. The Russians slaughtered 27,000 people in one concentration camp at Poli Charki. I believe that such genocide and persecution far transcends anything that has happened in South Africa.

The selective indignation does not end there. One only has to look at what has happened in Iran which until 1979 was ruled by the Shah. That leader had many faults-graft, corruption, the Iranian secret police and so on. The repression that took place in Iran sometimes even rivalled the day-to-day atrocities of its neighbouring states such as Iraq. That is how bad the situation was. However, the Shah had even worse faults which caused Iran to be singled out for a special campaign of vituperation. The Shah was friendly to the West and, in particular, the United States. To make matters worse, Iran had immense oil wealth and a well-equipped defence force situated in a very critical part of the world. With faults like those, naturally it had to go. Expert commentators emerged from everywhere at the call of duty to alert us to such evils. Newspaper editorials lashed out at the brutality of the Shah. Television footage filled our screens nightly of the wicked atrocities that were occurring. But, best of all, the Ayatollah Khomeini was discovered by Western intellectuals as Iran's saviour, a sort of latter-day Nelson Mandela. Naturally, the story had a happy ending. The Shah fled; Iran fell; oil production plummeted; mobs ruled the streets; `people's courts' dispensed justice; women were banished from sight; education for children retreated; the economy collapsed; the Press was banned; tourism stopped; people starved; and the Ayatollah ruled. It was the best of all outcomes. The West could be proud of the part it played. In fact, things are now so good in Iran that there is no need to mention that country's name in the media ever again. If only the leftwing of the Australian Labor Party could get the same result in respect of South Africa.
On the African continent, the countries to the north of South Africa also commit atrocities. We have seen the brutal oppression that has been imposed on the opposition in Zimbabwe.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean Rhodesia.

—Yes, Rhodesia. I thank the honourable member for his comments. Perhaps the most horrific story of all in Rhodesia/Zimbabwe was told by Peter Godwin, a reporter of the Sunday Times who travelled into Matabeleland where journalists are banned. Apparently soldiers shot dissidents by the thousands in a torture camp at Balaghwe. They loaded them onto trucks every night for `many weeks' and dumped them down disused gold mine shafts. Sometimes bodies got snagged on cross supports inside the interior. After each night's dumping, explosives were used to cover the bodies with debris. When Godwin visited the area, he said that the stench of rotting flesh was unmistakable. Commenting on these atrocity allegations Mr Mugabe said that he was `very happy' at the way his soldiers were behaving. `They have performed a wonderful duty', he said. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure you that the troops have been very restrained and we are full of praise for what they have managed to do over such a short period.

Father Gabriel, who runs a mission near the camp at Balaghwe, is an Austrian priest who lived through nazi rule in his home town. `The Gestapo', he said, `were gentlemen in comparison with the fifth brigade'. It is notable that our Government supported the recent tour by an Australian cricket team to Zimbabwe.

We see the same situation in Uganda where there are endless rounds of mass murders under all governments. If one belongs to a black group which is not in power, one's life, if one can hang on to it, can be an absolute misery. The leader of Ethiopia is engaging in a policy of mass destruction of his people. However, because he is Marxist, our Government encourages sporting contact between us and that country's athletes. Millions of people have been expelled from Nigeria. That country's massive oil wealth has been squandered and poverty is rife for much of the population. The same story can be told in Zaire. Kenya has been responsible for the mass expulsion of Asians simply because the people are Asians. The situation is the same in Angola and Mozambique. The story goes on and on and on.

So let us lay this charge of racism against South Africa to rest. South Africa is racist. However, that charge is certainly not unique to South Africa. All African states are racist. They all discriminate against someone. This is usually done on a tribal basis by blacks against blacks. However, it also occurs against Asians, Jews, whites and non-Muslims. The tribal racism is usually far more brutal than what occurs in South Africa. There is no genuine multi-racial society in the whole of Africa. Skin colour, racial origins or religious affiliation are of prime importance in securing elementary rights in all African countries. They all vary in the extent to which their discrimination is formalised or entrenched in their law codes and official philosophies. It pervades their political science or sociology courses at their universities. Tanzania has a sinister totalitarian doctrine called ujaama; Ghana has consciencism; Zambia has humanism; Senegal has negritude; and Zaire has mobutuism. All those theories reflect the appetites of the particular ruling racial group.

Apartheid is South Africa's own special brand of racism. Such a theory does not divide South Africa from the rest of Africa. It is merely the typical local expression that we find right throughout that continent. It is also in several other countries around the world. Apart from this, there are some who regard oppression via racism as more repugnant than oppression via any other means. To put it another way, some say that discrimination based on skin colour is somehow more reprehensible than one based on nationality or belief. By this reasoning, a Russian shooting a Pole or Czech is not as bad as a South African white shooting, or even oppressing, a South African black.

There are, of course, other considerations we should look at in foreign policy before we continue to castigate South Africa the way we do. It is not just simply white verus black. If we leave aside the diversity of the white population and the large coloured and Asian groups in South Africa, the black population itself is divided into at least 10 groups-the Zulus of six million people is the largest-but each group is divided into tribes. The Zulus are divided into 200 tribes; and even the smallest group, the Vendas, comprises 185,000 people divided into 27 tribes. Often, each tribe is divided further into clans. We have four main black groups of languages, 23 sub-groups and numerous dialects. Some groups cannot even converse with one another in their home language. The cultural differences are also very wide.

South Africa has potentially more racial unrest amongst its black groups than any other country in the African continent. This is not an apology or an excuse for apartheid, but it does indicate the enormous problems that exist there and the need for gradualism. If we abhor, quite rightly, racism in the form of apartheid we should recognise that racism in any form is just as bad. `That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet', said Shakespeare. Of course, many believe that South Africa has been singled out not because it is uniquely racist, but because it is anti-communist and because its strategic importance is highly significant. South Africa leads, or is second in the world, in a whole range of strategically important high technology minerals-chrome, platinum, vanadium, not to mention gold and diamonds. South Africa and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics have between 93 and 99 per cent of the world's supplies of these minerals-virtually a total monopoly of the world's strategic minerals.

It is obvious that if South Africa fell there would be one outstanding beneficiary from such an event. Let us not overlook the fact that tens of thousands of ships pass around the vital Cape route each year carrying much of the West's oil supplies, other minerals and goods. If that route fell into enemy hands the consequences to Australia's trade alone would be very substantial indeed. South Africa has its faults-horrific faults. However, it has done more for black people on the African continent, for all those faults, than any of the other 50 African nations. The standard of living for blacks in South Africa is the highest of any of those countries, measured from the point of view of money in the pocket or the degree of freedom. They are queued up on the border to get in. Hundreds of thousands have come in from more repressive countries and got jobs. There are more black-owned cars in South Africa than there are private cars in the whole of the Soviet Union. There are more black women professionals in South Africa than in the rest of the 50 African states put together. As I said, South Africa has its horrible faults, but compared with other countries it is often streets ahead.

We should work for change through friendship and communication. We should have trade with South Africa. We should have sporting contacts with South Africa. We should drastically revise this country's foreign policy on South Africa based on those earlier principles I enunciated of friendship and consistency and we should do it independently of the stance other countries choose to take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your elevation to your high office. I ask you to convey my congratulations to the Speaker. After listening to the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), I wonder why anybody would run for such a position. Unlike other members of the House you have to sit and listen. I think you have a great deal of forbearance.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise in this debate as it addresses Australia's role in the world. Unlike previous governments, the Hawke Government believes that Australia has a role to play in international affairs as an independent nation within the framework of the Western alliance. Too many Australians overestimate our world role and its significance, believing that Australia alone can change the world. I do not agree with this perception. However, I do not downplay the role Australia can play as an honest broker. Australia is not an unaligned nation and nor should it be. Australia is part of the Western alliance and an ally of the United States. This is my Party's policy and naturally the policy of the Government. Whilst being a strong ally of the United States, Australia is not part of the United States. We have different needs and, at times, a different view of the global situation. As an independent nation, we reserve that right.

It should not be forgotten that it was an Australian Labor Party government which forged this alliance under the prime ministership of John Curtin at the height of World War II. Australia faced the reality that we were no longer considered an important part of the British Empire, nor even were we high on the list of priorities of the British Government at that time. At the time of our greatest need and at the height of Australia's greatest danger Australia turned to the United States for help and assistance. This has been the foundation of Australian foreign policy ever since. The ANZUS alliance has been the cornerstone of Australian foreign policy and, at this time of disagreement between the United States and New Zealand, Australia is once more having to reassess the strategic importance of the United States alliance and the ANZUS agreement.

Whilst the Government disagrees with the actions of New Zealand in banning United States warships, it does not, like the Opposition, seek to bully the duly elected Government of New Zealand. We believe that the United States and New Zealand should seek resolution of their differences in the spirit of ANZUS. Australia and New Zealand have shown through many conflicts that they are close allies of the United States, having fought at the side of the United States in every conflict since the First World War. No other nation has paid so dearly for the respect of the United States. We should, therefore, urge patience and understanding between the two governments. It is through this role as a friend and an ally that we seek to influence the United States in its attitude to other nations. We do not presume to dictate to the United States how it should determine its foreign policy. We only seek the same respect from the United States in how we determine our own foreign policy. As Australian parliamentarians, we have common bonds with members of the United States Senate and House of Representatives. Anybody who has met with United States members will appreciate the easy rapport that is established. This rapport is one of the most important factors in the creation of closer ties between the United States and other nations.

It is in this context that I wish to mention the United States farm Bill. During the recess, I had the opportunity to meet several United States congressmen. I raised the subject of the farm Bill with them because I know the personal anguish that this Bill is causing many of my constituents. Most congressmen were unaware of the effects their farm Bill would have on Australia. I think that if this viewpoint is correct, it says something about our embassy in Washington. I fully appreciate that our embassy staff are fully occupied in the roles that they are playing. I also know that we have a liaison office to keep a watch on United States legislation. I believe, however, that it is imperative that Australia have a senior experienced politician as a diplomat to the United States. I say that not because I want the job or because I covet it, and certainly not through any dissatisfaction with the current ambassador. It seems to me that a politician would have some sway on legislation that will ultimately affect Australia. I give full credit to the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for the efforts they are making to downplay the role of the farm Bill and the consequences for Australian agriculture.

It seems to me that it is too late in the day for Australia effectively to voice its disapproval of the farm Bill. I say this because of the nature of the United States congressional system. It is a fact that for any matter to become a Bill in the United States, it is subject to compromise, changes, and deals between parties, therefore, once it is law it is just about set in concrete. I would ask the Minister to examine ways in which Australia could seek to influence events before they become law. Given the nature of the rural difficulties at the moment, it would seem to be uppermost in importance. It may well be that a person selected for the embassy could be nominated from one of the rural organisations. I say this, not just in the United States context but also in the European context. The European Economic Community and its policies have great effect on Australia's position in the world and the balance of payments that we face. The overseas market situation for Australian goods is very grim, so warped, that a radical solution to embassy staff is needed. I would like the Minister to examine this proposal to see whether it can be implemented. The present situation is simply ineffective. It is too little and not sustained enough to present a case for our rural community.

I also wish to mention the Government's policy on South Africa. As the honourable member for Parkes spent the whole of his 15 minutes trying to defend the Government of South Africa, I think it is pertinent that we address this issue in this debate. There is no doubt that the South African situation is very complex and very tense. I do not believe that unilateral sanctions are an appropriate form of retaliation. It is essential that Australia seek, where possible, to adopt a policy which will break down apartheid without rending South Africa and turning it into a blood-bath.

The tensions within South Africa are already being reflected in the South African political life. The ruling National Party is coming under intense pressure to reform. The Botha Government has attempted to commence some reforms, however ineffective. Yet the National Party is under pressure from an extreme right wing and the more progressive parties in the Parliament. I would say too that many white South Africans are voting with their feet. It would be interesting indeed to ascertain the number of applications for migration from South Africa to Australia. These people are doing this because they have lost faith in the South African Government's ability to control events. I feel that it is important that Australia adopt a united approach in attempting to influence events in South Africa. Yet the current Opposition is preventing this. The Liberal Party has a number of different approaches, some of which water down the firm principled stance taken by the Fraser Government. The National Party, particularly elements of the Queensland branch, is unashamedly pro the most extreme elements in South African society. Such an approach does not take into account the political divisions already existing in the South African Government. Surely, as people concerned about human rights, we should be about reducing the inhumane aspects of apartheid.

I also find it very strange that the self-proclaimed Christian Premier of Queensland has no hesitation in going in to bat for the South African authorities. There is no doubt that the Queensland Premier has, over the years, embarked on a campaign of denigration of coloured people in Queensland. It fails to impress me that he seeks to portray his demented views on the world stage. We find the Queensland Premier repeatedly identifying himself with the most excessive elements within South Africa. At no time has he ever spoken out for human dignity for all people in South Africa. I am appalled, and I believe all thinking Queenslanders should be, as should all thinking Australians, by the immoral positions adopted by the Bjelke-Petersen Government. There is no doubt that he is a puppet of the extreme right wing elements of our society who are active not only on the Darling Downs in my electorate but also throughout rural Queensland. I might add that the Queensland National Party also produced the Federal Minister who, because of his views on South Africa, served the shortest term ever.

It also concerns me that sporting organisations are increasing their links with South Africa. I say that because Brisbane is attempting to secure the Olympic Games in 1992. I fear that, if Australia is seen to be weakening in its sporting links stance, European countries may use this as a leverage against Brisbane's case. The negotiations are under way at the moment and I would hate fears of a boycott to be a reason Brisbane is not selected. I urge all sporting groups to think of Australia's sporting future and Australia's bid to host an Olympics before they sign any sporting contract with South Africa. The recent rebel cricket tour of South Africa showed that sport and politics do mix in that country. The South African Government allowed as a tax deduction the cost of bringing Australians to South Africa. This brought immense criticism from its own people, and so it should have. This clearly shows the lengths to which South Africa is prepared to go to bolster its sporting links with other countries. I ask the Minister to continue his policy of patiently convincing sporting groups of the lack of wisdom in going to South Africa.

I would like to turn now to South East Asia and what is termed the Pacific rim. The countries constituting this rim are in the forefront of economic growth in the world. These countries will be hurt by any trade war between the European Economic Community and the United States of America. There is a need for Australia to strengthen trade links with the countries of the Pacific rim. These links can be enhanced by the priority we give to our trade missions overseas. It is essential that experienced trade officials be placed to carefully explain Australia's position on trade matters. It is also essential that our leading foreign service diplomats in the Pacific Rim are familiar with the trade opportunities open to Australian manufacturers and primary producers. (Quorum formed) I thank my colleagues for their attendance in the House. As usual, very few members of the Opposition are in the House. I was addressing the problems facing our manufacturers and primary industries and how they can be assisted by our diplomatic service overseas.

I now wish to turn to what I feel is something for the future. Given our geographic position, it is essential that Australia adopt a closer relationship with both South East Asia and the Pacific. Indeed, I would like to see the day when Australia considers itself part of the Association of South East Asean Nations, as well as part of a South Pacific community. Such a proposition makes sense given the increasing level of tourist contact and migration from these countries to Australia. I believe that this idea will gain acceptability because Australians increasingly are seeing themselves as part of South East Asia and the Pacific community. The old idea that Australia must remain the last outpost of British colonialism should be replaced by a closer identification with Asian and Pacific bloc nations.
