It is apparent that this area offers us greater room for increased trading opportunities. This is essential for the economic well-being of our country. It is only by developing closer economic and cultural ties with Asia and the South Pacific that we will overcome some of the misconceptions about our region which have bedevilled our foreign policy in the past. The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has recognised this and has established a sub- committee on the South Pacific which is currently inquiring into the Philippines. With the situation that exists in the Philippines I do not think that it could be more timely for that inquiry and for this Parliament and its committees to play a role in trying to ascertain the position in those regions.

Finally, I would like to pay tribute to the interest and activity the Minister shows in his portfolio. As an electoral neighbour of the Minister, I am aware that the Minister devotes himself fully to both his portfolio and his electorate of Oxley. The Minister may be delighted to learn that rural folk in the areas I inherited from him following the last redistribution speak very highly of him as a Minister and as a member. Those sentiments should be echoed by all members of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity of rising in the House tonight to follow the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall). While I have a respect for the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) as a person, I know that the people in the Rankin electorate would under no circumstances vote for the Hawke socialist Government. In fact, I know that after the next election-whenever the Hawke Government decides to bring it on-the honourable member for Rankin will no longer be a member of this chamber. The Minister for Foreign Affairs is a genuine Labor man, unlike the person who temporarily occupies the position of Prime Minister of this country. We can respect the Minister because he is a Labor man. He is not an opportunist.

SPEECH.PARA: The Foreign Minister presented his ministerial statement on 26 November 1985. As the Opposition shadow Minister, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), said, he took a welcome if belated step to give the House an account of Australia's current foreign policy. What a disaster the Hawke Government's foreign policy has been since that fateful day on 5 March 1983 when it crawled into office.

The Foreign Minister in his ministerial statement argued that his regime has two paramount objectives in foreign policy: The first aim is to protect and promote Australia's national interest in a highly volatile world; and the second is to pursue a determined and independent role as a middle-ranking nation in the search for a better world order. Who would deny the aims of the Minister? They may well be laudable, but there are clearly major problems for Australia in seeking to pursue a determined and independent role in a volatile world. In particular, there is a danger that the determined pursuit of independence can produce policies which are not clearly conceived and well developed and which may not serve Australia's national interest. Examples may be mentioned. In discussing Australia's relationship with the United States, our great ally-where would we have been in the Second World War without the United States?-the Minister noted:

Let there be no ambiguity about the Government's attitude on this point. Our commitment to Australia's alliance with the United States of America is strong and deep . . . We are not pacifists. We are sober realists who have chosen to throw Australia's support behind the capacity and willingness of the United States to play the major role in maintaining international security.

What a sick joke! In its relations with the United States, the Hawke socialist Government has not displayed sober realism. It has at times sought to pursue policies which have not paid due regard to Australia's crucial alliance with the United States. The Hawke Government is an opportunistic government, it is an unprincipled government and it is a government which without doubt will be rejected by the people of this country at the next election. The Minister has claimed the Government has a commitment to arms control and disarmament--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a joke.

—It is a joke. The pursuit of genuinely bilateral arms control between the two super-powers is indeed of crucial importance, but the Government has at times inhibited United States efforts to promote arms control from a position of strength and security. It tries to undermine the efforts of the West while pretending to have an attitude of supporting the United States. It is a sick joke being perpetrated upon the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider the case of the MX missile tests. This is a vital case. In order to be able to pursue arms control negotiations effectively, the United States-our great friend and ally-has to preserve the capacities of its own strategic nuclear forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am pleased to have the support of the honourable member for Denison on this issue. The testing of the MX missile is important. Yet the Labor Party Government, which is temporarily in control of this country and which claims to maintain a strong and deep commitment to the United States, refused to provide assistance. It refused to provide access to airfields for United States monitoring services. Is that the action of a friend? Is that the action of an ally? Is that the action of a committed country which is trying to resist the onslaught of the Soviet Union and its allies?
—The Government kow-tows to Moscow.

—It does indeed. The Government claims to support the principle of nuclear deterrence while the super-powers pursue arms control measures, but inhibits the efforts of our main ally to preserve its own forces' nuclear deterrent capacities at a time when the Soviet Union is consistently improving its own nuclear forces.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the House, in the National Party of Australia and the Liberal Party of Australia, applaud the actions of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in floating the Australian dollar because that means that the international community is able to pass judgment on our economic performance, our political performance, and indeed on the way in which this Government is running the country. Since the Government was elected in 1983, there has been a complete and utter collapse of the Australian dollar. We have a situation in which our currency is no better than Monopoly money. It is tragic that this has to happen in order to help our export industries. Everyone will be pleased about the fact that our export industries are now a little more able to compete on the international market, but it is a shocking indictment of the Hawke Government that our currency has to become almost worthless for this to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for his support. Another matter I wish to raise is the Government's promotion of the South Pacific nuclear free zone. This is certainly open to criticism. The South Pacific region has so far been relatively free from tension and conflict, but it borders on regions which are highly volatile-South East Asia and East Asia. The South Pacific nuclear free zone cannot achieve anything to limit the major practical problems facing the South Pacific states, such as French nuclear testing and the dumping of nuclear waste; but the treaty does impose limits on the capacity of Australia's ally, the United States, to continue to provide assistance for the security of the region. The treaty prohibits for all time United States or allied basing of nuclear weapons within the zone, whether the regional security situation for Australia deteriorates or not.
—That is disgraceful.

—Quite correct. When our Prime Minister struts across the international forums trying to pretend that he is a world statesman, trying to undermine the position of the Western nations, he should be condemned and his Government should be condemned. Indeed, the Hawke socialist Government will be thrown from office at the next election. I thank honourable members on this side of the House for their wholehearted support for my speech.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at comrade Lange and his cronies in New Zealand-those people who have taken control of what was once Australia's closest ally. These people, who came to power in New Zealand such a short time ago, have sought to tear up the ANZUS Treaty. What did this Government do? Did it say to the New Zealand Government: `We will not exchange defence information with you; you are no longer an ally'? No, it did not. It said: `We are sorry that you are no longer friendly with our ally the United States, but we will leak information to you; we will give you defence information; we will continue to treat you as an ally', even though comrade Lange and his cronies are playing into the hands of the Soviet Union and the Eastern bloc. It is a disgrace that this Government, this transitory government saw fit to undermine our principles, saw fit to continue to provide comfort and succour to comrade Lange and his cronies, who are trying to subvert the situation of the West. It is a national disgrace and it is something that the Australian people will certainly not forget.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a Churchillian speech.

—I thank the honourable member for Parkes for his praise. Further confusion and ambiguity about Australia's national interests are shown in the Government's policies towards South East Asia. Since 1983 the Government has pursued policies towards Vietnam and Indo-China which have sought to promote dialogue over the Cambodian conflict. In doing so, the Government has diluted Australia's previous firm support for the Association of South East Asian Nations in opposing Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia. We must remember that Vietnam is presently languishing under a communist government which is a firm and strong ally of the Soviet Union. The Australian Government's policies have caused concern to Australia's ASEAN neighbours without producing any clear evidence of greater flexibility or willingness to compromise on the part of Vietnam. How long will this continue? How long will this Government be able to parade itself before the Australian people as a government that is looking after Australia's interests? I wish to tell the House one thing: The people of Australia are not fools. They will see through this charade and they will react in no uncertain way at the time of the next poll.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to compliment my colleague the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) for his contribution in relation to southern Africa. He has shown a realistic approach. He did not defend the situation in South Africa, but he pointed out that there is no genuine democracy in the continent of Africa. That was all he did; he did not defend apartheid and he did not support South Africa. He simply said that there is no democracy in Africa and implicit in his speech was a plea to the Government of this country to be consistent. The Government of this country is not interested in logic. It is not interested in consistency. It is not interested in the ordinary interests of the average Australian. The Government's appraisal of Australian national interests in regard to policies towards South Africa is not only questionable; it should be condemned. The Government purports to condemn the policy of separate development or apartheid and the policies of the South African Government. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Rankin, mentioned that the South African Government has been making reforms. Certainly it has been making reforms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am pleased once again to have the support of the honourable member for Denison. In fact those reforms in South Africa have to go further. Every reasonable person in South Africa supports those reforms. What we should be doing in this House is giving encouragement to the Government of South Africa to continue those reforms. It is a sad state of affairs that, the more the South African Government moderates its policies, the more condemnation is heaped on that Government by the people who control this country.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government singles out South Africa. It does not worry about the Soviet Union. It has forgotten about Afghanistan. It has forgotten about Czechoslovakia. It has avoided discussing the way the Soviet Union managed to enslave half of Europe after the Second World War. It does not care because it considers Russia to be its ideological friend. The Government tries to unify the members of its Left but none of them is in the House tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all at the Soviet Embassy.

—They may well all be at the Soviet Embassy. The truth is that the Government tries to bring together those factions in the Australian Labor Party by coming out and criticising poor old South Africa-which is attempting to take a reasonable approach and trying to water down and do away with its apartheid policy. The Government is not interested in that. It is interested in point scoring. It is not interested in the rights of South Africans. The policies of condemnation of South Africa do nothing to promote a realistic understanding of the country's internal problems and the methods that need to be adopted to alleviate them through negotiation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also causes unnecessary difficulties in communication between Australia and South Africa. What about those South African people who have moved here? We had a strike by the postal union. The Government will not permit Qantas Airways Ltd to fly to South Africa. Instead Qantas flies to Zimbabwe, that country which Malcolm Fraser managed to help turn over to a Marxist government. We all know that Zimbabwe is a country with a shocking record on human rights. For no apparent reason our airline is not allowed to fly to South Africa, although airlines from most other countries do. Australia has a government-it calls itself a government-which is going nowhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a rabble.

—The honourable member for Gilmore has called it a rabble. He could well be correct. The people of Australia should take note of the Government's shocking handling of foreign affairs and the way in which it has been refusing to consider the nation's interest. It has earned the condemnation of the people of Australia which will be shown at the next election when I have no doubt that the Labor Party will be swept from office in a landslide at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the early 1900s it has been predicted that the centre of the world's political and economic gravity would shift from the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean. President Theodore Roosevelt said in 1903:

SPEECH.PARA: The Atlantic era is now at the height of its development. The Pacific era, destined to be the greatest of all, is just at its dawn.
In 1944, just after his triumphal return to the Philippines, General Douglas MacArthur told a group of war correspondents:
The history of the world for the next thousand years will be written in the Pacific.

Scholars, businessmen, commentators and policy makers worldwide say the Pacific century is here. Masao Fugioka, President of the Asian Development Bank, told the Swiss Institute for Foreign Studies in 1982:
The Pacific is the ocean of tomorrow. We are witnessing the dawn of the Asia-Pacific era.

What is the cause of the heady optimism? Japan's great economic growth and leadership has been well documented; so, too, has China's experimentation with capitalism and emergence as a world market. Perhaps less well known to much of the world have been the great economic strides of countries such as Singapore, Malaysia and South Korea. Many economists predict that by the year 2000 the Asia-Pacific region will by-pass both the United States of America and Europe to become the world's strongest economic entity.

The term `Pacific basin' or `Pacific rim' generally refers to countries that border the Pacific Ocean, from Japan in the north to New Zealand in the south. It also embraces the islands of the Pacific and, across the ocean, Canada and the United States-often Chile and Peru in South America. The economic dynamism of this region gives it the world's greatest trading potential for the foreseeable future. Statistics illustrate this most dramatically. In 1983 Japan had the second largest gross national product in the western world, representing about 14.8 per cent of the total output of all Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, and some 9.5 per cent of global GNP. Its share of global trade was 8.1 per cent. Its direct overseas investments amounted to $7.7 billion. The average prediction for average annual real economic growth in Japan over the next 10 years is 4 per cent. This would produce a per capita national income of $14,500 in 1993-almost equal to that of the United States.

The growth rates of real GNP during the two decades 1960 to 1980 were Korea 8.5 per cent, Taiwan 9.6 per cent, Thailand 7.4 per cent, the Philippines 5.8 per cent, Indonesia 4.8 per cent, Malaysia 8.2 per cent and Singapore 9.2 per cent. The share of manufactured goods in total exports at the beginning of the 1960s was only about 15 per cent for Korea and Taiwan, and between 0 per cent and 5 per cent in the cases of Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand. By 1980 manufactured goods accounted for more than 90 per cent in the cases of Korea and Taiwan, and 28 per cent, 24 per cent and 35 per cent in the cases of Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand respectively. In the period 1970 to 1981 rice production rose by more than 60 per cent in both Indonesia and the Philippines-from 13 to 22 million tonnes in one case and from 3 to 5 million tonnes in the other. A recent Japanese prediction is for an overall growth rate of between 6.5 and 8 per cent for the market economies of the region for the rest of the decade. By the end of the 1990s, the Association of South East Asian Nations gross domestic product may well be more than 40 per cent larger than Australia's GDP.

The image of the East Asian region of mass poverty and backwardness is dangerously outdated. In an address to the Australian Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, Mr Geoff Miller, the then Acting Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs, said:

The first thing we should do is welcome this peaceful economic progress. Starting with World War II and going on until the end of the Vietnam war Australia was repeatedly involved in wars and fighting in Asia-the Pacific war itself, in Korea, Malaysia, Borneo and finally in Vietnam. We feared Japanese imperialism, Chinese, Vietnamese and Malaysian communism, and Indonesian expansionism, and our soldiers fought many times, from the freezing mountains of Korea to the jungles of South East Asia, to defend us from these perceived threats. They were not always successful and our perceptions of those past days have in some cases considerably changed. But the important fact is that we now face, in a way which was not the case in the past, an Asia which is not at war, whose component countries are devoting themselves to peaceful pursuits and the prosperity of their people, and thus provide an environment in which we as an integral part of the western Pacific region can ourselves prosper in peace

A former Australian Foreign Minister is alleged to have defined the goal of foreign policy as `the long term security and prosperity of the country'. Most people would agree that it is preferable to further foreign policy according to that definition through the pursuit of trade and other economic interchange than through military involvements of the kind referred to by Mr Geoff Miller.

Whilst we share the confidence in the rapid economic development of the Pacific region, the strategic picture is neither simple nor serene. Tensions exist on the Sino-Soviet border and between China and Taiwan. There are territorial borders disputes between the Soviet Union and Japan. Tensions exist between North and South Korea. There is conflict in Cambodia and, not least, there is the rapid expansion of Soviet military forces in South East Asia, particularly in Vietnam.
The Foreign Minister, in his statement to this House on 26 November, said with regard to the Government's foreign policy that it must:
. . . maintain a level-headed appreciation of the limits of the power and influence which it has . . . A foreign policy which ignores this fact will be no more than words.

Australia, by virtue of its size, geographic proximity to the Indian Ocean, South East Asia and the South Pacific and because of its military and political alignment, makes an outstanding regional contribution to United States strategic interests. Australia and New Zealand are formally aligned with the United States in the ANZUS Treaty and have traditionally provided the United States with close political support. Australia, especially, is a significant regional importer of United States technology and capital and it is a major exporter of raw materials and energy.

Australia and, to a much lesser extent, New Zealand have traditionally facilitated the regional military requirements of the United States. Three joint facilities in Australia directly support the United States strategic posture. These are the naval communications station at North West Cape, the defence space research facility at Pine Gap; and the space communications facility at Nurrungar. These three facilities provide the United States with communications including command and control of ballistic submarines, signals intelligence, early warning and targeting information. As well, Australia and, until recently, New Zealand have provided United States military units with wide access to port and other land support facilities. United States naval vessels, including aircraft carriers and nuclear-powered attack submarines have been calling at the Western Australian naval base at HMAS Stirling on the average of one a month. Under a bilateral agreement, Australia provides the B52 aircraft of the United States Air Force with staging facilities in northern Australia to assist with the United States Air Force navigation training and ocean surveillance programs in the region.
The Foreign Minister, in his speech to the House of Representatives of 26 November 1985, pledged a strong and deep commitment to Australia's alliance with the United States of America. He said:

In reaffirming this commitment, we have the support of the Australian people, for there is a profound and wide-spread feeling for the United States in this country which goes beyond the normal calculations of common interest.
He went on to say:

We are not pacifists. We are sober realists who have chosen to throw Australia's support behind the capacity and willingness of the United States to play the major role in maintaining international security.

Australia was directly responsible for the security of its colony, Papua New Guinea, until the independence of the latter in 1975. Close security links have been maintained over the post-independence years. These have been maintained due to geographic proximity as well as Australia's continuing role as Papua New Guinea's principal economic and military aid donor. In February 1977 the Prime Ministers of Australia and Papua New Guinea issued a joint statement on defence relations. The second and key paragraph of the statement affirmed the importance attached by each government to continued defence co-operation and states the intention of the two as being:
To consult at the request of either, about matters affecting their common security interests and about aspects of their defence relationship.

This statement, together with an exchange of ministerial letters on 21 January 1977 and the Status of Forces and Supply and Support agreement of the same month, remain the formal basis for security co-operation between the two neighbouring states. While these documents fall short of a formal alliance, Papua New Guinea regards them as the basis of an Australian security guarantee. The Hawke Government-an authentic Australian government, for its part, has taken a direct interest in Papua New Guinea's security for a number of reasons: For example the sensitivity of Australian domestic opinion to geographic proximity and historic association; considerations relating to Australian credibility in the South Pacific; and the consequences of Papua New Guinea turning elsewhere for help and so undermining the ANZUS strategy of regional denial. Taken together, these considerations draw Australia closely to one of the few potentially destabilising issues in the region-that is, the border between Papua New Guinea and the Indonesian province of Irian Jaya. Running some 760 kilometres over poorly marked and some extremely rugged terrain, the border is the only land frontier in the South Pacific region. The integrity of the border is a sensitive issue to both states. Indonesia sensitivities stem from the wider concern to maintain the cohesion of a state which is geographically dispersed and is inhabited by heterogeneous people. Papua New Guinea's sensitivities, on the other hand, stem from the determination of a new and weaker state to maintain its sovereignty. On Papua New Guinea's part, there is also a strong element of sympathy for the ethnically related Melanesian people on the other side of the border.

Mr Miller stressed the overwhelming fact about our relations with countries of the Asia-Pacific region. He observed that in a way that is unique for any country of predominantly European population, Australia is located among non-European countries which are steadily becoming stronger, more prosperous and capable when compared with ourselves.

The Australian people therefore value the indefatigable efforts of the Australian Foreign Minister in building many bridges between Australia and other Pacific rim countries. His outstanding success in constructing closer friendly relations between Australia and Indonesia is to be applauded. Indonesia's size, proximity and potential give it a special strategic significance for Australia. With a population of around 156 million, Indonesia is the fifth most populous country in the world. It has significant mineral and natural resources. The Indonesian archipelago stretches across the northern approaches to Australia, thus commanding sea lanes of communication to Japan, China and other trading nations in east and South East Asia and major routes between the Indian and Pacific oceans and major air routes to Asia as well as Europe. Indonesia shares a border with Papua New Guinea, where Australia has important political, strategic and economic interests.

The most immediate prospects for major economic co-operation between Australia and Indonesia lie in the joint development of the Timor Gap. Indonesia's determination to develop a steel industry may also hold long term prospects for Australian joint ventures, particularly given Indonesia's proximity to Australian mines and to the Kwinana plant in Western Australia. I believe that the Australian Government may need to provide funding for initial efforts to identify areas of possible co-operation as a means of redressing the deficiencies caused by the lack of historical and cultural ties between the two countries.

Of particular interest is the Australian Government's sponsored training program. Under this program, 225 Indonesian post-graduate scholars and trainees are currently studying in Australia. They are undertaking training mainly in the areas of agriculture, education, mining, engineering, health services and public utilities. Fourteen Indonesian students are currently training under the program at the internationally renowned graduate school of tropical veterinary science at Townsville's James Cook University.

In addition to training in Australia, increased emphasis is now being given to providing training courses in Indonesia, covering engineering, public administration and agriculture, designed to meet specific Indonesian needs. Over the past 10 years Australia has sponsored 24,000 students from all parts of Asia. These young people are among the technocrats and the intelligentsia who are making the Asian region so confident and dynamic.

Australians have accepted the challenge to be involved in all aspects of a drive towards development and economic progress throughout the Asian region. Examples include Australian participation in the Australian school at Bataan and the general hospital at Rangoon. The Australian Foreign Minister eloquently summed up the reason for our involvement, in a speech to the Bangkok Foreign Correspondents Club on 3 August 1984, when he said:
We are involved from the ground up in the drive towards greater development and dynamic growth in the Asian Area. We are involved in this way because this is our home too.

Whatever ties Australia has had with the old world, the very future of our land, Australia, and our race is irrevocably locked to the destiny of the Pacific rim countries. We share with these countries the same Pacific Ocean first seen by Europeans when, on 25 September 1513, Vasco Nunez de Balboa climbed a hill on the Central American coast and took his first sight of that ocean, the cradle of a new civilisation to be. Let us therefore go forth to contribute our skills and goodwill to ensure that the Pacific region will be a safe and vibrant home not only for our children but also for the generations of Australians yet unborn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year, as shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, I was critical of several aspects of the Government's handling of the complex problems of South Africa. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), in the statement now before the House, in reference to the group of eminent persons established by the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, says:

SPEECH.PARA: It will be concerned to engage the South African Government and all sections of opinion in that country in exploring how a national discussion on reform might be instituted. The question of further measures concerning apartheid by Australia will depend on the extent to which the South African Government shows its readiness to move on reform.

I am pleased to note that rather more positive approach by the Government, because there is no doubt that it is time for the Western world to challenge South Africa in the most positive way. The National Party Government in South Africa has not responded to the United States policy of constructive engagement. On the contrary, both domestically and in its relations with Namibia and the bordering sovereign states of southern Africa, it has betrayed the confidence given it by the West. Its military activity on its borders and its refusal to deal with the genuine leaders of the urban blacks have created a recipe not merely for internal revolution, but for regional warfare with the possibility of super-power involvement. The National Party Government in South Africa is one of the most intransigent, repressive and brutal in the world. It has forfeited the respect of all decent people.

If the non-racial, non-communist, essentially non-violent actions of current black leaders do not soon gain a commitment by the whites of South Africa to genuine discussions on constitutional reform, those leaders will be totally discredited in the eyes of the younger blacks. That was evident from many discussions which I had when I was in southern Africa last year and it has been confirmed by subsequent reports. As the Minister is in the chamber I would like to thank him and his Department for the assistance which they gave me. I particularly thank Messrs Etheridge, Pearce and Sparkes, who under the guidance of Ambassador Birch organised such a representative, stimulating and insightful program for me.

We have the danger not so much of extremism from the Right which we read about but extremism from the Left. A blood-bath seems inevitable. But I cling to the hope that it is still not too late for the parties rationally to discuss political power sharing. The usual ambit claims are made, but the key to peaceful change lies in constructive, constitutional discussions by elected white politicians with blacks who are similarly chosen-people who are chosen by the blacks, not people nominated by the whites. Apartheid is a political system. It is designed to ensure that the white minority retains political power to dominate the non-white majority. Consequently, concessions to social or economic discrimination should not be misunderstood as being reforms to apartheid.

No one would deny that progress has been made on the social side. No one would deny that there is much more to be done. I believe that President Botha intends to remove more social and some economic discrimination. But I do not believe that he intends to abolish apartheid as a political system. Indeed, he has further entrenched it in the Constitution by creating a tricameral parliament based on race, and excluding the blacks. There are separate chambers for mixed race or coloured people, for Asians and for whites. But the real legislative power lies in the white chamber and even greater executive power lies with the white state President.

Had the experiment of a four-chamber parliament and the non-elected President's council been tried a decade or more ago, it might have evolved into a non-racial parliament. But it cannot succeed now. Not only would blacks not now accept a fourth chamber if it were offered to them-and the President says it will not be-but also the boycott of the polls by Asians and coloureds dooms even the tricameral experiment. That is especially true now that the coloured and Asian representatives have supported the state of emergency. They had less than 20 per cent of the poll in terms of their ethnic groupings and those who were elected supported the state of emergency, which was, of course, imposed against the blacks.

The determination of the Government to work through people seen by educated urban blacks, coloureds and Asians as being Uncle Toms and to emasculate all opposition is welding the middle class together; so much so that the leaders of the three ethnic groups call themselves black. I spoke to the 16 accused facing treason charges in Natal. I found them united and integrated in their struggle for fundamental political rights. They had been acting in parallel on behalf of the three groups, but from now on they and the many thousands of others who support them will act in concert. Their adversity will bring substance to the commitment of the greatly harassed non-racial United Democratic Front, the banned non-racial African National Congress and the non-racial Progressive Federal Party.

Having spoken with many black leaders both within and outside South Africa, I am confident that, if blacks were brought into the political process now, they would apply themselves energetically and creatively to forging a new Constitution embracing the principles espoused in the Magna Carta, the United States Declaration of Independence and the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. They would be anxious to protect minority racial interests, of which there are several apart from the whites. How ironic and how sad it would be if they had to do this with the aid of the closed, totalitarian, brutal regimes of the Soviet world. Yet that is the prospect. The very product of apartheid is the absence of avenues of communication.

Few whites thought the state of emergency was justified. There was no riot in their streets and the limited media reports did not convey to them the real nature of the riots elsewhere. How can a manacled media really convey the frustration and hopelessness of the average urban blacks who told me of their dashed expectations? Few whites are even aware of the devastation felt by the third or fourth generation of urban blacks who strove hard for matriculation and to live in a home with electricity, running water and sewerage, only to find themselves denied those and other amenities which middle class people everywhere else regard as their entitlement. Few whites know that they have as many black counterparts whose upwardly mobile aspirations have been dashed by the white regime. Few whites know how brutal that regime is and few in the West really know, either. There was no need for the state of emergency, not because there was no riot in the white streets, but simply because the legislation already in place, the Internal Security Act, contains the powers that any government would ever wish for in order to found a state of emergency.

The whites who overthrew Smuts can only bargain from a position of strength. Their moral strength has evaporated and they can retain power only by increased brutality and repression. They complain of brutality against them, but as the recently retired Leader of the Opposition has said, brutality, of course, begins with the Government itself. The liberals, both black and white, are in opposition to the Government and in those circumstances, of course, loose talk of economic sanctions does not lessen the prospect of brutality.

I am convinced that the best way to help liberal whites and blacks is for a group of Western Foreign Ministers to go to South Africa and to tell the Government and all the organisations interested in that country's development that the Western world expects that they will sit down to genuine discussions on their constitutional future. Such a delegation must be led by the United States or perhaps the United Kingdom. It should certainly include Australia, Canada, Germany and Japan. It is not for us to tell them what form of constitution they should adopt. It is not necessary for it be a unitary system. A variety of federal and confederal systems have already been proposed. But it is legitimate for the West to say to South Africa: `If you really want to be a member of the Western club-and we certainly want you to be-you must behave in a manner which is consistent with Western democratic principles'. It has not in fact had an election for many years. When the next election is held in 1989, it will have been nine years since the last election. So even the 17 per cent of people who vote for the white House have not had an election for many years.

To avoid massive bloodshed of both whites and blacks, as a collective Western voice, including the Japanese, we must say: `We urge you to negotiate forthwith with black leaders chosen by blacks by secret ballot'. Such an approach gives the maximum possible emphasis to what the Americans call `constructive engagement'. Nothing could be more positive and I strongly urge it again tonight. That approach would be accompanied by the demands which have already come from the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, the United Nations and unilaterally from Washington, London, Bonn, Canberra and so forth: end the state of emergency; repeal the Internal Security Act; release all political detainees, grant amnesties to those who are now in exile; abandon so-called treason trials; legalise the ANC; give Nelson Mandela time to brief himself on the views of the young turks and then enter into genuine talks about power sharing with him and other leaders. We in opposition have said this. The Government has essentially said it as well, and it has added a few gimmicks which I do not think have improved the situation or the prospects one iota.

If that process begins, much progress can be made. By the time the next tricameral parliament elections are due to be held in 1989, all sorts of interim elections could be held under alternative arrangements agreed upon by all of the people in South Africa who have a vested interest there-blacks, white, coloureds, Indians, and so forth. If a positive approach of that nature fails, of course, the West will have to go back to the drawing board. I wrote an article along those lines in the Age on, I think, 2 September. On 10 September an Australian who had lived for 55 years in South Africa wrote a letter to the editor saying how absolutely right I was and hoping that nobody in Australia doubted those words. I am bound to say that, having heard the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) say that they do doubt it, history will prove, in a very short space of time, how wrong were their judgments of the Fraser Government and how wrong were their judgments of Zimbabwe.

In the last few minutes available to me I turn to some of the problems which are thrown up as a result of the picture I have shown. As reported in the Age of 27 July, Mrs Mandela, the wife of the African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela, said:

We thought years ago we would be part of a process to assist the Afrikaner in dismantling his own Frankenstein's monster . . . that time is over. We no longer want that type of freedom. The freedom we are fighting for is freedom now, our liberation now.

That is a fact. People are no longer interested in whether they can sleep together, eat together or urinate together, they want now to participate fully and equally, but subject to all sorts of reservations to protect minority interests-black, white, and coloured. The Age editorial on Tuesday of this week summed up the dreadful problem with which we are now faced. It was headed `The reality behind Botha's rhetoric' and stated:

Many people wondered what President Botha meant a few days ago when he delivered a major speech saying that South Africa had outgrown the concept of apartheid and that he and his Government were committed to power sharing. Subsequent events have provided the clearest possible answer. First, Mr Botha has publicly and sharply rebuked his Foreign Minister for daring to suggest that black cabinet ministers and even a black state president were possible and acceptable to him as long as there were sufficient guarantees for the white minority. Second, Mr Botha has given his firm support to a statement by his Education Minister saying that the ruling National Party would never accept integrated schools, hospitals and suburbs. Third, a group of coloured MPs taking Mr Botha at his word have been ejected from a parliamentary restaurant still apparently reserved for whites. Fourth, a South African human rights movement has reported that the forced relocation of blacks from areas designated for white use has resumed after an interval of two years. Fifth, a trading licence has been withheld from a white businessman because he is married to someone of another race. Sixth, the security forces are still killing blacks protesting against discrimination.

All this has caused, seventh, the resignation from Parliament of the Opposition Leader, Dr Van Zyl Slabbert, an honourable man who is obviously sickened by the cynicism with which the Government is conducting the affairs of a country in crisis and feels that it is futile for him to continue. These and other developments since the opening of Parliament serve as an indictment of Mr Botha's habit of saying one thing and meaning another. Many white South Africans, desperate for some good news, have been quick to seize on his alleged initiatives as a sign of real hope for the future. Instead, they have been given another reminder that Mr Botha must be judged not on what he says, but on what he does. The time to warm to his words will come when he announces an end to the state of emergency, a firm schedule for repealing all discriminatory legislation, the unconditional release of all political prisoners and the opening of negotiations with authentic black leaders.

That of course has been our policy. Essentially, reform will come from pressures within the country. We must all wish Malcolm Fraser and his group success. I am sure they will do their best, but should they fail I hope that the Government will encourage the major countries I have mentioned to send serving Foreign Ministers to drive the message home to the intransigents. If that fails, other international measures will have to be agreed upon and adopted multilaterally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before speaking to the foreign policy statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) I would like to pay tribute to the sensitivity with which the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) typically has viewed the traumas suffered by black South Africans existing under the brutal regime in South Africa. I have also visited South Africa on a private tour. Some honourable members were given a very brisk tour by the South African Government, but I came to an altogether different conclusion from those members and I appreciate the comments made by the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: In supporting in its entirety the thoughtful and comprehensive statement on Australia's foreign policy made by the most capable Foreign Minister to serve in the Australian Parliament, the Hon. Bill Hayden, I wish to be selective in my commentary. While supporting the diverse policies embracing security arrangements, peace and disarmament, and international diplomacy, I move to what the Minister has called Australia's involvement in the great international social issues, and within this forum focus on Australia's foreign aid program and on the needs of developing nations. Following the recommendation of the Jackson Committee on the Australian Overseas Aid Program that Australia makes its aid more effective by targeting it more carefully, the Foreign Minister has decreed that our program will concentrate its resources on fewer methods of delivery within fewer sectors. We are, therefore, concentrating on areas where we have particular expertise or resources. This is as it should be. Problems faced in the sadly abused continent of Africa highlight the manner in which adverse natural and social conditions can actually be exacerbated by unwise application of aid. This is manifest in problems such as the shift in food preferences away from the African diet towards imported food products and the related issue of dumping of food surpluses as aid without due consideration of the needs of the recipients. I congratulate the Foreign Minister on his acumen in fostering an aid environment which will discourage the development of such problems.

I wish to focus on the special needs of Africa as an illustration of some shared problems of developing nations. Africa is becoming increasingly dependent on industrialised nations and the real tragedy of this is that, as a consequence, its own agricultural patterns are being distorted. It may not be popularly realised that while Africa suffers extreme famine in many areas of that vast continent, it still remains a major source of supply of crops consumed in developed nations, notably the United Kingdom. These include coffee, cocoa, sugar, as well as ground nuts and cooking oil, to mention a few.

Before the colonial era African agriculture was geared to food production and most countries were self-sufficient and secure, but by the end of the nineteenth century, with mining and concession companies staking their claim, African society, already blighted by 300 years of slave trade, was shattered by the new colonial demands for land and labour. This opened the way for European companies to establish big plantations to secure supplies for their own factories in industrial centres-in effect, the era of the multinationals. One of the first foreign-owned plantations was established by Lever Brothers in 1911. Now known as Unilever, this company was one of many which prospered as African society declined and is now the world's biggest food business-a tragic irony. Pertinent to my comments on foreign aid, the badly designed aid programs of recent years have added to Africa's natural problems due to natural and social arrangements.

I would like to quote from the Ecologist of 1984 on the phenomenon of agric business, which is a situation whereby large companies in developed nations are introducing agricultural projects into underdeveloped countries for the stated reason of assisting those countries. The real result is that it is the company from the Western nation which benefits through the sale of pesticides, fertilisers and products such as that. In many cases the very introduction of the project is to the detriment of the people in the underdeveloped nation. The Ecologist states:

That is the nature of agribusiness: The integration of activities designed to make a profit out of the inputs to farming-the seeds, fertilisers, pesticides, agricultural machinery, management and consultancies, animal foodstuffs, research-as well as from, the outputs of the farm.

In effect, aid projects are badly designed, but time and again the schemes developed by experts and funded with aid, channel money into expensive and technically complicated schemes. Foriegn advisers, for instance, tend to favour irrigation schemes, since agricultural production rises spectacularly with regular water supplies. A sceptic would point out that irrigation schemes offer more for donor countries or agricultural consultancies than do rain-fed agricultural products. Some of these projects have a particularly disastrous effect on the people in the under-developed nation. For instance, in Nigeria during the second half of the 1970s the main area of agricultural investment was in large scale irrigation schemes, with devastating effects upon peasant producers. In Northern Nigeria the Talata-Mafara project irrigated 10,000 hectares near the Sokoto River. The work was carried out by Impresit Nigeria Ltd, which is 40 per cent owned by Fiat, and during the three-year construction period 60,000 peasants were moved. They were unable to farm, were given no compensation and finally, when they protested, the state called in armed police to put them down. It was a situation in which the developed nations and the Government of the country where the people were suffering compacted the misery that the people in those nations had suffered during the colonial period.

While I believe that these problems should be recognised publicly, it is important that we recognise also the famine which has been caused by natural features of drought and desertification in Africa. Famine and drought in Africa are not new phenomena. The 1984 Food and Agriculture Organisation report pointed to at least four famine-related crises now present in the region, relating to the appalling droughts of the past few years: Firstly, an environmental crisis caused by less rainfall, acid soils and desertification; secondly, a developmental crisis due to failure to establish effective national development policies; thirdly, an economic crisis because of a reduction in the world demand for Africa's main commodity exports; and, fourthly, a political crisis in specific African countries in addition to problems emanating from unrest in SouthAfrica. Population growth in Africa exacerbates the problems. Production or importation of enough food for the 15 to 20 million additional people each year is a tall order and understandably is beyond Africa's present capabilities.

African countries' food imports increased from $2.4 billion in 1981 to $5.8 billion in 1983. These countries are becoming increasingly dependent upon industrial nations. In the process, agricultural patterns are distorted. The need to create 200 million additional productive jobs between now and the year 2000 does not ease the situation. It is generally accepted that the food aid provided by the Western world is at best a short term solution which is likely to lead to even greater dependence on the part of the recipient African nations, but food must be provided and in greater abundance. It must get through to the hungry, for it is only those with full bellies who can enjoy the luxury of debating the advantages and disadvantages of long and short term aid, yet it must be debated. There is a need for long term agricultural planning and education to rehabilitate a land which was once fertile but which is now exhausted to the point of death.

Overseas aid agencies are providing the guarantee for the funding of large scale production food projects. The USAID's `Food Sector Assistance Strategy for the 1980s for Africa' emphasises increased production using technological advances, new seeds and skilled managers, technicians and administrators, yet it is argued that the problems of internal planning and bad design of projects abound. A number of monitoring agencies, such as the United Nations Children's Fund, the World Food Program and others, have determined standards and guidelines for such programs and have acted in an advisory capacity.

So, what has gone wrong? I believe that the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs has taken the right line in appealing to the United Nations to play a greater role in co-ordinating the international communities. I note with satisfaction the response of the United Nation and member nations to the crisis in Ethiopia. As a major food producer and comparatively affluent middle level power, Australia's contribution has been characterised by increasing its food aid allocations, mainly in the form of wheat; by promoting agricultural research and development programs through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research; and by providing aid through non-government organisations, such as community Aid Abroad, to local level projects emphasising food sufficiency and self-reliance.
I quote from a statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs on overseas aid programs ofNovember 1985, when he said:

The response of Australians to the famine in Africa has been prompt and generous. But long term development strategies are necessary so that the emergency does not continue. Australian aid programs to African countries will therefore focus increasingly on the objective of national food security. The Government is committed to a program which will draw on Australian resources and expertise to tackle the real problems. Our aid to African countries will continue to be channelled mainly through the World Bank and other multilateral organisations. We have already taken steps to look into the possibility of membership of the African Development Bank.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs recognised the potential for abuse of a developing nation when he said in his foreign aid statement:
We must be careful to ensure that such schemes-
that is, the Development Import Finance Facility scheme and the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation-
do not develop primarily as help for Australian industry rather than developing countries.

I refer briefly to one other aspect of the problems faced by developing nations, particularly with reference to the load which is sometimes put on them by developed nations which wish to help; that is, the problem of external debt in developing countries. The external debt in these countries has increased markedly over the past decade. A recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development study shows that while the level of the long term debt in developing countries in 1971 was $86 billion, by 1983 this had grown to $606 billion. The origin of the international debt crisis basically can be tied to the oil crises of 1974 and 1977 and was exacerbated by a sharp decrease in export revenue due to a global recession and an increase in the interest rates on the increased stock of floating rate debt. The burgeoning domestic deficit in developed nations such as the United States of America, which forced up the interest which then had to be paid by the underdeveloped nations struggling to meet a debt which really was incurred because of damage which was done in colonial times, must be recognised. I am pleased at the part the Australian Government is playing in reducing our deficit and have pleasure in giving my full support to the foreign policy statement made by our Foreign Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of my two predecessors in the Federal seat of Curtin, the first and probably the most distinguished was the Rt Hon. Sir Paul Hasluck. He wrote a book in 1948 after resigning from the then Department of External Affairs in protest at the conduct of Australian foreign policy under Evatt. Sir Paul, who was later to serve with great distinction as a Cabinet Minister under Menzies and as a Governor-General of Australia, was then a reader in history at the University of Western Australia. In his book, entitled Workshop of Security, Paul Hasluck wrote that Australia's contribution to world affairs should be one that emphasised `clear, objective, honest thinking and the firm, logical and unprovocative delivery of our views'. He went on to say that our influence rested entirely upon the respect in which Australia is held abroad. He wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: To be influential in the world Australia has to walk with modesty as well as courage, in wisdom and good faith.
Those remarks are as true today as they were when written 38 years ago. They are particularly relevant when we come to examine the substance of the conduct of foreign and defence policy under Labor.

In responding to the statement made by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) on Australia's external relations, my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), himself a distinguished former Foreign Minister, highlighted what he aptly described as the `steady erosion of cohesion, stability and direction in Australia's foreign policy under the Hawke Government'. In his wide-ranging address last year, the honourable member discussed many important aspects of the conduct of Australia's external relations. This evening I want to talk about the broader issues involved in the `creeping nuclear pacifism' evident in some sections of the community and in the Government.

Moral concern about nuclear weapons touches upon a problem vital to mankind's future. Our relatively new-found ability to exterminate ourselves has profoundly affected our notions of war and peace. As a famous British military historian, B. H. Liddlehart has noted:
Old concepts and old definitions of strategy have become not only obsolete but nonsensical with the development of nuclear weapons.
Thomas Schelling, the distinguished Harvard academic, wrote in 1966:
There was a time when the assurance of victory-false or genuine assurance-could make national leaders not just willing, but sometimes enthusiastic, about war. Not now.

The unparalleled power and destructiveness of nuclear weapons is brought home vividly when one reads or listens to eminent scientists detailing the horrors of the worst imaginable case of nuclear devastation. Who, then, can doubtOxford's Professor Michael Howard when he says: `The existence of nuclear weapons makes war seem a superbly unattractive option'. That is a masterful piece of understatement.

Peace is an objective we all share. What we are talking about today is the means of maintaining it. Because of the potential horror of nuclear war, it is easy to be deflected from reasoned discourse. Saying merely `no' to nuclear war is both necessary and difficult since saying `no' does not make it so. Words are, after all, only threshold actions. At best they are only stimuli which, if anything is to be accomplished, must trigger concrete policies. All too often moral passion has led to our streets being turned into a stage upon which the horrors of nuclear havoc are depicted in poster, poetry and pantomime while a chorus insistently proclaims that `something must be done'. Far too many nuclear disarmament campaigners believe that an expression of moral outrage is going to be helpful, saying that nuclear war is an obscenity is going somehow to make it less likely.

TALK.START.PARA: —They should not do that, should they?

—Democratic societies entrust such matters to public discussion. That is one reason why they are worth defending. Democracy itself depends upon the civility and wisdom of the discussions that take place amongst its citizens, and I recommend that sort of approach to the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling). As former United States Secretary of State Henry Kissinger has argued:

SPEECH.PARA: Moral concern must be coupled with a willingness to think through the central issues with a seriousness and in a detail that does justice to dangers as complex as they are enormous.

In particular, leadership in a democracy is exquisitely dependent on cool-headedness and the force of reason-a task made more difficult by the outbursts of passion, wild accusations, flagrant hyperbole and misleading assertions that far too often have been the `substance' of the so-called `peace movement' arguments.
In deciding important questions of public policy, it is a wise procedure to seek first a clear grasp of realities, interests and powers. As Colin S. Gray has noted:

Visions that cannot be implemented can be irresponsible and harmful when they channel attention and creative thought away from more modest practical steps that actually might help reduce the risk of war.

A good example of this failing is Jonathon Schell's book The Fate of the Earth. Schell writes with eloquence and a sophisticated appreciation of the horrors a nuclear war would entail. Yet when he moves to actual proposals in chapter three-apocalyptically entitled `The Choice'-his simple but frightening vision of the future lacks practical detail. Having set out a vast agenda for global change, he says:
I have left to others those awesome urgent tasks which, imposed on us by history, constitute the political work of our age.
As Time magazine's diplomatic correspondent Strobe Talbot noted `Thanks a lot': That is the sort of thing we get in literature from proponents of and people active in the so-called peace movement.
Unfortunately, while passion can give an impetus, only analysis can produce results. As Henry Kissinger has argued:
It is a disservice to serious moral concerns to pretend that there is no practical dimension.

One writer has discussed this matter with the seriousness it deserves is Michael Novak, whose April 1983 essay Moral Clarity in the Nuclear Age is a document of rigorous thought and elegant moral reasoning. I commend his book to members of the community seriously concerned with these issues.

I turn now to a particular matter in the conduct of Australia's external relations. I refer to the peculiar approach of the Hawke Government to the Western alliance. I join with the honourable member for Kooyong in expressing concern at the failure of Labor's foreign policy to recognise in a wider vision the values that underpin the Western alliance. As the honourable member for Kooyong pointed out, `The Western alliance is not just a grouping of powers'; it is `also the embodiment of certain ideas and values which are distinctly part of the Australian character'. Those ideals are democracy, liberty and respect for the individual.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you know why I voted for you.
—That was very kind. I did not know the honourable member had. I thank him very much.

SPEECH.PARA: Forty-one years ago when General Sir Thomas Blamey, then Commander-in-Chief of the Australian Military Forces, issued an order of the day on the occasion of the surrender of the Japanese, he was under no illusion as to why Australian servicemen and women had fought and died. Sir Thomas wrote:
We are now to go to our homes having done our part in ensuring freedom for which we have fought so long and successfully.
I wonder how many people have forgotten that, when we think about what happened in relation to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. However, that is another story.

Whatever the failings of the nations comprising the Western alliance, they are immeasurably superior to the alternative and, as the honourable member for Kooyong reminded us, that alternative has been active in enhancing its own massive military resources and in taking advantage of available opportunities to extend its influence. For, despite all the complex debates that take place about the size, posture and purpose of Soviet military power, the essential facts are clear. As Professor Hedley Bull of Oxford University noted in 1983:

. . . the growth of Soviet military power is no figment of the American imagination: In the course of the 1970s the Soviet Union acquired a lead over the United States in some aspects of strategic nuclear power: It extended its long standing superiority in conventional arms in central Europe: And developed a capacity for direct military intervention in the Third World . . .
Professor Bull went on to argue:

The Americans, moreover, are correct in believing that, whatever else they do, they must first ensure that the Soviet Union does not establish a position of military preponderance in the world as a whole. The maintenance of the global balance of power is a basic condition of international order, without which there would be no prospect of security either for the United States or for its allies, or for neutral third parties. The burden of maintaining this balance is one that only America is capable of carrying, and those of us outside the United States who presume to criticise its policy towards Moscow need always to remember that our own countries do not bear this responsibility.
What is more, it happens all too often. Henry Kissinger noted in 1982:

Little attention is paid to a whole series of aggressive or intransigent Soviet actions, from the dispatch of Cuban troops to Africa through the occupation of Afghanistan, to the repression of freedom in Poland, which not only threatened the global equilibrium but are the proximate cause of the breakdown of strategic arms control negotiations in the 1970s.
Kissinger had already noted in 1981 this amazing phenomenon:

Less than two years after Afghanistan, less than four years after Cuban troops under a Soviet general appeared in Ethopia, six years after the same thing happened in Angola and while thirty-plus Soviet divisions are constantly bringing pressure on Poland, that at this moment there should be mass demonstrations all over Europe-affirming what? The desirability of peace and implying that it is the United States which is the obstacle.

Even less attention has been paid to some basic facts of post-war history: But for Soviet pressures in the immediate post-war period American troops would have been withdrawn from Europe in the 1940s, as indeed they were from Korea; but for the Korean War the United States military budget would have shrunk to derisory levels; it was the threat to the freedom of Berlin in the late 1950s which accelerated the American military buildup; the Soviet strategic arsenal has grown and been modernised relentlessly since the Cuban missile crisis 20 years ago; for a variety of reasons the United States stopped its numerical buildup in the late 1960s and slowed its modernisation for the better part of the 1970s; and all world wars in the post-war period have occurred where there were no American forces and no nuclear weapons, while Europe, under American nuclear protection, has enjoyed the longest period of peace in its history. Kissinger went on to note:
For all these reasons, the clamour for peace in much of the West is in most respects addressed to the wrong government.

All too often foreign policy as conducted under the Australian Labor Party has left the clear impression of fundamental moral incoherence. An excellent example of this Government's tendency to morally and practically incompetent decisions is the disgraceful decision on the proposed Pacific area defence equipment exhibition originally scheduled for this year. After more than $1m and two years planning had gone into attracting over 100 Australian exhibitions as well as companies from Britain, France, Holland, Belgium, Canada and Sweden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) stepped in and said that it was inappropriate for Sydney to host the exhibition because 1986 had been declared the International Year of Peace by the United Nations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issues I want to address arise from statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in regard to human rights issues. The Minister referred to his visit to the Soviet Union last year and indicated that he had raised his concern over the issue of human rights in that country. He also noted that Australia was re-elected for a three-year term on the United Nations Commission on Human Rights starting this year. The starting point for me in relation to the three issues that I wish to canvass is my delight at the release this week of Anatoly Shcharansky by the Soviet Union, presumably as a result of some discussions that took place between the leader of the Soviet Union and President Reagan when they met in Geneva earlier this year. The statement largely ignores the plight of the continuing 11,000 refuseniks, as they have become known. They are the 11,000 people who are politically neutralised in the Soviet Union, risk considerable difficulties in terms of maintaining employment, can often find that they are incarcerated as a result of their desire to leave the Soviet Union and are very often charged with offences of a very specious nature. These people have put their whole career and life at risk in order to exercise what we all regard as a fundamental freedom; the freedom to be able to migrate from one nation to another.

SPEECH.PARA: I have before me a number of papers relating particularly to individuals who have been subjected to harassment and persecution and about whom I would have liked to have given the House more details, but I simply mention them by name: The Lifshitz family, Valadimir Slepak and Ida Nudel. These people have suffered as a result of the Soviet Union's approach to this fundamental question of immigration: The freedom to be able to immigrate from one country to another. These people continue to suffer. I would like the Minister's assurance that Australia, re-elected to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, will raise this question as quickly as possible and draw it to the attention of the Soviet Union so that this issue might be pursued.

The second matter I wish to raise in the context of the exercise of human rights and freedom of religion, the tolerance of other people's religious views and the need to understand the diversity of opinions that people might hold is the way in which Australia has exercised its vote in another forum of the United Nations, the Security Council. Already today in this debate the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) referred to Australia's voting in relation to Israel.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was in the votes at UNESCO.

—I am sorry, I thought it was in relation to the votes at the United Nations. The vote in the United Nations which I wish to bring to the attention of the House is the vote in relation to the Temple Mount question. That has been a very controversial question of late, but in the context of a pluralist society, which Israel is, we saw a situation in which certainly Israelis, including some members of the Knesset, exercised their right which I believe would be the right of people in any society to put their point of view in relation to the way in which religious freedom ought to be able to be exercised. I do not see that as something that one ought to condemn. I certainly would regard it as a matter that might be appropriate to be critical of if they were going to take away from others their rights to exercise their freedom of religion. In this case some people in Israel did this and yet, by our vote in the United Nations-I have read carefully the vote, the draft resolution and the statement by our delegate to the United Nations-we were, to all intents and purposes, condemning Israel and Israelis for the action taken by a few.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it ought to be understood that the very way in which we approach that matter in the United Nations has, I think, put a little dent in our relations with Israel. The Israelis are very tolerant of Australia and Australians. They recognise that we are, like them, a pluralist society and that we do have views. They try to be understanding in relation to these matters, but I think there is a real concern and lack of understanding about the fact that on this vote the United States of America exercised its veto, Thailand abstained and Australia voted with all the other nations against the interests of Israel by condemning it and its people for the actions of a few people. We ought to understand that there can be different views in a democratic society.

The final matter I wish to raise in my brief comments supplements some comments that I made in the Appropriation debate in this House when I spoke about the support of Australia for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. I was concerned that we had in this country reduced significantly our contributions generally to the UNHCR and to special programs from $9,154,621 in 1984 to about $4,776,953 in 1985. That is a significant reduction. It is one that ought to embarrass this Government greatly. It ought to embarrass the Government even more when it considers the report of the UN Commissioner about unprecedented financial crisis. I have before me the UNHCR journal of November in which the editorial comments on the measure of the crisis that the UNHCR is facing. It is described as the worst crisis in the 35-year history of the organisation. It says that there is good reason to fear that important activities undertaken all over the world on behalf of refugees will have to be suspended. Comments are also made by the retiring Commissioner about the size of the short- fall and the consequences for refugees. I hope that the Minister will take time to read those very important comments and to urge his colleagues in the Ministry to reassess Australia's position in relation to this matter and to ensure that our record on human rights questions and our record of support for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees can be restored so that we as a nation will not be left with this blemish on our record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The House has had the benefit of an extended opportunity to debate a statement on foreign affairs. This would be the first occasion for many years on which a wide range of speakers have been allowed to participate in such a debate. I think it would be something like a decade or more since such an opportunity has been provided in this Parliament. It is a shame, therefore, that given such ample opportunity to explore a vast range of the complex issues which arise in foreign affairs so little was presented. The Opposition adopted many postures but took up few positions.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to return more generally to the matter of foreign affairs. In the closing comments which I wish to make perhaps it would be better, for the sake of brevity at this hour, to address myself first to some of the more particular matters which have been raised in the course of debate. What was significant was that although much criticism was levelled against the Government no substantial case was marshalled in any instance. What it means is that while, predictably, the Opposition sought to-we understand why it would want to do so-engage in political posturing for the electorate it really had no concrete case of disagreement to launch against the Government.

Of course, as one would anticipate, observations were made about New Zealand and ANZUS. One of the great glories of opposition, as the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has discovered, is that it is always much easier to fix up difficult problems from the opposition benches than it is from the benches of government where one has to answer for, be responsible for and make things work. I merely say, as an expression of the deep affection and great friendship which I feel for the honourable member for Kooyong, that I trust he is able to enjoy that self-indulgence for many years to come. In the meantime, I have to settle down to the hard work of trying to get around some of these problems and seek solutions and, at the same time, keep together the national interest. I will come back to New Zealand and ANZUS a little later.

Some speakers, including the honourable member for Kooyong, whom I freely acknowledge as a distinguished Foreign Minister of this country for a number of years, took the opportunity to suggest that Australia should have sent observers to the Philippines election. Maybe it should have done so and maybe it should not have. That is a matter of contention between different points of view. My view was then, and it still is, that we should not have, and that we were correct in not sending observers to the Philippines election. It seemed to me that one of the great deficiencies was that, if there was going to be effective monitoring and reliable reporting on the conduct of those elections, a properly structured and well-developed organisation of monitors would have to be put into place. It would have required widespread access to the conduct of the polls at all levels and at all times leading up to, during and after the actual polling. I give one simple symptom of the impediments which were in the way of such an arrangement. People other than those going to a polling booth to cast a vote were not allowed to go within 50 metres of a polling place. This clearly presented problems about the effectiveness of any conduct of monitoring which could be carried out by outsiders. I make no apologies for having made that decision. I repeat: I believe it was the proper one. There were many other reasons as well why that decision was made and they too were proper.

A matter was raised concerning the North West Cape communications station. It was said that the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, and I had declared at various times that it was our intention that that station should be closed in the event that a nuclear first strike capability be developed by the United States of America. No such thing has been said by either Senator Evans or me; certainly not by me. What I said was that in such an event, which would be a critical change in the relationship between the nuclear powers-more specifically the nuclear super-powers-there would be a case for re-evaluation. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) pointed out to me, at about the time that comment was made that was very much a hypothetical proposition and, therefore, scarely merits further consideration at this point.

The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) accused me of closing down the PADEX armaments exhibition which was to be held in Australia. Nothing could be further from the truth. The Government took no such action at all. Private organisations which wish to conduct such exhibitions are entitled to do so. That was made clear to the organisers of PADEX. What was pointed out to PADEX was that the Government would not be participating.
