The Government at no time said that it had contemplated or would contemplate participating and made it clear, when approached, that it would not. It was a decision taken by PADEX of its own volition to not proceed with that exhibition.

The honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) raised questions about the United Nations Commission on Human Rights and refuseniks. He queried whether the Australian Government would pursue such matters in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights Commission. I can assure him that we have done it in the past and we will continue to do so in the future. The honourable member expressed concern about our voting in the Security Council of the United Nations on a resolution relating to an incident at Temple Mountain in Jerusalem. The facts are that Australia voted with the other Western countries on the Security Council other than the United States. The United States, I seem to recall, exercised a veto. The incident referred to was much more complex and potentially much more provocative, perhaps even dangerous, than the honourable member preferred to acknowledge. There are no apologies from the Government of Australia for having cast a positive vote for that resolution. I think that if the honourable member looks at those who also cast a positive vote he will note that Australia was in good Western company when it did so.

The honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) raised the proposition that there should be a political appointment to Washington. He suggested that there would be the opportunity for developing more influence in Washington with a political appointment. There is clear evidence that political appointments can be extremely effective. Sir Robert Cotton was an effective political appointment both in New York and in Washington. Mr Bill Morrison in Jakarta and Mr Les Johnson in Wellington-I must in particular emphasise the valuable role which Mr Les Johnson has been contributing to Australia in his reporting from New Zealand-are two cases of political appointments made by this Government who have been extremely successful. Having said that, it would be unfair not to put on the record also that career officers equally, and sometimes even more so, can be extremely successful in these roles at sensitive political points in the world. The Ambassador to Washington at present, Mr Dalrymple, has proved to be a splendid appointment. I have no regrets at all at about having chosen Mr Dalrymple. His qualities, experience and contribution in the foreign service in the past speak for themselves. His performance now emphasises what an excellent professional he had been. This is true generally of the officers in the Department of Foreign Affairs. I cannot speak of them in any terms other than those of the highest praise for the way in which they go about the task of serving the government of the day, for the diligent and generous way in which they take upon themselves the duties they have to fulfil for the government of the day.

It is unfortunate that the International Year of Peace program was criticised by a number of speakers from the Opposition benches. The International Year of Peace is an undertaking designated as such by the United Nations. It is an extremely important project and I believe it will be quite effective in sensibly projecting the policies of the Government in connection with arms control and disarmament, in its efforts to promote processes which will resolve conflicts before they break out into aggression, and in emphasising that the dominant theme in the mind of the Government is to search for better ways in which to bring about peace. I do not believe that in principle or, indeed, much in practice there is anything of great difference between the Opposition and the Government on those causes. Therefore, I ask the Opposition to await patiently the development of both the informative advertising the Government will undertake as part of the International Year of Peace program and other activity which will broadly involve the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have only given us chickenfeed-$3,000 is all we have got. You have not provided enough. We had a better case to put but you denied us funds.

—I notice that in opposition the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) not only fixes up the most complex problems much more easily than he did in government but he spends much more extensively and generously than he was prepared to when he was in government. I merely point out that this is a worthwhile program and it deserves broad political support.

SPEECH.PARA: The most diverting and entertaining proposition put forward tonight was that of the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), who accused me of being responsible for policies of `creeping towards neutrality and non-alignment'. I really found this quite delightful because only last weekend I was speaking to another group of people who, just as he is placed to the right of the political spectrum, were placed to the left of the political spectrum, and they accused me of being too deeply involved in and committed to the United States alliance. I must have something worthwhile going for me when I cop that sort of barrage from both sides of the political spectrum.

I conclude by saying that the guiding influence of the Government in defining its foreign policy is to serve the national interest, which is paramount, but in doing so to temper its objectives by humanitarian concerns. For me at least-I know this is also true of members of the Opposition-it is important to be guided by the great and enduring principles and values of democratic socialism. Accordingly, we go about our tasks with, I trust, resourcefulness and persistency in developing the policies we have elaborated. We do this on arms control, human rights, global economic issues, and in regional matters which concern us, as well as of course the important bilateral relationships we have and which we seek to improve.

It is not possible to go through all the matters which would elaborate those principles or issues I have mentioned. I merely want to conclude on a regional issue, and that is ANZUS and New Zealand. It is all very well for the Opposition to say how it would mediate. It is quite impressive to hear Opposition members, who have no responsibility and are not likely to have any responsibility in this matter, declare how quickly they would intimidate the New Zealanders into behaving themselves and fulfilling the expectations of the Opposition. The undeniable fact is that New Zealand is a sovereign country which is quite proud of its sovereignty and it has displayed the fact that it can be rather prickly with people who unwisely seek to intrude into its affairs in the way in which the honourable member for Kooyong particularly has suggested.

Let us get one thing clear: Both the United States and New Zealand are eminently satisfied that the role Australia has been fulfilling in this matter is the most productive and positive role which can be contributed. That is the first point. The second point is that, much as we regret the situation in relation to ANZUS at present, we must also acknowledge that the test, while we seek a way through this, is to keep the bilateral relationships in respect of both the United States and New Zealand in good stead. That is no easy task and that we have been working out successfully.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Retirement of Mr Kevin Chapman-Taxation Proposals: Primary Producers-Australian Federal Police: Wollongong Office-Telecom: Telephone Directories-Terrorism-Defence Service Homes Corporation: Insurance-Petrol Prices-Belconnen Mall

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.15 p.m. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn

Before the House adjourns, I would like to mention that today is the last occasion on which Mr Kevin Chapman will be assisting the House as an announcer with the parliamentary broadcast. Mr Chapman first made the announcements for the broadcast of the House proceedings in 1957, some 29 years ago, and for much of the time since then he has been a familiar figure to members at his place in the broadcasting booth at the rear of the chamber. During that time he has become a close friend of many members and others who work in this building. By his voice he has become known to many, many Australians across the length and breadth of the land who have tuned in to Parliament. I wonder how many Treasurers have been introduced to the nation on Budget night by Kevin Chapman.

On behalf of all members, I would like to thank Kevin for his contribution to the parliamentary broadcasting over so many years and to extend to him and his wife our best wishes for the future. We wish you, Kevin, a long, healthy and happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I was looking to see whether we were being broadcast when you were making all those complimentary remarks about Mr Chapman. On behalf of the Government, I too would like to extend to Kevin our very best and thank him for the unique and outstanding job he has done for a considerable number of years. This is a job which must be done very modestly and one that does not attract a great deal of attention. Only those of us who have worked in this Parliament over the years know the sort of burden he has had to carry and the way in which the proceedings have had to be presented. Kevin Chapman has become very well known to many of us in more ways than one, and I am sure it will be along time before his contribution to this Parliament, via the broadcast, will be forgotten. For a person who has served this Parliament and the Australian people so well for so long, he deserves the commendation which he has received from this Parliament.

—I would like to associate the Opposition with the sentiments that have been expressed by the Leader of the House (Mr Young). Mr Chapman has become something of an institution through his association with parliamentary broadcasts. For those in the community who are rather more fanatical about politics than others, including many outside this House, his voice has become very well known in their households. To have served in that position for almost 30 years and at the same time to have maintained and extended his reputation as an extremely competent and effective general broadcaster in other areas is a remarkable achievement. His personality has been well respected and well liked around Parliament House. The contribution he has made to the flow of broadcasting and information from this Parliament to the Australian public is a quite remarkable one. I certainly share the good wishes which you, Madam Speaker, conveyed to him: That he and his family have a very long, happy and healthy retirement. He has served this Parliament and the institutions of democracy extremely well. He has been a credit to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. We on this side of the House wish him well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of members of the National Party of Australia I would like to join in the remarks of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). I regret that the remarks which the three of us are making about a man who has for so long been associated with the radio waves are not themselves being broadcast. I feel this denies those who are his listening audience the right to hear those things that we would say about him. He is a man whom perhaps most members do not recognise around the corridors. He might well be one who would not be known were his name not so frequently heard by us all in his general broadcasting responsibilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Our Parliament is one of the few which have all their proceedings broadcast. Those people who sit in the broadcasting box are observers of our highways and byways, of our good times and bad times, of our triumphs and our occasional failures. It is a unique responsibility that they have. While those who sit in the gallery look on us as being in a fish bowl, those who are in the glass cage of the broadcast box are even more so. We see them through the glass, but darkly. We hear their voices and, more often than not, they hear ours.

Kevin is one who in the execution of his duties has performed his task nobly and well. At a personal level, I pay him tribute for the manner in which he has exercised his responsibilities as an officer of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, for the way in which he has served this Parliament in the monitoring of the broadcasting and the way in which one has always been able to listen to him and keep up with what is going on in the chamber when one is not here oneself. Outside that role of broadcaster for the Parliament, he certainly has been a very noble citizen of this country and a very effective servant of the people in his role as a general broadcaster. I, like you Madam Speaker, wish him, his wife and family a long, healthy and happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to associate myself with the sentiments already expressed. I make no apology for being very fond of Kevin. I have known him for many years. I admired him many years before that. When at the end of every Parliament we have said `thank you' to various people who have served this Parliament well I must say that I cannot recall anyone having thanked the Australian Broadcasting Corporation people, of whom Kevin was foremost. Perhaps we should thank them all, but particularly Kevin. He was one of the pioneers of Australian radio and television. He read the television news quite early in the piece before he moved permanently to Canberra. He is one of those people who have been the epitome of the ABC we all remember and, we hope it will, albeit in somewhat different form, become again a permanent feature of Australian life.

SPEECH.PARA: Kevin was a very fine participant in the proceedings of the Parliament. He was totally professional, totally apolitical and he was extremely admired, respected and, indeed, loved by those who had the privilege of getting to know him. I join all of those honourable members who tonight have said how much they think of him. As the Leader of the National Party, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), has rightly said, this is not being broadcast so perhaps, just as Kevin observed the protocol required by the Act which governs the broadcasting of this Parliament, those who are in the broadcasting booth tomorrow, without breaching that Act, will be able to make reference to the fact that their erstwhile colleague has been paid this tribute by this House tonight and by the Senate last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's ill-advised and discriminatory tax proposals will come before this Parliament in the very near future. Some of those proposals have already been debated and passed into legislation with the support of the Australian Democrats in the Senate, against the combined Opposition parties' vigorous alternatives. One of the most iniquitous and discriminatory proposals is the quarantining of farm losses. Tomorrow several thousand primary producers will visit Parliament House to make known to the Government their concern over a whole range of Government decisions which have adversely affected their incomes, their families and the rural way of life. That follows on from a demonstration of tens of thousands of farmers only eight months ago in July last year.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a great many rightful and legitimate complaints of primary producers and the small business people who are interlinked with those who till the soil. Amongst these concerns are, of course, the taxation proposals to be debated by this Parliament in the very near future-I understand that probably this debate will commence next week, although the Government has been so tardy and in such legislative confusion that it is doubtful that anyone can be quite certain just when that long-awaited legislation will see the light of day. One thing we can be certain of is that off-farm income is to be severely restricted, so much so that off-farm income above $20,000, running down to $40,000 will be disallowed. This will have a disastrous effect on many primary producers. The best estimates show us that probably around 60 per cent of farmers exist only because of income earned off the farm. How many of that 60 per cent of farmers range above the $20,000 off-farm income level is a matter for debate. I believe it would be a very significant proportion.

What is indefensible is that young people wishing to start up a farm, to purchase a property and the stock and equipment necessary for working a farm, must work off the land. For instance, I know of several couples in my electorate who work off the farm, one partner as a nurse and the other perhaps as a teacher-they work in any number of professions. How else are these people to purchase land with interest rates at 20 per cent? There is no possibility of their starting out on a property other than by earning off-farm income.

Another aspect of limiting off-farm income which has not yet been discussed as it should be is its effect on private foresters. There are two great problems here. Firstly, foresters harvest, with some thinning out over the years, only after about 20 years. Consequently their investment is not rewarded for some 20 years. The second problem is that until the forest is harvested they are incurring losses which cannot be written off against any income.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they can.

—The honourable member for McMillan has been visited by representatives of the Australian Forest Development Institute. He has been given the facts, as have the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). None of them has properly responded. Not one of them can answer why it is that somebody who has invested in primary production and who does not expect a return for 20 years-sometimes 30 years-should not be entitled to write off the maintenance costs, the fertilising costs and the thinning costs. It is no exaggeration to say that these taxation proposals will finish off in one hit, will kill off, private forestry. This is at a time when Australia imports $1.3 billion worth of timber products. We should be more self-sufficient. We should be encouraging more those people who are prepared to take the risk, those people who are prepared to invest.

SPEECH.PARA: The House should see it as self-evident that this involves an enormous investment and enormous risk. Many of these investors regard the eventual harvest as so far down the line as to be their superannuation-their retirement fund. The submission by the AFDI and my arguments are supported entirely by the Australian Forestry Council, which is made up solely of State Ministers. We must have incentives, not just for primary producers such as farmers but also for those private foresters who have contributed enormously to the Australian economy and who, in a very brave and perhaps even innovative way, are seeking to develop a new industry or expand a fledgling industry, to the benefit of all Australians and seeking less reliance on imports.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to refute some outrageous claims that were made yesterday evening in the adjournment debate in the Senate by Senator Michael Baume concerning the closure of the Australian Federal Police office in Wollongong. The facts are plainly wrong, misleading and fanciful. I want to refer quickly to the information that was contained in his speech. He indicated that he had been refused a request to attend a meeting which I and my colleagues from the south coast attended with the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) to discuss this matter yesterday. I point out to the House and to Senator Michael Baume that he approached me only the night before, seeking representation at that meeting. In fact, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) also approached one of my colleagues on the morning that meeting was to take place.

SPEECH.PARA: Interestingly enough, not one of those two gentlemen had made either a written or oral representation to the Special Minister of State expressing their concern about the potential closure of the office; rather, in the case of Senator Michael Baume, he chose the more expedient way of going straight to the media and getting front page headlines without getting the facts. We, of course, chose the more appropriate manner. We collected our facts and we then went to the Minister and we made representations. On a number of occasions, my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and I contacted the Minister by telephone and by letter and made a number of representations. Interestingly enough, Senator Michael Baume said that only after widespread concern expressed in the media did the local Labor members get on the bandwagon and take this matter forward. As I have indicated, that is total rubbish. We did not grandstand, but we gathered the facts before we went.

Senator Michael Baume also alluded to the role played by the Lord Mayor of Wollongong, saying that he had made representations. Yes, he did. He wrote to everyone of the local Federal members, and we made representations again on his behalf to the Special Minister of State. We took a regional approach when we were approached in the correct manner.

It was indicated by Senator Michael Baume in his speech last night that this was a political stunt by the four local members. If this was a political stunt, I say let us have more of it, because, as a result of the representations made by the four members, today the Minister was pleased to announce that the closure of that office has been suspended at least until Easter. More importantly, there will be a wide-ranging inquiry into many of the claims that have been made by the honourable senator and by others in the Illawarra region concerning drug trafficking, social security fraud and a range of other criminal activities. There will be a thorough investigation which will look at all of those claims and those involved in that investigation will have to report back to the Commissioner of Police and to the Minister. That decision has come as a direct result of consultation carried on with local members in the appropriate way.

I speak on behalf of my colleagues. I know that the honourable member for Throsby is present in the House now. We do not reject a regional approach. I say to the honourable member for Gilmore, who is also present, that we welcome that decision. We would like to see these issues being taken up at every opportunity, provided it is done in the correct manner and that when approaches are made we should sit down and talk about them reasonably. We accept that we should go and get the facts before we race off to the newspaper to grab banner headlines.

It has been said that the facts sometimes can get in the way of a good story. I suggest that this is the case with regard to this issue. Quite frankly, this has not been a political stunt on behalf of my colleagues and me. I reject totally out of hand that implication that has been made. We have achieved results in our quiet achieving way, which is the hallmark of the Hawke Government. We do not grandstand but rather we collect the facts. More importantly, I share with my colleagues the honourable member for Throsby, the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) and the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) the concern that has certainly been expressed by the honourable member for Gilmore with regard to the whole question of drug trafficking and the problems associated with criminal development that have been evident on the south coast and have been brought to the attention of the important people in that area who conduct inquiries.

The Minister had indicated that when this investigation is carried out he would welcome the input of the local community. He would want the people who have information about these sorts of things, such as the role of Port Kembla as a potential drug importation area, to come forward and make information available to the task force and to the four police officers who will remain in the area. I can also say on behalf of my three colleagues that we will do everything in our power to ensure that the police force in that area conducts its inquiries in a correct and proper manner, that the results are translated into an appropriate action plan for the Illawarra area and that if it is proven that the presence of the Australian Federal Police is required in that area, we will be pleased to see that happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak, Madam Speaker, may I convey to you the congratulations that are in order publicly on your elevation to office. These are not merely the obligatory congratulations that one feels one ought to utter, but they have blossomed as a result of the association I had with you when you were Chairman of Committees and as a result of the way in which you allowed the Deputy Chairmen of the Committees to become familiar with their role. Would you pass on my congratulations to the Chairman of Committees on his appointment.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a new year, a new parliamentary session. With the coming of the new year we have had the issue of Telecom Australia's new telephone directories. Let us make no bones about it: Issuing a new telephone directory for Australia is in itself a mammoth task. It involves taking all those Australians who are telephone subscribers, checking where they should fit in to the book and, in addition, doing just as large an excercise with regard to the yellow pages. Taking all of those who buy advertising space in the yellow pages and listing them appropriately is an enormous task. In fact, I was surprised to find that 16.4 million directories are printed in Australia every year-more than one directory for every man, woman and child, regardless of age. Some 5.4 million white pages and five million yellow pages are printed for the urban areas. For the country areas 4.9 million books are printed. This is a Telecom Australia project. The Victorian, South Australian, Tasmanian and Northern Territory directories are printed by the Adelaide Advertiser. The New South Wales and Queensland books are printed by William Brooks. In Western Australia the books are printed by the Government Printing Office. The paper comes from Tasmania and this is, as I said, very much an Australian project.
Tonight I want to commend Telecom for that project and to commend it for the prompt and obliging way which it deals with the inquiries that I make as a Federal member.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are printing too many books.

—To placate the honourable member for Gippsland, I rise to condemn Telecom for the way in which it printed the latest of these directories. Everyone in a country area knows how important is the map on the back of each directory to the use of that directory. In fact it is more important than the listing that is inside. All rural members know how they grab the directory and check the map on the back to see whether it covers a country town in their electorate so that they can make the appropriate call. Would honourable members believe that the latest directory for country areas has been printed without that map on the back? I hesitate in any way to mislead the House. I must say that the map does exist. It may be found between the yellow and white pages, if one can find it. The place for it is on the back of the directory.

SPEECH.PARA: I have raised this matter with Telecom and with the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) and I have had a good hearing. That does not alter the fact that the books have come out without a map at the back. I rise to plead with Telecom and with the Minister to ensure that next year's directories reflect the sort of foresightedness that would place the map where it belongs, on the back of the directories.

Only someone with an urban mentality could have produced a directory like this. How on earth is one expected to find the map which is more important than the alphabetical listing when one has to fumble round inside the directory between the yellow and white pages? This is an absurdity. Frankly, this makes the directory relatively ineffectual, given the time one will have to spend thumbing through the directory for the map of the area it applies to. Who on earth would create a telephone directory that does not easily tell one to which area it refers?

TALK.START.PARA: —Only a Labor government.
—As the honourable member for Gippsland said: `Only a Labor government'. I can say this-
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to have this opportunity to congratulate you, Madam Speaker, on your appointment to the high office of Speaker. I am very pleased to think, having looked at the long rows of photographs of male faces outside the chamber, that some time hence-some years hence-your photograph will be there, too, and will improve that long row.

SPEECH.PARA: The present escalation of terrorism involving the killing of innocent victims is a deplorable and evil phenomenon. It must not be forgotten, however, that one person's terrorist is another person's freedom fighter. These terms are, in any case, used for blatant propaganda purposes by political activists of both the Left and the Right. My personal definition of a terrorist is a person who is prepared to undertake an act of violence as a political weapon even if that act involves the killing of innocent people. In my definition, therefore, both the Contra mercenaries in Nicaragua, whom President Reagan calls freedom fighters, and the rebel Abu Nidal group, who were once part of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, whom Colonel Gaddafi calls freedom fighters, are, for example, quite clearly terrorists.

My concern, and the reason for my comments tonight, is the fact that the present concentration on security measures for dealing with Middle East terrorists is overlooking the tragic reason for the acts of terrorism, which, in the case of the Palestinian people, is their desperate need for a homeland of their own. As Sheikh Fehmi El-Imam, a leading figure of the Arab community in Australia, indicated recently in Melbourne, the recent acts of terrorism could not be justified, but arose because of the frustration of the Palestinian people, who for 40 years have fought to regain their homeland. `As long as the disease continues', said Sheikh El-Imam, `there will be no peace in the Middle East.

Similarly, the Palestine Liberation Organisation has condemned the acts of terrorism at the Rome and Vienna airports and has continued to call for peace talks with Israel and the five Permanent members of the Security Council. It is a matter of great regret to me that the Israeli Government continues to refuse to negotiate any peace proposal with the Palestine Liberation Organisation, presumably because any lasting peace would involve recognition of the rights of Palestinians to self-determination and the withdrawal of Israel from the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The United States Central Intelligence Agency has claimed that it has proof that the Libyan leader, Colonel Gaddafi, was behind the terrorist attacks on the Rome and Vienna Airports, but these claims have been refuted by a number of countries, including Austria and Greece.

However, the Melbourne Herald of 8 January 1986 made an even more irresponsible claim in a front page article with the large headlines `We're on Libya Hit List: Hayden' and `Australia is Number 3 on Libya Hit List, Warns Hayden'. The article went on to quote the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in correctly as stating `we are under constant threat' and `Australia is as exposed as any country to the depredations to terrorism'. On the following day the Herald published the Foreign Minister's refutation on the bottom right hand corner of the second page of the newspaper and excused the sensationalism of its headlines by saying that the Minister's comments were paraphrased and attributed as a direct quote by mistake and were withdrawn after appearing in only one issue. In the circumstances I would like to quote what the Minister for Foreign Affairs did say, because whilst the Herald published his actual statement, it was given little prominence in the newspapers. He said:

I'm not sure why we were listed so high (by terrorists dealing with Australians who are hijacked), because I regard our policy towards the Middle East as a very even handed policy, a very fair policy.
It respects the position of Israel, but sees some shortcomings. It recognises the justifiable claims of the Palestinian people but it recognises also that there are shortcomings there.
It recognises the role of the PLO if there's to be any conclusion to the unfortunate situation in the Middle East.

But on the other hand, there clearly can't be any role for the PLO while it denies the right of Israel to exist. So if you sort out what we are saying, it's clearly a very even handed and fairly constructed policy. Nonetheless, this decision has apparently been made and I'm not sure why.

So to come back to my initial point, the pre-occupation of the media with the acts of terrorism is overshadowing the tragedy of the Palestinian Arab people who are dispossessed in their own land. One of the most cruel but least known aspects of life under Israeli occupation is the breakup of many Palestinian families. The Israeli military authorities decreed that any Palestinian who was not physically present in the West Bank and Gaza when they were seized by Israel in 1967 lost his or her right to residence. This is most improper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, may I add my congratulations to you on your election to your high office. I wish to raise some serious questions about the apparent contradictions in the Defence Service Homes Corporation home insurance statement of conditions which came into effect on 1 November 1985. The first paragraph is misleading, to say the least. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government provides this home insurance under the Defence Service Homes Act for your benefit as a person who is about to receive, or has already received the assistance of the Defence Service Homes Corporation in the purchase of your home.

I suggest that the selective use of words, including the introductory words, `the Australian Government', implies that there is no choice for the insurer who has received purchasing assistance through the Defence Service Homes Corporation. A Press release from the Department of Veterans' Affairs of 1 October 1980 clearly states:
Borrowers will be able to insure their homes with the insurer of their choice.
This further suggests a conflict with the provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. More problems arise in the first paragraph on page 7, which says:
We will not be liable to pay if you can recover your costs under other insurance.

Providing the statement of conditions that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) tabled on 12 November 1985 has been prepared to accommodate the provisions of the Insurance Contracts Act 1984, which became operative from 1 January 1986, the defence service homes insurance scheme will be in breach of the Insurance Contracts Act 1984. It will be in breach of this Act because the Insurance Contracts Act specifically provides for the policy holder to be given the right to recover his loss from any one or more of the insurers and in any sequence he chooses, but provides that he cannot recover an amount that exceeds the amount of the loss. The insurer against whom a claim is made must pay, whether or not there is other insurance. The insurers may then obtain contributions from each other in accordance with their rights. On page 11 the following statements appear:
If your home is damaged by any of the events listed on pages 3 to 5 we will:
pay the cost of repairing or reinstating your home, or repair or reinstate your home.

We do not have to reinstate your home or any part of it exactly. We will repair or reinstate to the extent and manner that we consider to be reasonable. Our determination in this matter will be final and conclusive.

These statements have mind-boggling implications. For example, here we have an insurer saying that in the event of a total loss it will either pay the cost of reinstating the home or arrange to have the home rebuilt itself. However, if the insurer wishes to exercise his right to take charge of the rebuilding it will reinstate to the extent and in the manner that it thinks reasonable. If the policy holder does not like it, that is obviously just bad luck, for the conditions clearly state: `Our determination in this matter will be final and conclusive'.

Again, this is the very kind of heavy-handed tactic the Australian Law Reform Commission wanted to eliminate. The insured must, of course, have the right to take legal action if he believes he has been disadvantaged. This amazing statement appears to be an attempt to oust the jurisdiction of the courts; one of the reasons why the Law Reform Commission recommended changes to protect insurance consumers and which ultimately resulted in the new Insurance Contracts Act. But, would one believe, worse follows; for the policy goes on to state:
. . . if your home is destroyed and we agree that it would be inappropriate to rebuild, we will pay the market value of your home . . .

I ask honourable members to reflect on this. Let us say the reinstatement value is $50,000 with $30,000 for the market value. If the property is destroyed the policy then allows the Defence Service Homes Corporation to pay out $30,000, rather than the sum insured of $50,000. All the Corporation has to do is to say `we agree it would be inappropriate to rebuild'.
I think these few examples that I have referred to, suggest that this critical policy condition is misleading, deceptive and sets a trap for unsuspecting policy holders.

We may well ask, given the poor drafting, inconsistencies and conflict with the Insurance Contracts Act: What corrective action does the Minister propose to take to ensure that the policy is rewritten to reflect the principles outlined by the Australian Law Reform Commission and incorporated in the Insurance Contracts Act 1984? We could be entitled to ask further: Since the Government announced in its last Budget that it proposes to privatise a major part of the operations of the Defence Service Homes Corporation, perhaps it should also consider privatising the insurance scheme, especially since it cannot even get the wording of conditions correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks the National Party Government in Queensland has been desperately trying to deve- lop a campaign against the Hawke Labor Government on the issue of petrol prices. The Premier Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen and Employment and Industrial Affairs Minister Lester have even threatened legal action if the international price reductions are not passed on to the Australian motorist. When one looks very carefully at a document which has been presented to me today and which comes from the Queensland Transport Department, it is clear that the attitudes expressed by the Premier and the Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs are gross hypocrisy. They have been bleating about the high cost of petrol in non-metropolitan areas, and yet for many months, in fact since 25 November 1985, they have been carefully covering up their own activities and their own policies, which have continued to hold up the prices of country fuel.

SPEECH.PARA: For years the minority National Party Government in Queensland has enforced a policy relating to the transport of petroleum products. This policy gives special advantage to the Queensland Railway Department. One might say: `That is fair enough. If you have a State Railway Department you want to ensure that it is able to carry the products around the State'. But under these rules no one is allowed to transport petroleum products more than 80 kilometres from local ports by road. Instead, it must be transported by rail unless a special permit is given. This has effectively forced up the price of fuel in all country areas and in all provincial city areas. For example, if one looks at the township of Emerald in central Queensland, the freight cost of fuel from Rockhampton to Emerald is 4.3c a litre, and that is because it is transported by rail. If it was transported by road, it would be 1.8c a litre and a maximum of 2c a litre. In a place called Taroom in central Queensland, the cost of freight is 8c a litre by rail. If, however, it was taken by road it would be around 3c a litre. So the motorists of the country areas and the townships of central Queensland are paying, in this instance, up to 5c a litre extra because of the State Government's policy.

Let us look at the Darling Downs and the township of Dalby and the freight differential that the State Government is involved in. The freight cost by rail is 3.2c. If the fuel was taken by road it would be approximately one cent. It is costing farmers and townspeople somewhere between 1/2c and 8c a litre throughout Queensland because of the State Government's policy. For years it has been promising to change that policy. A committee of inquiry in September 1984, headed by the Minister for Transport, Mr Lane, decided to bring down some recommendations. I have here the bulletin that has been put out by that Department. It states:
The Queensland Government has recently approved changes to the policy relating to the transport of petroleum products.

The changes are a result of the recommendation of a committee of enquiry established in September 1984 by the Hon. the Minister for Transport, Mr D. F. Lane, M.L.A. The Committee made extensive investigations into the distribution of petroleum products by rail and road throughout the State.
The Committee's recommendations advocated major changes to the transport of petroleum products in Queensland.
As a result the requirement of obtaining a permit for the carriage of packaged petroleum products by road is to be lifted as from 1 December, 1985.
That really means nothing because we are talking about packaged petroleum products, which is a very small part of the total tonnage. The article continues:
The current restrictions placed on the road transport of bulk petroleum products will be progressively abolished over a period of two years-
I emphasise two years-

or such other period as determined by budgetary constraints. The program for the progressive deregulation of bulk petroleum traffic will be formulated by the Commissioner for Transport and Railways in consultation with the Under Treasurer.
The deregulation of bulk petroleum traffic will not be implemented in any particular area of the State until (a) six months has elapsed from introduction of revised railway freight rates-

In other words, there will be a six-month period for the Railway Department to get the edge and to keep its customers. What this has meant, and honourable members need to know this, is that the people of Queensland have been conned and are being conned by the Queensland Government. It has been taxing the Queensland motorist to the tune of millions of dollars, using the Railway Department as a taxing agent. This is a totally hypocritical attitude. Again, the National Party is showing that it is anti-rural and anti-motorist. I do not believe it is fitting for the Premier or for the Minister for Employment and Industrial Affairs to be criticising anyone else about high prices of fuel when they themselves have been keeping up the price of petrol in Queensland. They stand condemned and exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I said two weeks ago that there was a whiff of scandal over the flogging off of the Belconnen Mall for a paltry $87m. I say tonight that there is a stench hanging over the whole affair. Earlier today in Question Time I put certain questions, based on cast iron evidence, to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I challenged the Prime Minister to table in this House this day and before the House rose this day the executed sale contract for the Belconnen Mall. Nearly eight hours have elapsed and this Prime Minister has failed to table in this Parliament the executed sale contract of an asset of the people, owned by the people of Canberra, the property of the taxpayers of Australia. On any proper valuation, the property was worth over $100m and now has been shamefully flogged off at a Sale of the Century price of $87m. This asset of the people has been sold by the Prime Minister and his Government, but despite seven hours discussion and the frantic calling to this Parliament House of public servants, who were summonsed here at a few minutes notice, the Prime Minister has not had the courage to table the very document which will damn him and his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia are entitled to have specific answers to specific questions. Two days ago I placed on the Notice Paper of this House 14 specific questions requiring 14 specific answers. To date they remain unanswered. The silence is deafening. I have alleged, and many others support me, that the Belconnen Mall is worth over $100m if it is worth a cent. It has been flogged off at a bargain basement price, which is just a scandal. Yet was it not the Prime Minister who just a couple of weeks ago was pontificating about flogging off the assets of the people to rich friends in private enterprise? I have alleged today that at the time tenders closed the plant and equipment at the Belconnen mall were worth-I will quote the figure to the dollar-$4,003,327. To the amazement of everybody, the executed contract of sale will show when it is finally tabled in this Parliament that the value of plant and equipment has rocketed to nearly $9m.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—Nearly $9m. I will now give the House for the first time the exact figure. Let us see if it coincides with the figure in the executed contract of sale when the Prime Minister is forced to table it in this Parliament. The figure-I invite honourable members to note it down right here and now-is $8,921,710. That is a very substantial upwriting of plant and equipment in just a few months. This means that the lucky purchasers-we still have to discuss in detail who they might be-have received a windfall tax benefit of $2.4m. I heard the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), who is at the table, pontificating on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio today about tax evasion and tax avoidance. The Minister should have a good look at this one. He will find that the lucky purchasers, whoever they might be, have received a windfall tax benefit of $2.4m. That is five times the amount involved in the Australian Bicentennial Authority affair about which the Prime Minister called for the head of that very great Australian, Mr John Reid. These lucky purchasers, when we find out exactly who they are-we have to be patient-out of the blue are now entitled to claim an extra $5m for depreciation on plant and equipment which has already been properly depreciated by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, a statutory authority of the Commonwealth and under the control of a Minister of the Crown. The Prime Minister hides behind the skirts--
—Order! The honourable member should watch the imputation.

—Yes, indeed. There is much more to come. I have not even got on to these photographs yet. I am going to talk about a few people who have been in the wrong place at the wrong time, with the wrong company, but I will come to that later.
—I suggest to the honourable member that he had best be careful when he does.
—Madam Speaker, I am in the fortunate position of having to answer no charges, but others might in the fullness of time.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjouned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Domestic Air Travel: Department of Science

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Detailed records relating to the number of RAAF personnel regularly engaged on coastal protection duties have not been held over the last ten years. However, P3 Orion aircraft are currently engaged on coastal protection duties at an average rate of 2.5 sorties per week with an aircrew of ten personnel per sortie. Whilst this equates to 25 RAAF personnel per week, the figure is indicative only as the same personnel can be involved in more than one sortie per week.

RAN personnel involved in coastal protection duties comprise two groups, those employed in the Patrol Boat Force and those employed in the Fleet Air Arm's S2E/G Tracker detachments. Tracker aircraft detachments operated from Broome then Darwin between April 1975 and December 1980. Each detachment comprised 39 personnel and the total number of flight personnel involved during this period was 117. (b) No detailed records have been held on the number of RAAF aircraft regularly engaged on coastal protection duties since 1975. Between April 1975 and December 1980, three RAN Trackers were based at Darwin or Broome. One Tracker aircraft was engaged in surveillance of the Bass Strait area during the period December 1980 to December 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to strengthen the judicial standing of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal since March 1983?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is the licensing and regulatory body for the broadcasting industry. It also provides a forum for licensees, applicants for licences, other interested parties and the general public to express their views about the way in which our commercial and public broadcasting sectors should function and develop. It has regard to the public interest in complex issues such as the grant and renewal of licences.

As such, it is important that the Tribunal contain within its members a range of skills and expertise. Legal knowledge, as applied to broadcasting, is clearly one of the desirable areas of expertise. Since March 1983 the Government has strengthened the Tribunal, already strong in this area, by appointing a number of new members recognised for their knowledge of broadcasting law.
As well, significant amendments to the legislation dealing with the powers and functions of the Tribunal to strengthen and improve its effectiveness became effective from 1 January 1986.
The most important changes were contained in two pieces of legislation:

(1) The Broadcasting and Television Amendment Act 1985 introduced provisions which significantly streamline the inquiry procedures of the ABT and thus remove any of the concerns over the conduct of public inquiries which had arisen since their introduction in 1978. The Tribunal will now conduct its inquiries into the exercise of substantive powers under a set of uniform inquiry procedures. The detailed procedures which will provide clear statements of the powers and discretions of the Tribunal, will be set down in regulations. These regulations are currently being finalised. In addition, amendments in this Act clarified and strengthened the rights of a person to be a party to an inquiry.

(2) The Broadcasting and Television Legislation Amendment Act 1985 reaffirmed the power of the Tribunal to determine and administer standards in relation to the broadcasting of programs and advertisements. These amendments became necessary as a result of decisions of the High Court and the Federal Court which raised doubts as to the Tribunal's powers to determine such standards. The amendments enable the Tribunal to determine standards with qualitative and quantitative elements extending powers to encompass the nature of the advertising matter and the frequency of broadcasting. The power to preclassify children's programs has been explicitly provided for in the legislation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken to encourage the development of public television.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Broadcasting Act 1942 provides for the licensing of public television services, but so far, no applications have been invited. My Department has been involved in comprehensive discussions with the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia (PBAA) on a possible framework for introducing Public Television but no solution has yet been identified to the question of funding. Draft guidelines were prepared in 1981, but have not been implemented because of the difficult threshold issues such as funding as well as the limited planning resources available within my Department. At this stage the Government's present priorities are to increase the number of commercial radio and television services in non-metropolitan areas.

Discussions are continuing with PBAA and other television industry representatives on possible future introduction of public television. One possibility being considered is to use the public television provisions as a means of addressing local programming for small remote communities, including Aboriginal communities, following the introduction of satellite broadcasting services.
